Im writing my review as new player to the Yakuza franchise so please understand (Sorry in advance!)

My issue with this game was that the story didnt start becoming interesting until chapter 11. I felt like I was tied to the back of a truck and dragged through the streets of Kamurochi against my will. I had to really fight through the story building. This feeling mainly stemmed from not having any connection to Tak, the protagonist. I felt more affinity to Kaito than Tak in early game. Because his backstory is left in the dark and we dont really seem much of it until late game, I was left wondering "Why does he care this much?". i felt like I was plopped into a drama that I had no business running in. For someone who spent much of his time doing odd jobs and such I didnt see why he felt so strongly about THIS case. Granted the story did end up becoming more interesting, by that time I was already exhausted by playing 18 hours of side missions and Keihin gang antics. I truly wish I could have enjoyed this game more. The combat was decent and the overall story was very well written , but for me the pacing was very off. I reached out to friends who loved the game to see if I was missing something and was told to just be patient but GYATDANG. For a 13 chapter story, to only really see the fruition of the plot in the last two chapters is mad. 

In the previous Yakuza games I played, what made me love them was the feeling of vengeance I was chasing all game. Whether it be a murder off rip or a betrayal, I would chase to the end of the game for my MC's retribution. I felt that this was missing for Tak. I didnt really care to see through the story UNTIL chapter 11 where more info is revealed. 

I will likely still continue to play through to Lost Judgement just to have all the Yakuza games complete but I am bummed that I seemed to have missed something of a gem here..

The best Detective/mystery story I've witnessed in a video game . It has it's problems and is missing a lot of fun side activities like Cabaret club, karaoke. dancing, fishing etc and the Combat could be a little deeper. But regardless of these the Pros of the Game greatly outweigh the cons. Amazing mystery plot, really amazing characters and their developments that even made me tear up in a couple of places and the fun combat. If you like doing side activities with a lot of dialogue  but with no voice acting, then you'll absolutely love this game. I personally can't get immersed if the side quests are not voiced. So mostly I skipped most of the side quests' dialogue. Now this game is not perfect , not the best yakuza game but it's at least top 5. Only if it didn't have those god awful tailing missions , could clearly tell that was for padding purposes as most of the time there needn't be any tailing required. even if you had to do it, you have a drone you can freely control. Why waste time hiding and following slowly. This is the most frustrating tailing mission in any game period. Also those god awful thumb lockpicking sections. hope they did a little more play testing with the controls as the sensitivity for the sticks were awful and no option to set the said sensitivity. 

Verdict: Great detective game with a twist where the story twists and turns, courtroom drama , fun fighting , bustling atmosphere . A game with a lot of hits and few misses. It was a fun ride to the end, can't wait to play the sequel.

Judgment is a phenomenal game set in the Yakuza/Like a Dragon universe, however it has barely any connections to Kiryu's adventures aside from Tojo Clan involvement and of course taking place in the city of Kamurocho. Yagami is a great departure from Kiryu's iconic stern and serious self as Yagami tends to crack more jokes but can get serious when the moment calls for it.

Like always the stories created by RGG are full of twist and turns especially in a game where the plot revolves around a murder mystery and conspiracy plot gripping the city of Kamurocho. You will get sucked into this game's plot immediately and while there were definitely sections that felt slower or less impact it all came around to have one of if not the best ending in a RGG game I have witnessed yet!

The music as always is amazingly composed as it is hard to not find a plethora of songs on these games' soundtracks that aren't amazing! Seeing how this game doesn't connect to much with the wider Yakuza world this game is worth purchasing for series newcomers, and if you miss the days of Yakuza's brawler/beat em' up combat since the series' move to turn-based RPG combat then, this will definitely give you that fix!

After the "end" to Kiryu's saga in the 6th entry in the Yakuza (Like a Dragon now), a spin-off entry was released before the shift in the main series to the turn-based entries. Judgment, known as Judge Eyes in Japan, is a different look into the city that has enraptured me and so many others, through the eyes of Takayuki Yagami, a detective working in Kamurocho. 

A former attorney, circumstances have him working a different job. As he takes on a case involving the killings of yakuza members, all with their eyes gouged out, the mysteries only pile up from then on, into well, another government conspiracy. But this one is one of the good ones, just like how Judgment's story is on the higher end of RGG Studio's entries. The mystery is done in a nice manner, and the links to the people behind it all are done very well. Yagami's own past is also connected to the cases, and some interesting things are done there. A good detective story, for a first foray into something different from the norm, that does the story beats pretty well, even if some side cases are awkwardly fitted in between chapters to fill time.

While Yagami himself doesn't have the immediate appeal as Kiryu or Ichiban, he is a pretty decent protagonist, and the people he hangs around with are pretty interesting and funny too, in certain instances. It's also nice contrasting the 35 year old Yagami being more tech savvy than the inept Kiryu (at 50 around this time no less), incorporating more modern features in the game. Kaito, his former yakuza friend, is charming and they also have banter back and forth that is pretty believable. Substories are done as side cases, which often times are strictly professional, but can also lead to some befriending of people involved in these cases. Some of them can be pretty funny and a bit on the wild side, like the Twisted Trio saga, and the humour you'd expect from the series is still present in a good number of these ones, amongst others that are just business. There's even times where the client aren't who they appear to be.

As Yagami is a detective, he has to build rapport with other people to get reputation, and to get cases to get paid. The friends system from Kiwami 2 is integrated here, as befriending certain establishments will allow special EX actions. There is a good reason to get friends as they will be able to greet you on the street form small boosts to the EX gauge, and there is also a side case that ties a good chunk of the previous friendships together, which is pretty good for those that do these kinds of things.

The XP system relies on getting SP, and while the gain of these can be kind of underwhelming (especially checking the KamuroGo list, this game's completion list, for the effort needed to attain some of these), it can be alleviated somewhat with the Growth Extract (Items that provide temporary buffs, constituting this game's crafting system), as it gives a flat 10% increase to almost all SP gains, including main story and completing KamuroGo actions, something extremely crucial on the Legend run. Otherwise, it relies on getting Hug Bomb Omegas, which give the largest SP boost at a hefty cost of 140,000 yen after investing into it through Quickstarter, and getting money isn't quite as easy when there's no business rolling in.

Money is tight in this game, and you can really feel it if you invest into everything the game throws at you. Drone racing, Quickstarting projects (oddly enough they almost all give or do what they advertised), it can all feel very overwhelming. The way to make any kind of real money is through the VR board game, which I wasn't feeling at first, but after getting the skill that slows the dice rolls considerably, I did find myself having fun in them while grinding for money in the 2-5 million yen range, on the later courses.

Combat in this game is the best so far in the Dragon Engine games. A flat upgrade to 6's combat, where moves feel very good, as Yagami has a different approach to fighting than say, Kiryu. No stored weapons though, which is somewhat of a shame considering Kiwami 2's improvements on that front. Some of the unlockables in combat skills feels game changing, such as the Triple Finisher, while others conflict with other skills. The counter from 0 is an unlockable skill, but if used, doesn't stun the attacker. This can prove fatal if one is trying to use Tiger style trying to use the Tiger Drop (unlockable in this game from an in-game QR code), one can be left in the red if the timing isn't correct. The skill that requires 6 "drunkenness" is counter-intuitive when above 6, as it removes all stacks of it, and the damage is not that great anyways. It is still the best it has felt with the main engine of these games though, and it's still funny being able to destroy anything if you run into it long enough. The concept of Deadly Attacks leaving parts of the health bar locked if you are hit  unless you use a health kit, or go to get healed, is something I'm mixed about, especially since guns will do that easily when they show up later in the game.

Minigames are decent, the usual fare of darts and gambling games are here, with arcade games from Sega's heyday (although I'm really sick of having to do Virtua Fighter 2), alongside Drone Racing, and lock picking related ones (which is really hard on Legend for no reason) to progress in stories or side cases. No karaoke is tough, but I guess they couldn't get Takuya Kimura (the guy who plays Yagami) to do that in these games. There is no Puyo Puyo in here, and that is a good thing, because trying to do mahjong with the wareme rules was already wack in itself. They really love that stuff over there, and I'm glad it's a one-time thing in this game. Kamuro of the Dead is fun as it's a Dead Souls and a House of the Dead reference, and easier than the respective game it's based on too.

The completion of this game still has sour spots though, and the Amon fight in this game felt cheaper than usual, at least it felt that way trying to get him done. One good thing about these Sega games that get ported to PC after an initial console release, is that the DLC that was on that console now comes pre-packaged in. This includes drone parts, office customization, and even clothes for the girlfriends you can make in the game, alongside some top end reusable extracts. Some of those extracts can be powerful, but they do have a time limit so you can't completely cheese the game. Anything to make the Legend run easier, I'll take, and boy, that last stretch you have to do without saving brought back Kiwami memories...

Aside some middling detective parts (trailing missions are meh, and you're not really penalized for presenting wrong evidence), Judgment is a pretty nice look into a different aspect of Kamurocho, while still retaining its seedy vibes. It is kind of a Yakuza game, with detective clothes on, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. A pretty good entry into the Like a Dragon franchise, and I am eager to continue Yagami's story in Lost Judgment.

Thanks to the 50% off sale I was able to try Judgement (Judge Eye). Previously I've played 10+ hours of Yakuza (Japanese Mafia) 0, still a newbie of the franchise but I get familiar with how events are presented and what to expect. Judgement is a branch related to the Yakuza games, with standalone characters and standalone story. For me, it's a good 20 hours for the main story and I had a lot of fun.

Judgement is story-driven and just like the trailer introduced, "playing this game is like watching a Japanese TV show". I browsed Youtube to find that the cutscenes took 19 hours, enough to create a mini-series. It burns slowly at the beginning but gradually it gets interesting, every little thing that seems isolated will eventually all come together and make sense, so try to be a little bit more patient, and get to know Japanese culture and the way they think.

I found Judgement a relaxing game.

Beside story and cutscenes, it involves lots of fighting but rest assured, Judgement does not require a master skill like it is in Street Fighting to beat up enemies, but the visual is satisfying because every hit takes count and effect. Special attacks will be unlocked with progress and purchase, easy to trigger in both advantage and disadvantage situations, and with 2 style efficient to aim single or group enemies, the fights never bore me. And you can always avoid random street fights if paying attention on the mini-map, or switch to easy mode.

For the detective part, no need to search every corner or burn your brain to solve a case. Only 4-5 items are to be found in the crime scene and to be presented at the court, things are straightforward so you don't need IQ 120 to pick the right evidence for conclusion in serious detective games like Danganronpa or Ace Attorney. If you miss something or make a wrong speculation, no worries, you can always choose again without punishment.

Now comes character and story. The protagonist is Takayuki Yagami, once a lawyer now a detective, the main story unfolds on why he changes occupation and what haunts his mind, new challenges and risks await him for every choice as he gets closer to finding out the truth. Also, Judgement involves major characters with high place in both yakuza and government agencies, they either stand or are against Yagami so there's no absolute conclusion on which side is good or bad, but everyone gets benefits and makes sense. Judgement is not a dark game, at the end justice is brought, and the feeling of a real event is the highlight. My only thought is the original name 'Judge Eyes' fits in better.

I recommend this game. However, Judgement is not perfect. There are repeated missions about tailing people and flying a drone with camera to gain evidence and both could be painful. if they are skippable I'd rate it 9.5/10.

[spoiler]3 years ago, A truck driver/cleaning worker was accused of murderer at a pharmaceutical research and development building. This place develops new medicine to cure Alzheimer patients, evidence leads to one of the patients being murdered with a body found in the truck. The truck driver insists he's framed and defense lawyer Takayuki Yagami successfully gave him freedom but shortly after, this truck driver killed his girlfriend then burnt the house down. The media hyped the event and with self guilt, Yagami quit being a lawyer and became a private detective.
Back to now, yakuza members, a lawyer and a prosecutor have been found dead with both eyes gouged out (Why take the trouble? What happens to the eyeballs?). Yagami looked into the case, and with help from a corrupt police who delivers secret files, things are linked to this promising medicine development for a Alzheimer cure called AD-9, which is actually a failure but publicly states a near success. With the potential huge benefit of both fame and money, the head of a yakuza family and government agencies protect it.
Turns out the key developer for AD-9 illegally tested on humans and no one has survived. All the corpses are taken care of by the Head of Police dept Mitsuru Kuroiwa, who's also a fight master aka the Mole, kills whoever hinders the medicine's procedure and takes out tester's eyes since they became scary blue. He's the one who was the truck driver's girlfriend.
When AD-9's failure is known to the public, the benefit chain has broken and everyone's for themselves. Yagami and his buddies chased Kuroiwa who's after Shono, in the end, Yagami beat Kuroiwa and Kuroiwa is shot by several police officers, he had the delusion to see Shono made AD-9 and died seeing Shono injected himself with a dose he thought successful yet eventually killed himself.

Another game by Ryuu Ga Gotoku studio (RGG), much like its better known "Yakuza" series.
Overall, more of the same so if you liked Yakuzas this will not be a miss.

Action game with a lot of fighting, and a lot less detective/lawyer-work.
It is nice to see the studio try to branch into different game styles, but personally, I just found this to be more or less like the other Yakuza games.
There is a big overarching conspiracy that the protagonist is trying to solve, and the main way protagonist does that is through being a basically unstoppable fighter.
You would think they would tone it down with the protagonist being a lawyer/detective, but that does not seem to be the case as Yagami (the protagonist) is honestly comparable to Kiryu, and even learns one of his signature moves just like that.
Most of the answers Yagami has to beat out of others, yet the game tries to play his combat prowess off.
There are a few cases where Yagami tries to avoid danger by saying "but they have an army in there" or "it's too dangerous", despite having a proven track record of being basically unstoppable, and the game basically throwing you into such situations anyway.
Really, the only thing holding him back is the new mechanic of "mortal wounds" which is a type of permanent damage that requires a doctor or an actual medkit to heal (of which you get a very limited amount you can carry), but on a normal casual playthrough it does not seem to be a very limiting factor, so carrying a whole shop's worth of food is still a viable strat.
I guess on this note, I will also mention that I was not particularly sold on fighting in this game neither, it just felt janky.
Like one of your best attacks is a charged light attack, which tends to work at the start, but then bosses just shake it off, even if you can perfectly see that it should have connected.
Some skills and critically, dodging, are reliant on lock-on which honestly fucking sucks, as it seems to more lock your character's view than lock you onto an enemy.
I found myself walking back-first into the boss multiple times because I tried using the lock-on, so in the end, I would really rather not have to use it, but alas.

Detective/Lawyer side felt a lot weaker compared to the action.
Sure, there is evidence-gathering and such, but it feels kinda barebones, and there are like only 3 cases, which all get rolled into one by the end of the game, anyway.
Game labels a lot of things as "cases", but realistically, those are more information storage and fancier side quests than actual mysteries.
Some also get abruptly "solved" at some point, too, at least according to the UI.
I want to draw a parallel to Danganronpa here - in that game, there are clear cases, you go gather evidence for them as they occur, and with some effort it is even possible to put all the pieces together before the game tells you how it all actually went down.
Here, I found myself figuring out the first 2 cases easily enough, and the last one was basically the whole story that became clear like 1/2 or 2/3 into the story, with the rest of it going about trying to collect proof.

Gameplay-wise, this game feels and plays like any other RGG game.
Kamurocho is open for the player to explore, and has more activities than necessary with a touch of some Japanese bs.
There are great graphics and motion provided by the modern Dragon Engine.
Of note this time, I guess there are drone races that I completely skipped, but heard are really brutal, and the "VR game".
The latter is just a virtual Kamurocho that Yagami can plunge himself into to play a simple board game that puts him into various minigames depending on the tile he lands, of which more interesting are again, fights.
Those fights can, and will have challenges in them that can be actually challenging (like going against an enemy that has all its attacks count as "mortal wounds" and limit your HP bar) to fun spins like "kill everything with a railgun".
This VR thing also pays an absolutely stupid amount of money, playing it for like 5 times has given me more than enough funds to go through the rest of the game.
It also has an annoyingly catchy BGM.

To summarize, this is an okay spin on the usual formula RGG employs.
People who are already familiar with Kamurocho get another excuse to delve into it, and those who are not are in for an okay introduction into the franchise (though, probably Yakuza 0 is a better start).

[b] A Detective's Tale in the Yakuza World with a Side of Hot Sauce [/b]

Alright, folks, grab your magnifying glass and your sense of humor, because I'm about to take you on a whirlwind tour of "Judgment," the game where you play a detective that's part Sherlock Holmes, part Jackie Chan, and all Yakuza.

First up, let's talk gameplay. You've got your standard Yakuza brawling, now with a side dish of detective work that's as challenging as choosing what to order at a fast-food joint. Lockpicking? More like a tutorial that never ends. Crime scene investigations? More like a game of 'find the object' with training wheels. And tailing suspects? Well, letâ€™s just say it's a good time to catch up on your podcasts.

But wait, there's more! You're also playing a bit of Phoenix Wright here, minus the thrill of courtroom drama. Your dialogue choices during investigations? They matter as much as asking for no ice in your drink at a self-serve soda fountain. No real consequences, just the illusion of choice.

Now, letâ€™s talk about the heart and soul of the game â€“ the combat. Think of it as a dance, but you're dancing with street thugs and the occasional ninja. Yes, a ninja! Youâ€™ve got two fighting styles â€“ one for the crowds, and one for those intimate one-on-one encounters. And letâ€™s not forget the delightful absurdity of using hot sauce as a weapon. Thatâ€™s right, hot sauce in the eyes, because why not?

But what really shines in "Judgment" is its story. It's a twisting, turning narrative thatâ€™ll keep you guessing more than a game of Clue in the dark. Itâ€™s the kind of story that makes the less exciting gameplay worth it, just to see what happens next.

The game's not without its quirks. Like, why do side characters in cutscenes move like they're in a school play? And speaking of side missions, they intertwine with the main story, but suddenly the characters forget how to talk. It's like going from a Broadway show to a silent film in seconds.

So, is "Judgment" a Yakuza game in disguise? Absolutely. But it's like wearing a vampire costume to go undercover â€“ obvious, but somehow it works. It's a game that's not afraid to be a bit silly, a bit serious, and a lot of fun.

In conclusion, "Judgment" is for those who enjoy their detective stories with a side of street fighting, a dash of comedy, and a sprinkle of Yakuza magic. It might not be the perfect game, but it's a perfect way to spend a weekend solving crimes and doling out street justice, Yakuza-style.

Judgment is an action-adventure game developed by Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio and published by Sega. The game was released for the PlayStation 4 in 2018 in Japan and June 2019 for the worldwide release. The PC version was released on Steam in September 2022 as part of the Judgment series bundle. Judgment is the first game of the Judgment series, a spin-off to the Yakuza/Like a Dragon franchise. The story takes place in 2018 and the player play as Takayuki Yagami, a former attorney turned private detective whose past events haunted him while a series of killings took place in Kamurocho. Yagami confronts his past and solve the killings with legal courtroom dramas, investigations, and martial arts. Judgment has similarities and differences to the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series. Does Segaâ€™s and RGG Studioâ€™s new IP spin-off series got your intrigue?

Like the main Yakuza franchise, Judgment has a strong story and voice acting. Judgment took the story element further and I found myself really invested on the story. Judgment is also more character driven and leans heavily on the acting performance. The protagonist, Takayuki Yagami, is played by Takuya Kimura. From what I read about the actor, heâ€™s famous in Japan. The story in Judgment is interesting and has some neo-noir flair as the story is formatted like an TV mini-series. The gameplay is familiar to the mainline series, so I wonâ€™t review it further. However, there are some enhancements and subtle qualities of life.  

One of the major differences are the combat styles: the Crane and Tiger. Crane is suited for fighting against multiple opponents while Tiger focuses on one target. However, the different fighting styles are not too tied up so you can still use either style on any fighting scenarios. I do find the fighting techniques somewhat in reminisce to the older, Hong Kong martial arts films from the 1970s and 1980s. Feels like a Jackie Chan or Donnie Yen film at times. The dynamic intros are cinematic and well choreograph. The soundtrack for the combat styles is addicting to listen to. Furthermore, I found the overall soundtrack for Judgment to be very memorable, catchy, and straight banging. The composers for RGG Studio have done themselves an outstanding job.
 
The â€œside casesâ€ are the same as substories, but the minor characters are involved in assisting the protagonist in certain situations. Itâ€™s like Yakuza Kiwami 2, but itâ€™s expanded, and the minor characters are useful. Since the player is a private detective, there are investigation mechanics like trailing a suspected character, chasing, disguises, and search modes. In addition, there are new minigames like drone racing/customization and Dice & Cube courses at Paradise VR (an â€œVRâ€ monopoly type game for the player to earn money).

Judgmentâ€™s strengths are noteworthy and commendable, but there are some imperfections. Yagamiâ€™s investigations mechanics feels light and an experiment that didnâ€™t expand further. The skill points are hard to earn and takes a while to get all the points to unlock all skills. Thereâ€™s a certain â€œexploitâ€ by purchasing a specific drink, consume, and grind the Paradise VR minigame. Itâ€™s really a detachment and does hinder the game for those who want a perfectionist run, like me. Doing the minigames, activities, combat encounters, and food/drink consumptions are not enough.

Judgment is unique because thereâ€™s not a game where the player can play as a former attorney turned private detective who knows martial arts. There are some influences like Ace Attorney, various courtroom TV-drama series, and Hong Kong kung-fu films but RGG Studio puts a unique spin and learned the lessons on their experiences on the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series, applying on what can be considered as one of the unique games released. There are lots of established franchises in the video game industry and I commend the developers for doing something original. As the first title for the new spin-off series, I look forward on how future title(s) improve in Lost Judgment and possibly how it parallels the main series. The game has my recommendation for both newcomers and long-time fans.

After the awesome journey of Like a Dragon: Gaiden, this game was my obvious next foray into the 'you as a suit wearing guy see some ugly mfs and beat em up' genre, and now maybe I can say I'm a real RGG(Ryu Ga Gotoku) fan.
For starters, I rue the fact that this game was brought up to me this late due to release cadence, it is important to note that at the time RGG studio games have a JP exclusive time window, that window is often spent on PS platforms only. For the same reason the series might be hard to continue from the side of the devs due to disagreements with the Actor's management group from Japan, thanks to the devs tho, playing on pc now is still a perfectly whole experience.
This game has the same basic legs of the main RGG yakuza games, only this game sees the Dragon Engine shine like never before (just don't be fooled because the wacky physics and confusing ragdolls are not gone). The story blows everything you've seen out of the water but closely resembles J-drama (in this genre some of the contemporary story lines borrow and refine from Agatha Christie novels, you'll see some of those here), although maybe the story relies a little bit too much on yakuza knowledge from the main series, but still can be enjoyed as the protagonist you play really is his own thing.
Combat wise this has lots of jank that would be fixed in the sequel Lost Judgement, there are skills you can pick up early on to sidestep the difficulty, but playing the game normally while you abuse your ability to release the fist of JUSTICE after bouncing from walls should make it a smooth and fun experience.
Be wary of the length, don't try to beat the it one go, and go play the next game when the amazing story is still in your brain.

This is more of a list of complaints and things I liked as a Yakuza fan so it not going to cover story, graphics and others. 

This studio in all of their games reuse a lot of the same styles, characters, NPC's, mission types, side missions, and extra goodies. Now don't get me wrong, the city seeing it change over the Yakuza games is awesome, but the developer since they arent really tying much of the Yakuza series to it, then why bother? Its disappointing since they wanted to go to this new route but didnt really do much new stuff in a new city. Hell even Yakuza 3 went and brought in another city entirely, why couldnt it have been done here?

The fighting is new, and interesting and very stylistic, though the same 2-3 mobs keep coming at you all the time. This is really sad since even in previous games the makeup of the random mobs would at least look different, most of the time. Here its such a small pool of NPCs. The fighting is limited to two styles, the Crane being the most useless of the two. Upgrading the styles is grindy so I wouldnt say it is worth it. The encounter rate is nothing like, Like a Dragon, but there are a lot of random encounters in the game...wayyyyy too many!  Also, what in the hell, the stagger times when you get hit are way too long. Want to go for realism? Great. That would have clearly hurt but these guys are going to stand around and wait for me to get up from being staggered, yeah right. Also, whats up with the rag doll physics? Ive seen mens bodies do the same thing as bouncy balls and running into a bicycle can send it into the air? Lastly about fighting, I would have to say, the most annoying parts is while you are holding someone, the other NPC's can clearly just knock you out, which is completely dumb. I even got knocked out in a fight while holding and beating the guy down and the other NPCs whacked me, very very annoying. Again, going for realism is fine, but the line isnt very clear on how this was mapped out. 

I really enjoyed that they kept the environmental impacts when fighting. Nothing cooler then fighting and you throw or kick someone through the windows, or even using some of the verticality to use an EX move on the mobs. Speaking of which, the EX moves are just like all the other games, meaning the further you get into the game, the more of these you can spam, invalidating some bosses if not all, completely. For me, if you put in the time, and get the power ups, I feel great when I just own the crap out of a boss, as there EX moves just like in previous games become a real bummer to fight against, so the EX stuff is definitely cool. Plus the all new animations across the city are neat, especially the ones with friends. As well, different friends from cases around the city can lead to new items or tricks up Yagami's sleeve including extracts. Basically drinks from vending machines from previous games giving you a boost but there are some interesting elemental attacks that you gain which is super neat. Interestingly enough, all of them are made from little items you pick-up throughout the city. How does a fire element attack work, when you combine fish soup, cat food and some shabby wire! Who knows but it does!

Regarding the little items, it seems this is a borrowed effect from open world games, so its annoying but useful. Useful for extracts but also useful for one of the coolest parts of the game, Drone Racing! I would recommend trying this out to all players and getting through the whole thing, very much worth the time!

Going back to the city and the NPC's, this feels a lot more like, Like a Dragon then the Yakuza series as the side cases (side missions) this time around can and will lead to assistance in the city. You protect them, and they will help you when a mob tries to take you on. Its good stuff, albeit very very repetitive. It feels like you really are a hero to these people and them helping you while battling is just a nice touch. It is interesting, going back to the over used assets and numerous NPC's that look the same every where, once you get some help from certain people, they basically roam the city doing their "city" thing. Some even walk the street looking for fights to get in with you, to help you. With that said, they are every where, I mean the same NPC. There is no realism here at all. Im up and down the streets, from one end of the map to another and I see the same lady on both sides, just reappear. I feel this is lazy and dumb. 

The detective work, although fresh, really turns into, tail missions, camera missions and really boiled down to it, is really just side missions from the Yakuza games. Many of them are just as ridiculous with no real value to the stories but that was often the case with the Yakuza games so no real change here. Sure there are some tie-ins, but not much. The detective work is super repetitive, and there isnt really a fail, which is fine because in all actuality, by chapter 5-6, most players will have had enough of it. 

Speaking of the tailing missions, sometimes they go on for way too long and then my question, who thought it was a good idea for you to just run behind a corner real fast while the meter goes up and the NPC you are tailing is like, well I guess thats not strange at all! Dumb. 

I think one of my biggest gripes on the game is the studio is just lazy with assets, overusing them to the point that it was like, what in the hell were they thinking or just didnt care. Here's another Yakuza game, we know you'll grind away, and by the way, no quick load, and no Karaoke.
Honestly one of the best stories RGG has told. Keeping me interested the whole way through

Judgment has been a very fresh and interesting new experience, given the new character cast, gameplay and stylistic elements of the game, even though its still based in the same universe as the more established Yakuza/Like A Dragon series franchise.

Plot wise it was a nice tempo and really liked the chemistry between the various cast members, especially Yagami and Kaito, along with the rest of the new supporting cast.  The storytelling was superb as it was able to weave in back stories through out the narrative, whilst baking in various plot twists given it is a detective/mystery crime thriller.

Combat wise it was definitely a stark difference from mainline Yakuza/Like A Dragon as Yagami is more of a technical fighter rather than a combatant relying just solely on brute force.  The initial fights at the beginning were tough to master, however once more SP skills were unlocked, the combat got noticeably easier which was a relief and interesting growth experience on its own.

Particularly interesting and new are the observation and tailing missions.  I think it certainly fitted in well with the genre and as a first version in the first game I'm fine with it, though I hear from others it might be quite cumbersome.  Hopefully future renditions will fine tune this formula further, but was a good enough immersive experience for me.

Side cases are the sub stories equivalent and have been just as wacky and serious.  I also really like the nice music that complements the overall game play through out the main and side quests.

I also really enjoyed the uniquely new activities such as Drone Racing and Dice & Cube VR, which complemented the modern technology vibe brought about by a younger more tech savvy protagonist.

However, some of the pain points include grinding a fair bit for cash to use in the Kickstarter App and to support unlocking all the SP skills for completion.

Overall, it was a very fun time I had in this first spin-off in what I can imagine will be a successful new series by the RGG studio.  Looking forward to solving more detective mysteries with Yagami and Kaito in the next one.

Out of all the Yakuza games, this one slapped the most. Completely separate from the main line titles makes this game easy to jump into for new players not immersed in the universe and the whole design premise of the style switching combat from Yakuza 0, in the funny and slick physics engine already had me sold.

Gameplay - In my opinion the previous entries within this new engine (Yakuza 6, and Kiwami 2) never really fully utilized the crazy tech you would be able to pull off in previous titles, and boiled down to spam punching combos till enemy dies. The previous games were carried by their funny wacky physics of punch guys into space and objects and watch them clip over the place (which not at all makes the those games bad, in fact I enjoyed 6 and its craziest physics). However, during Kiwami 2's collesium side content, some bosses would put me through the mix with unbreakable action moves happening in real time and I wondered how those moves would operate if they were actual techniques you could pull off yourself in game. Well, this game manages that, it gives you tech off the wazoo. You wanna throw yourself off a wall and swing on enemies like a monkey? You can do that. You wanna play hop scotch and reverse suplex enemies into the ground? You can do that. You wanna insta kill blast opponents with a simple open palm move that makes a funny bass noise? You can do that. Hell, remember me talking about those moves in kiwami 2 that bosses pulled on ya? You can actually deploy those moves from extraction potions that you craft and completely alter your fighting style. I haven't even talked about the two main styles you can switch to, and honestly I have already said too much. The best part about the two new styles (crane, and tiger), was figuring out what they do, and where to use them. So ill leave it off there.

Setting - For returning players we see the return of Kamurocho from the eyes of a disgraced lawyer turned small time detective. Now, even halfway through the game I knew that this was one of the best iterations of Kamurocho in the entire series (previous qualifiers were Yakuza 0's time switch, and Yakuza 4's verticality). What makes this Kamurocho so great is the friend's system. Its the best version of previous title's reputation grind, but its actually good this time cuz unlike previous titles where you would do a citizen's rep meter, and would never see them again or hear from them. In this game, you not only see them wandering the streets, you see them aiding you with crafting materials, boosting your EX meter, or aiding you in fights whether with ally heat animations, or tagging along in fights. The new northern part of Kamurocho being the "Hills Garden" area was really beautiful and the new areas within the city that makes it easy to traverse thanks to Yagami's parkour god skills, makes carving shortcuts through point A to B, fun. The story was also one of the best this series has to offer, and is carried by the cast of characters you that surround yourself with throughout the game. At the credit screen I was already wanting to jump back into that iconic detective's office that you come love by the end of the game. Its that good.

Mini games - Now I will admit, this is the weakest lineup of mini games within the series. Now does that mean the side content in this game is bad? No. You have your basic mini games that you've come to expect in previous titles like baseball, returning sega arcade games, mahjong, etc. Even with the returning mini games, they manage to spice things up, shogi now has a much needed mini feature of having checkmate problems to solve presented as "puzzle shogi" which to me was insanely addicting to solve, along with mahjong getting a whole new parlor named "Tachibana" which was mahjong on crack, which was high rated nuts to butts action with the "wareme" rule. This game had my favorite sega arcade lineup in awhile simply because of the amount of fun I had with "Fighting Vipers" which is now my definitive favorite fighting game ever. Unfortunately no karaoke, that seems to be specific to the mainline titles, but the brand new exclusive mini games to Judgment weren't exciting to me ON PAPER, but ended up being pretty damn fun. Drone racing was a blast, and in my opinion was better than Yakuza 7's dragon kart mini game. Simply because of the deep amount of customization you can apply to your drone and the 3D racing environment giving you more exhilarating, high octane, ball sack quenching moments maneuvering through tight corroders within cafes, and buildings. Finally, we have Paradise VR which is a single player mario party type game that has you avoiding black cats, conquering challenges, and scoring big. This was my main money maker throughout the game and though it did get a little bit boring near endgame with constantly running this mini game for cash it definitely was fresh air from the meta in previous titles which had you just go to the casino or gambling hall to win big and I am thankful nonetheless for the change in scenery.

I haven't had that much fun with a Yakuza game since the first one I played which was Yakuza 0. Def. a must have for people getting into the series or fans who have money to burn.

10/10 MASTERPIECE!

I got to be honest with you guys. I would have never thought that this game or the Judgment series in general would ever come to PC (I'll exclude Google Stadia that no longer exist. RIP).

There were some rumors and speculation e.g.: "Lost Judgment will be the last game in the series due to a disagreement between Sega and Johnny & Associates, the talent agency behind Takayuki Yagami actor Takuya Kimura. The fallout stems from Johnny & Associates not wanting the Judgment games to launch for PC, as it conflicts with its particularly strict likeness policy â€” essentially, the company doesnâ€™t want Kimuraâ€™s face to be so readily accessible on the internet." (quote from The Gamer, published on Aug 23, 2021).

When I read these articles, my hopes were shattered. Because the game was pretty good. And it would be a shame if the series becomes a lost medium in the future because it's tied to consoles and if the two big companies (Sony and Microsoft) don't support backwards compatibility, you're limited to old hardware. That's why I always write reviews in which I ask for new releases of old games. 

And then there was the day Sega casually dropped a trailer that Judgment and Lost Judgment (+ DLC) were available on Steam. 
You have no clue how happy I was. Just the fact that there's a game on PC that I'm interested in is a reason for me to buy it. 
Hell, even if it was released only on GOG I'd buy it on that platform, as long as it's not available on the Epic Games Store I'm good (EGS is still an empty Fortnite launcher for me).
And if you are complaining about Denuvo, then just wait until Sega remove it. I hope that they will not delist Judgment and Lost Judgment because of the quote (about those rumors and speculation) above. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Now, with all that being said, let me tell you how the game was for me.
The gameplay, story mode, cutscenes, etc are great. Especially the action sequences. It feels like I'm watching a Hongkong martial arts movie with noir vibe. XD

I almost forgot that Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio is a AA studio and not AAA. They are well-known for recycling assets and using the same map again (except for the new games). 
As long as they tell good stories, I have no problem with that.

If you don't like Judgment, you can still play these arcade games: Virtua Fighter 5 Final Showdown, PuyoPuyo, Fantasy Zone, Fighting Vipers, Kamuro of the Dead (similar to House of the Dead), Motor Raid, Space Harrier and Outrun.  So there are many ways to enjoy this game.


Total and a message to Sega:
Sega, I want to thank you again from the bottom of my heart for releasing this game on Steam. This game is now one of my favorite games of all-time. ^^
I really hope that you will release more of your old games on Steam, especially Fist of the North Star: Lost Paradise and Skies of Arcadia. ^^

As of writing this review it is currently past 1:00 AM for me but I am in my feels at the moment from completing this game, and despite being very tired and wanting to go to bed I really feel like this game deserves a positive review so I will get straight to the point:

- The story was great, I found it very refreshing to play a detective/lawyer sort of role in the Yakuza/Like a Dragon universe. There were several thrilling moments, plot twists, and classic Yakuza/Like a Dragon humor that made playing this game very enjoyable. There is so much content in this game, despite having 55 hours at the time I completed the main story it still appears I have a lot left to complete in the game. I felt really connected to the characters in the game. 

- The soundtrack once again is amazing. This game has some of my favorite boss themes to date and its final boss theme is ranked as one of my top boss themes in all of the Yakuza/Like a Dragon games so far. The end credit songs were also bangers. 

- This is something that I haven't really commented on other game reviews I've done, but I very much liked the art style of Judgement, especially whatever font was used for chapter introductions and boss battle titles. 

- Combat was really cool as well, I really liked the QTE's that were included in battles and boss battles in this game, they do their job of making you feel cool. I liked the straightforwardness of having two fighting styles, one for controlling crowds and one for more one-on-one fights, and even then you can still branch out skills for each of the fighting styles. 

This is what is at the top of my mind for now, if I think of more to say as I let everything sink in for a bit I will edit the review. But nonetheless I really enjoyed this game and am very much looking forward to playing its sequel.

For a Yakuza spin off, Judgement does a really good job; in fact, it does even more then most Yakuza games.

[h3] The Combat [/h3]

I played this game straight after Yakuza 6 [i] (I completed Y:LAD) [/i], and despite the game releasing in the next 2 years [i] (1 Year when Kiwami 2 came out) [/i] it has a really polished combat system. Yakuza 6 suffered from the unpolished combat system, since it was a new engine; while, Yakuza Kiwami 2 suffered by making Kiryu a [b] GOD [/b] by making his Heat Actions deal damage equivalent to the power of a Sun. Judgement marks the return [i] (For now) [/i] of combat styles, and one of them is clearly superior than the other. The Tiger Style is supposed to be focused against one to one fights, and its many style specific abilities show that. The Tiger Style's Flux Fissure ability makes every enemy a joke because, Flux Fissure does a stupid amount of damage, and give around 2 heat bars. The Crane Style is an okay style since the only problem of Crane is that it does not have any style specific abilities. Both styles still have "launchers" to start juggling, and it usually is 4 light attacks followed by 1-2 heavy attacks. The juggling in Judgement is not that insane compared to Lost Judgement. Another thing that both styles have is the ability to perfect block, Tiger Style has a perfect block that can be followed by 3 options: Light Attack Launcher, Heavy Attack "get off me", and Flux Fissure; while the Crane Style has its perfect block become a dodge combined combined with a light attack. Extreme Heat is still here, and it is VERY BROKEN. Extreme Heat allows you to become fully invincible to ALL attacks, and gain access to EX-Heat Actions which can be broken. Tiger's EX Heat Action is focused on one target; whilst, Crane's EX Heat Action can hit multiple targets (Up to 3). Overall, Judgement's Combat is EXTREMELY good.

[h3] The Prologue (Spoiler-Free) [/h3]

Judgement's story follows Yagami, a Lawyer turned Private Investigator, and his friend Kaito, an ex-Yakuza turned Private Investigator. The game starts off with a flashback to a younger Yagami who is a Lawyer for the Genda Law office. Yagami had recently defended a client named Okubo in a murder case of a dementia ridden patient named Waku in the Advanced Drug Center (ADC). Okubo had a ton of evidence against him due to his job at the ADC (Laundry duty), his past violence due to being somewhat of an alcoholic, the fact that the body was dumped inside Okubo's truck, and the fact that he buried the body. Yagami won this case, and Okubo was set free; however, trouble returns since the Genda Law Office received a phone call about Okubo murdering Emi, a nurse who "helped defend" Okubo in the trial and his girlfriend; which Yagami does not believe is true. In this murder case, Okubo had a ton of evidence against him. Okubo, despite being sober for the past years, was intoxicated at the time of the murder, and his clothes were all bloody. The defense was not successful this time, and Okubo was sentenced to death and transferred to a detention center to be held until the day he will get executed. Yagami's reputation gets tarnished since he had defended a murder; and because of that, Yagami quits being a Lawyer. Yagami soon becomes a private investigator with his own office to escape from the guilt of defending a murder. This brief prologue sets up the story, and events of Judgement since pretty much everything is connected into a web of conspiracy. Yagami ventures out to seek the truth to find the true killer... to find the elusive Mole.

[h3] The "not really good things" [/h3]

This section is just a rant of a few things that I do not like in Judgement.
[list]
[*] [b] Tailing Missions [/b], these get old very quickly. Its just walking around the streets following a dude slowly for 5 minutes offering really nothing to value. Side cases are filled with these.
[*] [b] Some Investigations [/b], most investigations are fine; however, some investigations require you to look at a specific thing first before spotting an obvious clue.
[*] [b] Lockpicking sometimes [/b], sometimes the locks are very easy and have a decent window to get them correct, others don't, and I hate those.
[*] [b] Mandatory Side cases [/b], some are usually okay; however, it gets annoying really quickly when I want to focus on the main cases.

RGG studio doesn't make bad games (at least, not since Dead Souls). I was wondering how this would feel, without the strong personalities of the mainline games' protagonists. Instead, you play a pretty boy in skinny jeans, but Yagami feels like a natural fit in the setting, and is interesting for a totally different reason than Kiryu and company.

The narrative here almost feels like a throwback to the neo-noir of Yakuza 4, but, at least so far, the story hasn't taken a big wet turd on itself (if you know, you know). Instead, it's a broody, sometimes shocking story filled with tension, surprise, and intrigue. The investigation stuff is pretty linear, in the style of a Danganrompa or Ace Attorney game, but the linearity doesn't really matter once you let it sweep you up. And while the tailing missions are a chore (yeah, I get why every review complains about them), they're also a great way to slow down the pace, get you to focus in a different way. 

If you played any other Dragon Engine game set in Tokyo (Yakuza 6, Kiwami 2), then you know how the exploration is going to go, and you can guess what minigames from earlier in the series return (mahjong, shogi, casino stuff), and which ones are still gone (bowling, we miss you). 

Add to that familiar stuff the new experiences of piloting a drone around, a slightly more fleshed out friendship system, the revamping of heat into the not-quite-exactly-the-same EX system, and the whole new cast, main and supporting, and this is a great addition if you're a fan of RGG's other games, as well as a wonderful entry point into the cracked-mirror version of Kabukicho that RGG has been building for the last two decades. Thumbs way up. I'm only in chapter 5, and it's already captivating.

Edited to add: Oh, right, I forgot to mention the English dub, which RGG wasn't really doing prior to this (except Fist of the North Star). It's excellent. Sega and their subsidiaries tend to do great voice casting and direction, and this is no exception. So if the mainline Yakuza series' lack of English VA turned you off, this has that option (but also comes with the Japanese dub as well if you're a purist; the best of both worlds)

This has to be one of the greatest intros ever in a video game. It pulled me in as much as anime does, the game itself is anime, the intro is anime, and they pull out a bad ass anime style song too. The story is killer, all though it does get a bit slow at times, but it just had a way of pulling me back in. I have enjoyed only a few games this year, Starfield is great, but I also like the Bethesda style of game. Dead Island 2 was fantastic, but it was too short. I can't say, or even think of a better series of games in my life. At this point Ryu Ga Gotoku has become one of the worlds best development studios, They have mastered the entertainment of beat 'em up style games, they have great writing, and every game feels distinct, and different. The "Twist" is in the nature of a lot of their games, however they just keep getting better and better at hiding it, and allowing you to be surprised like you'd hope.

Cinematic 9.5 / 10 I think they could've done a bit more with the smoke, but it was so bad ass, probably one of the best, if not the best intro to a game I have ever played, and the best I have ever seen.

Story 8 / 10 it did get slow, but it wasn't slow enough to make me stop, in fact just when it got slow, just when I started to feel like it was bad, suddenly it ripped me back in, it pulled me into the story, the comedy, the writing, and the characters are great.

The Voice Acting 6 / 10 the voices don't really fit the character, and some people kind of make 0 sense speaking english, but it got a lot better as the game went on, to the point that I basically forgot that the voices were weird, the main weird one is the best friend Kaito, his voice is definitely too deep, and strange for the look of his character, however. The main character has to have literally the perfect voice for how he looks, and holds himself. Makes me think they may have even literally made the character after him.

Fighting 8 / 10 its a yakuza / Like a dragon game, of course the fighting is great at this point. The moves feel amazing, but the funnier thing is the extracts you get can kinda just remove fighting.

This game series stands as the pinnacle of my gaming experiences. RGG consistently delivers an exhilarating rush of beat 'em up action that never fails to release a flood of dopamine. Lost Judgment is no exception, offering an unbeatable combination of characters, storylines, and a soundtrack that's nothing short of exceptional.

Picture a fusion of the adrenaline of John Wick, the open-world freedom of GTA, the hacking intrigue of Watch Dogs, the zombie mayhem of Dead Rising, and the dramatic storytelling of Yakuza, all seamlessly integrated into one breathtaking series. This masterpiece of a series has been executed with a level of craftsmanship that leaves no room for disappointment.

I wholeheartedly encourage anyone who hasn't yet ventured into these games to give them a try. They are true masterpieces that have the power to enrich your life in the most remarkable ways.

Judgment proves itself as a standout addition to the Yakuza series, with its most prominent strength lying in its gripping narrative. It strikes a balance, delivering complexity and unexpected twists without veering into the labyrinthine territory of some mainline Yakuza titles.

The side quests, an integral part of the Yakuza experience, are also mostly very enjoyable. The sub-stories revolve around Yagami, taking on various detective cases and making you feel like a man with work to do rather than just being a local errand boy. 

While Judgment excels in many areas, it does stumble slightly in its boss fights. These encounters lack the dramatic flair that you might expect from a Yakuza game, and the accompanying soundtracks fail to leave a lasting impression. Nonetheless, it's important to note that Yagami's identity leans more towards that of a detective rather than a brawler, and this aspect is reflected in the gameplay. Sadly, the detective elements suffer from an excessive amount of hand-holding, making them feel less challenging than they could have been.

Overall Judgement is a game with great characters, a great story, and is an entry to the franchise that should not be missed.

Honestly, it's a fantastic game. The story gripped me all the way through, which very few games can do for me these days. You've got all the side stories as well, which are always unique, along with quirky, memorable characters. The combat is fun as well. I look forward to playing the sequel.

I'll try to keep this absolutely spoiler free, I hate receiving even the slightest spoilers about gameplay, story, even about the length of the game, so I'm not doing it to you. I'll not spoil yakuza either.
Judgment, also known as Judge Eyes, and some other titles, is a spinoff to the yakuza series. If you haven't played the yakuza series, you really should, when I bought my first yakuza game years ago, I started basically non-stop playing more and more yakuza content for hundreds of hours until I ran out. This is that moment. I ran out. All of it was amazing, it reminded me of something that I almost forgot in the modern gaming industry: Games can be good, and full of passion and meaning, videogames can teach you something about life, and they can make you love people that don't even exist. The Judgment spinoff series does the same thing, but from a different perspective.
This game advertises itself as a detective game, just like the sequel "Lost Judgment" does. I played Lost Judgement first, for some reason. In Lost Judgment, I felt disappointed with how little thinking it really requires of the player, how many crutches it gives you and how it never, not even once, actually requires you to do any real investigating. Somehow, the first game does this far better. I really enjoyed immersing myself into it.
If you are interested in playing as a guy in a leather jacket who looks scary but has a good heart, and who is also a detective, you should buy this. You might just feel like I did when I started playing yakuza games, you might just get a new perspective on life, all while having a blast playing this game.
Once you're done, maybe you could give the Yakuza/Like a Dragon mainline series a go, too. 

Now, here's a small spoiler unless you've already played the sequel, something of a warning if you, like me, play this after already having played Lost Judgment:
The chase sequences are fucking garbage. Really, they are complete ass. Remember how in Lost Judgment you had these super cool, energetic chase sequences where you had to exhaust the guy you're chasing and then catch them? Well this game has chase sequences too, but it doesn't matter whether you fuck up and run into every single obstacle, or dodge them all. In this game, the guy running from you will slow down and even stop to wait for you if you fall behind, and if you're about to catch up to them, the guy you're chasing will simply speed up. They don't have a stamina bar, and you're not actually required to do anything. Almost every single chase sequence I had encountered during my 57 hours of playing, you didn't have to catch the target. Instead, the chase would just end once the guy you're chasing arrived at a certain position, the game would fade into a cutscene of you catching them. I saw the "catch" button prompt exactly once ingame and it didn't even work. Why the fuck??

I am dying of boredom here. I kept hearing everyone praising this game but it just feels like a chore every time I launch this game now. Of similar games from this studio I only played Yakuza Zero and Kiwami. The combat here does not feel nowhere near as good as it did on those games. 

Side quests are slow and predictable. Then when I thought I could just ignore the boring side content and focus on main story, the main story itself forces me to do side quests. "Oh X is not around, hey since you got time now do this side quest instead." It just breaks the flow of the story by forcing you to engage in a far less interesting side story.

But the worst crime this game does right at the beginning is spamming screen wide text box tutorials for such simple things like answering the phone or choosing the right key for a door. How stupid are their play testers that they think these simple button prompts need such tutorials?

Furthest I got in the main story is around chapter 4 or 5. Reading other negative reviews here they all say story is still great. So I guess I'll just watch a youtube story recap instead.

This game has a lot of content in form of story missions, side quests and mini games. It is streamlined for those aiming for completion with its KamuroGo app. The missions you do can be very goofy but I believe this entire series of which this is a spin-off to manages its tonal shifts superply well.

Some things I don't think are particularly strong include the key chain, tailing missions, looking around to find hot spots, lockpicking, putting on costumes (but only if the story needs it) and minor stuff like that. I totally get that they enhance the notion of you being a detective and that they help with the overall pacing, but I don't find them very engaging.

The iteration of Kamurocho in this game is densely packed with detail and life, but somehow this micro-cosmos feels a little small. If only there were more locations. There's no rooftop or underground passage. To be honest, there isn't all that much you can do to screw around. Having played Yakuza 4 before as my introduction to the series, I'm missing several activities. You do have the opportunity to go to the arcades and enjoy some Sega classics, play Darts, Mahjong (in three different places), Shogi, traditional asian gambling (but only two), Poker, Black Jack, Drone Racing (which is a big one), go to the batting center and into VR (which is a recontextualization of everything you do otherwise). That list may seem extensive, but it is only half the stuff you could do in other games. Most of these things get introduced over time, so you need to advance the story considerbly to gain access to everything. But it's not like you ever run out of things to do. 

Also, I would have prefered if you had more to spend your items on. Once you are done with your drone and its upgrades, you only have brewing extracts left, which isn't all that useful, because this game isn't very difficult and the game grants you some overpowered ones that aren't consumed upon usage. At no point are you able to craft weapons or even have any outside combat unless an opponent brought one. It's good that you have no inventory restrictions, so no back and forth to move objects. But you also have no equipment whatsoever to adjust your playstyle.

Some things I, personally, had some gripes with are the controls, for one thing. I swear, half of the time I performed an EX action was by accident, because it's the same button as the strong attack. I constantly bumbed into walls because the prompt to open a door didn't show up in time. Doing the thumb turn bypass with the controller is next to impossible, unless it's brand new. I had to disconnect my controller in VR everytime I had to open a safe, which made me avoid those spaces. Same goes for baseball and darts. You need to play all that with a mouse. I also hate the fact, that you cannot reload from within the game and have to return to the title screen and then reconfirm everything multiple times. But I guess then it would be easier to cheat, because you can save almost anywhere at any time.

I don't think any one part of this whole game is bad. It just isn't perfect is all. The combat is still very satisfying, because of all that brutal stuff you can pull off. The graphics are great. The characters are well defined and memorable. The plot is a little hard to follow, but you can always look stuff up should you need to. This is a mature game with an intricate story and some dark themes, but it also has a cornucopia of ways to dissolve the tension and get you lost and immersed in this colorful world.

I actually feel crappy recommending this one. In the RGG series, the story here is easily one of the best, top three even. Too bad the game that story is attached to is intensely irritating and only sporadically fun. The characters and plot make it worth slogging through, but it's tough recommending a 50+ hour game that pisses you off so regularly. 
The plot is easily the best part of this game, and it would be criminal to spoil any of it. Whereas the mainline series could be described as crime thrillers, Judgement is a hard-boiled detective mystery. The central murder mystery is well developed, the reveals expertly paced, and it's mostly free of the series' more wacky contrivances. Yagami is a fantastic main character, and he's surrounded by a supporting cast that play off him in ways that are almost always entertaining. The villains are equally great, and the game deftly achieves a rare balancing act of humanizing them without excusing their crimes. The game is very timely in its indictment of deluded glory seekers who betray their principles in the name of "the greater good". 
I wish I could leave it at that and give this one a solid recommend, but that would be ignoring all the ways this game disappointed and infuriated me. Lets start off with the game world: Kamurocho. That's it. That's all you get here. The same city I've explored top to bottom in over half a dozen games in the last fifteen years. If you were to ask me what has changed or been added since Kiwami 2, I couldn't tell you. Mainline games in this series usually add at least one additional location to at least give the appearance they aren't simply copy-pasting the same map over and over again, but Judgement dispenses with all pretense and does just that. It's a very nice city, and still one of the densest, most vibrant open worlds ever created, but it's not enough to carry an entire game anymore, especially when we've already seen every inch of it too many times before. It doesn't help that the amount of side content seems parred back as well. You can play Darts, a couple of arcade games, or participate in races with Yagami's drone. There is no karaoke, billiards, dancing, hostess clubs, or business management. Instead, Yagami takes on cases as a detective, which can involve two kinda neat lock picking minigames, a passable photo minigame, and easily the most godawful trailing missions I have ever experienced in a videogame. The trailing missions are easily the worst part of this game, and they unfortunately account for the majority of the detective work in side-cases. 
The core combat is interesting and kinda fun, but is completely undermined by bizarre and awful design decisions. Yagami has two fighting styles, tiger and crane, but you may as well go ahead and ignore crane, the developers pretty much did too. The overwhelming majority of upgrades and useful techniques only seem to apply to tiger stance, and by the halfway point crane just wasn't reliable or versatile enough to keep using. The fundamental move-set is cool, but the problem is Yagami's standard combo bounces right off of almost half the games enemies. In fact, enemies are extremely erratic in how they respond to your attacks. Sometimes they eat a full combo, other times they spin around 180 degrees in a fraction of a second to block your attacks, and yet other times still they will ice skate across the floor at warp speed to avoid a hit and circle around behind you. If you happen to commit to a combo and make it halfway through, the enemy can simply activate super armor, declare "mom says it's my turn to combo", and melt your health bar with a super-move Yagami isn't responsive enough to avoid. To be fair you are given a lot of tools to compensate for how unreliable basic brawling is in this game, but it doesn't do much to make the core experience more fun. It also doesn't help that the game rams combat down your throat with a chimney sweep brush due to the gang system. Are you enjoying hanging out in the world, completing side stories, playing arcade games, or doing literally anything else? Too bad, here's another text from Kim demanding you go beat up the same four gang leaders for the fifth time this chapter alone. You can ignore it, but you're gonna get jumped every 10 steps you take until you lower the "threat level". If I could have stuffed Kim in a dumpster and been done with these awful encounters for good, I would have done it without hesitation.
One thing I'm getting sick of more than everything else in this series is the bizarrely awful progression. Did anyone else play Like a Dragon Isshin this year? Remember the stupid chicken racing mini game, and how it was the only viable way to get the resources you needed to strengthen your character? This game does the same damn thing, only this time it's a VR board game. If the game is going to force me to fight random goon squads every five minutes, why do the majority of them reward me with 0 yen and barely any skill points when you win? Why do I have to grind a tedious mini-game for hours so I can afford the SP boosting items necessary to buy the ludicrously expensive core skill upgrades that make combat more bearable? And speaking of skill upgrades, why are so many essential abilities hidden in skill books that can only be found in arbitrary, nonsensical locations? Fail to investigate a particular mini game or side case completely? Hope you won't miss that essential ability that charges your heat gauge faster! I don't know why the developers balance things this way, but it's become a series trademark at this point, and I'm sad to say I'm finally getting fed up with it.
If you actually read all that, you're probably surprised I still recommend this game. Is the story that good? Yes, it is. But only just. Pick this one up on a sale or if you're new to the series. I was planning to play Yakuza 7 or Lost Judgement next, but I'm tapped out on this series for now. Maybe next year.

I haven't played any Yakuza game other than Like a Dragon - the only one dubbed in English, which due to my vision is a must for me. After experiencing this story, I know I'm missing out. Seriously a fantastic mystery involving organised crime, political intreague, conspiracies - multiple - and a genuine medical issue which is just as bad in game as in reality. There's good and bad, but there's also a ton of grey. Highly recommend for the story and characters, plus a really good dub for nearly the entire main story.


My only issues stem from just how much side content this game has - and that's very much a matter of opinion. over 100 sidequests - Friends, side cases and other activities mean you'll have a TON to do. I only completed a portion of the side content, which among Yakuza enthusiasts instantly makes this review a farce. It wasn't that the side stories weren't interesting. There were simply too many of them, and they often involved visiting a marker multiple times after enough time has passed, or slowly traversing the map - more on that later. They merely served as distractions from the fascinating main story. They also weren't voiced, which for me is always unfortunate. Still, if you like your serious stories with a heaping helping of bite sized narrative heavy distractions - as I usually do - you'll be happy.

My only other gripes are more nitpicky. There are taxis which you can use to fast travel, and more than enough drop off spots to make getting around a breeze. But there are only a handful of pickup spots which mean lots of walking. Granted it doesn't take a long time to get from one end of the map to another, but when you have to do it over and over like a blind bull in a busy street it really adds up. I caused more pretend property damage just wandering around than during all but the most hectic fights. Couple that with being able to collide with literally everything and it can make for an amuzing - though time consuming tour of the streets. A character even comments on it in a late portion of the game in a section which had me laughing out loud.

Finally, the tailing sections. I hope I never meet another one. I get their purpose - you're a detective after all - but it's so easy to get spotted, and just as easy to lose your mark when they turn down a side path or get lost in the crowd. If  they had kept the minimap at that point it would have really helped. Less immersive/realistic, but sometimes that's okay.

This was a hard call to make. 

This game has a few major flaws that nearly spoil the entire experience for me. Compared to the mainline Yakuza games, I'd say it has some catching up to do. 

1. The biggest flaw is the God-awful "wound" system. Whoever cooked this nightmare up needs to be demoted to janitor. I cannot even begin to imagine what possessed RGS to ship this abomination into the main game. All it does is make the game a huge pain in the ass and makes you waste hundreds of thousands of yen. Which leads me to my second point...
2. Getting yen is very inconsistent in this game, and it's way too stingy with recovery items. 
3. Heat generation is way, way too slow unless you chug alcohol or spam Tiger Flux. Most random encounters for me now are me just spaming Tiger Flux or using Tiger Drop.
4. Pacing that whiplashes from "holy shit I can barely keep up" to "I'm literally falling asleep at the wheel". There's large chunks of filler interspersed with amazing story and combat, which is just barely enough to keep you going.
5. A lot of the minigames are under-utilized or over-utilized. I am so fucking sick of the trailing minigame. Why did there even have to be a minigame for finding the right key to unlock a door? What purpose does it serve? There's no penalty for getting the wrong key, and you can get a skill for cheap that makes the correct key glow anyway. What's the fuckin' point?
6. The drone is barely used outside of drone racing. 

Despite all that... The game still has that Yakuza charm that keeps bringing me back. I'll finish this game like the others. Apparently Lost Judgement fixes a lot of these issues, so fingers crossed.

Reminds me to the first time I played Yakuza 0. Fair to say that RGG games always have its own charm. Guess I'll buy the sequel in the future.

Upsides
+Gameplay feels good. Initially battles felt clunky, but as you get more skills, they turn more interesting and fluid. Battles weren't necessarily as good as in Yakuzas, but still really good, especially when most of the random ones can be finished pretty quickly.
+Just like Yakuza games, the characters look really good and the city feels lively. Animation and directing on main story are good, while on side quests they are often simple and low effort, but somehow it's kinda charming how comedic it looks at times.
+Interesting story.
+Alot to do from side quests to mini games, even dating.
+Investigations are fun, looking for clues and presenting evidence.
+Cats everywhere.

Downers
-Theres alot of filler in the main story. It felt that whenever theres some big movement in the main story, you need to spend as much time on completelly unrelated things to advance the story. Often this is for character development, which might have been better as side quests, but there are also points where you need to wait to hear from other characters and the filler is just something to make you feel like you are actually waiting.
-Most of the tailing sequences are pretty boring. There are some that are more interesting later on, but mostly they are a pretty dull. Points where you are able to hide are pretty specific, so how you handle the tailing feels pretty scripted.
-Chase sequences. All of them, and theres quite alot. Chases are basicly just QTE and they tend to follow same patterns, have a group on the right, followed by group on the left, finish with fallen bike, on to next segment, rinse and repeat. I personally feel QTE is lazy game design, and this is nothing but that.
-Kim. He is merely the harbinger of pain, but every single text message makes me hate him more.
-Side cases are locked behind community level, and to raise that, you need to make friends. The cases open every 5 levels, so you will be spending alot of time doing friend events, of which most are talk, go away, come back, type things or fetch quests. There are some fun and interesting ones, but most are pretty mundane, and few are downright grind (Ebisu, Batting center, Extract guy, Mahjong. Thank god shogi wasn't on the list). Worst part is spending an hour getting the community level up to unlock a new side case, which might take just 5 minutes to complete. Getting all 50 friends isn't huge undertaking in the end, especially if you use guide for the grindy ones, but still it feels kinda unbalanced what you get for the effort.
-Mortal wound system and guns. They are kinda cheap shots to chip away your max health, they don't take much, but it's annoying regardless.
