RGG did not disappoint with Judgment.
While they are mostly known for the Yakuza series, you should highly consider playing it if you liked the Yakuzas. While there are similarities between the two IPs, such as Kamurocho or the presence of the Tojo clan, they are also very different, so you don't feel like you're playing another Yakuza.

The story was amazingly well-written, and got me hooked from the beginning to the very end. Rather easy to follow, while still being elaborate, but never far-fetched. It makes you truly feel like a detective trying to assemble puzzle pieces. All characters have a deep story that doesn't feel made up, making you appreciate how every single one of them is written.

The combat is very satisfying. It's smooth and diverse, with Yagami's two different battle styles. Sheer force has been traded for agility, which gives some spectacular street fighting. The heat actions are beautiful and there are plenty of them. Acquiring various skills will make it all the more satisfying.

The music is fantastic. It never feels repetitive, far from it. Everything got its own theme, and before you know, you get to listen to them even when not playing the game.

The game itself is very beautiful, and fluid, thanks to the FSR. Also, even if I played most of the game with JP voices, the English voices felt very "natural" and well done.

Outside the main story, we get to see more classic RGG content. The sides stories (friend events) are funny and silly, and the sides "missions" (side cases) involves different kinds of mechanics making them diverse. Minigames are cool as well, I really liked drone racing and dice&cube.

However, I did notice a couple of flaws, that altered the overall experience:
- The Keihin gang mechanic becomes more and more annoying in the long run. At some point, it feels like you just know they are going to spawn anytime soon. They also have some of the worst enemies in the game (in my opinion)
- The mortal wounds mechanic is interesting, but can be frustrating considering the punishment can be quite harsh if you just happen to be unprepared.

There are also some less noticeable things that, albeit not as infuriating/annoying as what I mentionned before, can still be a little disappointing. For instance, there were a little too many tailing missions while not so much for the other mechanics. While on the topic of tailing, I kind of wished that it could have offered a little more challenge.

Overall, it's an incredible game worth its price (although I bought in on sale), with a masterful main story and side content. On sale, it's a steal!

I love the Yakuza/Like a Dragon games, but this game disappointingly IS NOT Steam Deck-friendly enough to be falsely-advertised as "Verified". After getting to the point in the story where you unlock Essence Concoctions all Heat Actions have an extremely high chance of flat out crashing the game, and at worst making the Steam Deck restart itself. No amount of graphical settings seemed to make this problem less prominent. The Heat Action where you use it on an enemy on the ground to make Yagami kick them off the ground and into the air is the worst one which crashes 9/10 times, with the only times it doesn't seemingly have no logic to it. I use this Heat Action often in Judgement, so I can definitely say it was working fine up until that point where the game does a mini-tutorial on how Essences worked.

I know it's not anything to do with a corrupted saved game or anything on my end because I swapped over to my PC and ran it there and I spent an hour or so doing as many Heat Actions as possible and not a single one had any crashes or issues with the same save file and everything. Then I go back to it on Steam Deck and it goes back to crashing frequently on using Heat Actions, especially the basic kick one. So this makes Judgement on Steam Deck unplayable for me because even if I don't use any Heat Actions, boss battles that are required to fight in the story force you into scripted Heat Actions, and there's no guarantee if those will crash on me or not. That sucks a lot because I bought Judgement and its sequels specifically to play on my Steam Deck, and them having the Verified by Steam would mean they work.

Judgement might be an amazing game, but a massive Buyer Beware * on this game, especially if you are wanting to buy this specifically on a Steam Deck. Especially since this game-breaking bug was introduced to me 20 hours into the game which for other buyers translates to no easy refund. This game is by no means a safe "Steam Deck Verified" purchase, and if Valve happens to chance upon this review definitely change that at least until RGG patches stuff like this, because with stuff like this the game isn't even Playable status.

If RGG happens to fix this I'll happily change my review, but as of right now the game is unplayable to me on what I was advertised to it would work on.

For me, the Drone race was not interesting. It's not something I enjoyed. And so the OG SEGA arcade game or for me the arcade itself, which was a copy-paste of Yakuza felt lukewarm at best. Each game they produce have the 1 thing that helps you produce the much needs money. Casino is up there but in this game it's the VR Game which is essentially a game of cat and mice in with a parkour you ultimately wanna finish with as much rewards as possible which produces a ton of money. The investment app was a fun way to unlock unique abilities/side mission/ items. 

So overall those things makes it feels like a proper unique game from of my favourite studio. The same thing can be said to the structure of Friends and Side Cases which add unique side stories, good way to make money and add some helpers that helps you get aggro from the street gangs you fight. 

 The main story is basically related to the Fate of the Yagami. It's difficult to not give spoiler but it's a thriller drame with lot of amazing cutscene, good side characters that are rich in back stories and that you love to get to know. The vilains are never one dimensional and have complex layers of story to explain why they are acting like they are. They are never absolutely evil - at least for the most part. It does take a stand against corruption and how deep it sinks in Japanese culture. I thought this was very interesting 

I would recommend, I cleared it with much ease with some decent but not excessive grinding in just over 100 hours. I feel if you focus on unlocking the skills by chapter 6 it gets much easier to get bigger fights with higher Exp and the main story itself it nowhere close to be enough to unlock the skills within rushing the main story. I do feel it could add a much higher level of difficulty as you're much weaker. 

In the last chapter finale, I feel this studio has been mostly hit or miss with games I've played. E.I. a most boss have 2 phases where you'll clear the first 50% in zero effort. at first you're familiarising yourself with the combat engine, clearly a CC: of Yakuza, so you kind of get some cheeky tricks that breaks any level of difficulty- Increasing your Heat Gauge, Using a Special combo when your have something in your hand that activate a mini infight cutscene that inflicts massive damage.

So yeah, at the last fight, you get the boss fight pissed off, he goes hard on you, you run, pick up something and when close enough, juke him with zero effort, rinse and repeat and you clear the last fight with like almost getting untouched. 

One last thing I don't like from this game is that you need to grind a little if you're doing all the side quest, friend quest, drone races, gamba/shogi/other japanese traditional gamba to get some prices to unlock the good stuff ... you finish the game and you have the legendary difficulty and other new game adventure type you can play. I think it would be fun to have legendary difficulty unlock a lot more. You barely use healing during fight. It's so easy.

However, I learned that this game is more technical then all out brawl like Yakuza, which I found to be more enjoyable that the series. (plus you can upgrade combo speed thank god) On top of that the game boasts a juggle system, which is always welcome as an avid action game fan. Besides the story and great combat, Judgment gives the player an enormous amount of side content as RGG is known for. My first playthrough took me 74 hours to complete as I got distracted by the many minigames and side cases. In summary, Judgment is one of the best games this studio has made, and the mastery of their new dragon shines brightly in this entry. With this is mind I highly recommend This game as it is one of the best in the entire RGG line up.

Similar in the style to the other Yakuza/Like a Dragon games, Judgement instead follows disgraced-ex-lawyer-now-detective Yagami as he tries to unravel the cause behind serial killings in Kamurocho. Along the way, with the support of a large variety of characters and in typical RGG fashion, his sleuthing reveals that the reason behind the killings isn't as simple as originally thought.

The game is honestly a 10/10 in the body of an 8/10. The story is fantastic, characters are all equally as fantastic, and this is the best the city has looked so far. However, the game has several fundamental issues that drag the score down. Combat is a big mixed bag for me. When you first start the game, the combat is likely the second least enjoyable in the series just under Yakuza 3. It is significantly improved with upgrades to speed and EX moves, but that takes several hours to finally collect. OST wasn't as impactful as some from the prior games, but I did like a lot of the jazzy detective beats. 

The general story as a whole has some issues. Funny enough, it has the same issues Yakuza 3 had. The main story is very, very intriguing, but the devs have no scruples in completely veering you off course to force you to do some other side story out of the blue. Say, youâ€™re trying to get ready to hunt a certain character down, but the devs randomly force you to figure out who ate the cake in the fridge first. These side stories are very well written, but it definitely puts the brakes on the main storyâ€™s momentum. And that happens many times throughout the game. Just like in Yakuza 3 with the orphanage sections -  being forced to do them is more tedious than anything. And it doesn't help that the game heavily reuses the tailing and chase sequences for these as well as other side cases. On their own, these sequences are pretty enjoyable. However, by the end of the game, youâ€™ll likely end up doing them all together for dozens of times. By then, they became eye-rolling.

So, issues with combat, mission structure, and the pacing of the main plot sort of drag the overall experience down. Still, the game kicks a ton of ass.

The combat has plenty of kinks to iron out, but I generally loved this game. The completely new cast of characters in this Yakuza spinoff grew on me more than I imagined they would.

Don't let people tell you this game has good combat, because it doesn't. It feels like Yagami weighs about 400lbs and he's as responsive as a man who is heavily drunk.

God help me, I'm never buying another RGG game in my life. Every single time I go in with my expectations on the floor in terms of mechanics, and every time the game stomps them into the tiles to get them just a bit lower than I thought was possible. How is it that a studio that has been around this long has never made a beat-em-up system that's even half as good as something like the Batman or AC games? Those aren't even that good, they're just simple, but this is both SIMPLE and CLUNKY at the same time. 

If you want the combat to have weight and commitment, it needs to be consistent so the player can make good choices. If you want the combat to be skill-based, it needs to be responsive and feel good to use or else nobody is going to want to play it. These are simple ideas that nearly every game studio understands, but apparently not RGG.

Judgment's combat doesn't understand any of this. Yagami takes inputs more like suggestions half the time and his slow action speed paradoxically makes avoiding mashing very hard. Hitting the buttons too slowly will interrupt your combo, but hitting them too fast will end up queuing more attacks than you intended if you want to play technically, so the best option is just to mash and build your basic strategy around that. Worse still, Judgment eats inputs sometimes, killing the responsiveness. One of the first upgrades to cancel a combo with a dash barely functions at all because it only works at specific timings that are probably very tight based on what I experienced in my hour of play.

I get why Y0 was a bit clunky, the engine was old, but this is not an old engine. Yet, it's even worse than Y0, and I returned Y0 because the combat was bad. I dunno man, I want to like these games. On paper, they sound like games I would like. However in practice, every time I've played one of RGG's games my only takeaways have been shock at their mechanical incompetence and disappointment at the wasted potential.

As I said for Y0, for the story, there's always Youtube.

Please do not skip this game!

I'm starting my review to say please do not skip Judgment. For some reason there's an idea out there that people would rather skip this game and play Lost Judgment immediately. You can do that but you'll be missing out on this unique experience that LJ cannot offer.
I played this and LJ on PS4 just 1 month before it was added to Steam (SEGA please announce this next time so I don't have to buy the game twice, since obviously I'd prefer to buy on Steam) and now I've played through Judgment again on here as I wait for LJ to have a smaller price.

Judgment's strong points are it's story, the new character you play as (if we have played Yakuza previously) and the minigames.
The story is better than LJ in my opinion and one of the strongest in the Yakuza series. You'll feel great when playing it for the first time and I came out feeling more satisfied than the (in my opinion) over hyped Lost Judgment.
The new character Yagami is very unique and likeable. I'll admit I don't like his fighting styles compared to the Yakuza characters, but it's something new to learn and you can master them to an insane level.
The game is also VERY optimised being an amazing PC port of the PS5/XS|X version. The game looks and runs great.

This isn't a too long review or that in depth but this game needs to be experienced for yourself since it's far better than I've seen some people make it out to be.

Despite Ichiban's introduction after this game and multiple new playable characters in Yakuza 4 and 5, Yagami stands out as the most utilized character who seamlessly fits into the modern setting. Without the sequel baggage, the story can finally have the freedom to be unique and creative. It has a light Ace Attorney-style narrative that I enjoy. Unlike Yakuza 3, Judgment maintains the line between over-the-top storytelling and a sense of realism. The story is well-paced to keep you interested throughout.

Although the combat offers a lighter depth, it brings back the beloved style-switching mechanic from Yakuza 0. While enjoyable, it doesn't reach the level of being amazing. The mortal wound mechanic is a questionable addition. Its goal is to prevent players from constantly relying on healing items. In my experience, I still guzzle down food to heal. The wound can become frustrating since there is only one spot in town to treat it. 

The friendship mechanic returns and stands out as the best iteration I have ever experienced. It's a mix of easy tasks such as purchasing items to side-quest story content. While the overall number of side-quests may be fewer compared to other Yakuza games, they are well spread within the friendship mechanic and side-cases. On a related note, the girlfriend mechanic is arduous and morally questionable as you are dating 4 girlfriends simultaneously.

The new mini-games don't hit it for me. They end up taking a lot of your time, and the rewards they offer are pretty underwhelming. Even if the payoff is great, the mechanics themselves can be a chore. The number of new major mini-games included is disappointingly limited, with only two notable additions.

To conclude, Judgment is a fantastic game that handles its main story well but stumbles a bit in its side content. Conversely, its sequel stumbles with the pacing of the main story but manages to deliver remarkable side content. What sets it apart from the mainline Yakuza series is its laser focus on the main story, which makes it stand out.

Judgment: most misleading LAD game/spin-off in SEGA's series?

As a long-time player of the Yakuza (Like a Dragon) series, I went into Judgment with somewhat high expectations. Big mistake on my part because the majority of Judgment wasn't particularly above average to me. The game falls short in areas I really can't defend and will elaborate on. But its bad qualities don't overshadow the clear effort that was put into this game. Small details like the stellar graphics, detailed animations, and soundtrack, really emphasize the passion RGG Studio had in developing this project. However...

The game is overshadowed by extremely mediocre characters, gameplay, and pacing in my opinion. The characters, while appearing interesting at times and deeper than they appear, often fail to act on this impression. Reacting to events somewhat mechanically and with a lack of passion. 

Judgment, as beautifully detailed as it is, suffers from a similar curse that Yakuza 6 does. The gameplay isn't engaging and the new characters introduced aren't particularly interesting. During the first few chapters of the game I already wasn't finding Yagami (the main character) particularly engaging. I found very little substance to his character and his motivations. I feel like RGG wrote Yagami to be lawful but on the edge of criminal, like a bad boy or something. But Yagami lives by the law, making remarks about criminals having guns like he's seen a f*cking unicorn. YAGAMI THEY'RE CRIMINALS. 

Yet, his character is so defined by his search for the truth he literally becomes righteous to the point of absurdity. It's unrealistic for someone to have so little flaws to his character. Flaws make characters interesting- Yagami's one flaw is also his origin story and by the end of the game we realize said event that defines him wasn't even really his fault.  

I think a big part of the characters seeming uninteresting was due to the poor introduction and motivations presented at the start of the game. As much as fans rave about the writing of this title, the motives are boring and fail to garner emotional investment, the pacing is too slow and bogged down further by slow gameplay (looking at you tailing missions.) 

Speaking of which, realism is what this game does best in terms of its writing. The core premise is interesting (not going to spoil too much) and creative. But it's not really well done. The game's plot is poorly organized and I'm constantly asking "Okay, but why?" because as I said before characters don't seem to be logical at all. Ironically the realism is so dominating it actually makes the game harder for me to deal with, the tone in particular is extremely serious to the point of being dry to me. LAD games are meant to have a solid balance between drama and humor. Judgment is almost all drama.   

Judgment has a lot of potential but falls short of it often and if you aren't sold on the game within 3 hours I'd tell you to go for a refund because the first 3 hours establishes the game pretty well. In those three hours, you already understand the layout of Kamurocho.
Kamurocho in this game is small and there's not much to it. I preferred it in every other Yakuza title, cause it felt more lively and detailed. Even Yakuza 4 had underground malls, and rooftops. 

The side content is lacking, Mahjong, 6 or 7 arcade games, no karaoke, no golfing (if you're into that,) Dice and Cube (a virtual reality board game) is the big money making mini-game. and for me it was a f*cking grind. The game forces it on you because apparently the gambling halls don't have plates to pawn anymore.  Speaking of gambling, the game shoves Mahjong down your throat as well. Which wouldn't be so bad since Mahjong isn't too hard to learn, but the requirements for completing it are like three days long in ordeal. By the end my brain was like an egg on a pan. 

In summary; Kamurocho offers very little in terms of exploration and mini-games are subpar. 

One of the highlights of the game was drone racing, which I thought was actually pretty fun but even drone racing was tedious and stressful because of its race time requirements. I was ripping out my hair over race 5 in particular because even with high handling, the drones were very difficult to control through millennium tower openings. 

Bottom line; Judgment is for fans of Yakuza who don't mind a more serious and grounded simulation of Kamurocho, I don't advise first-timers to play it because the spirit of the game is dramatically different from the rest of the series and it doesn't balance serious with comedy very well. Plus, the gameplay is pretty immediate and there isn't as much variety. 

A lot of Yakuza fans will tell you it's one of the better games in the franchise, but I'd have to disagree. In my opinion Like a Dragon despite its turn-based combat, does a better job of emulating the spirit and tone of the original Yakuza games and the characters (especially Ichiban compared to Yagami) are much more interesting and endearing.   

7/10- Worth buying on a high sale. Content is lacking.

The reason for my story rating is that I came from Yakuza looking for a similar Yakuza story. What I got was an ex-attorney turned detective solving a murder case. Typical of cold cases. If you want more cold case files or murder stories, I'd go watch a real series on a cold case or murder mystery. Its way better than this game's story even with the slight plot-twists which is to be expected of solving murder cases. What I'm saying is you might enjoy the story if you haven't binged a bunch of Cold Case stories in your life. I was able to predict most of the story and in my honest opinion, the story doesn't get good until chapter 8 or 9 out of the 13 chapters. You'll find yourself doing more of the side quests aka "case files" than the actual story where the side stories are more fun and entertaining than half the game's main story line. So I guess that makes up for it.
As for the gameplay, I hated the "stalking" missions aka Pursuits. They were very boring! I felt the devs were very lazy with these missions and decided not to re-work them. If they ever update this game (which I doubt nowadays) but a mechanic needs to be added to add some fun and variety to these missions to either distract the suspect or speed up the pursuit. I felt like I was wasting my time with these missions. Personally, I'm not a fan of stealth unless they add certain mechanics to make it fun instead of playing simple stalk-hide-seek. 

The graphics are super clean and the game is very well optimized. I ran this game at 1440p at 120fps max settings with Nvidia DLSS at Quality with a 3090 and Ryzen 5800x3D all while recording with no hiccups. 
Its a beautiful game but the color tone can throw some people off as most of it is cool. There are some minor lighting issues. ex. Too bright in some areas.

I am a 52 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing Judgement. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son found this game at Christmas, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Great game. Story's great, characters are great, jokes mostly hit, sucks you into the experience pretty well most of the time. You routinely find yourself ironically and unironically thinking: "Man, everyone's just so cool."

Even though I highly recommend it, I want to complain at least a little bit. I think this about all RGG Studio games but at first it's easy to do the combat and do the chore-like missions because it's a new story, new characters, relatively new setting, etc. More forgivable. After about hour 15, it's nothing but a nuisance in my opinion. Want to progress the extremely engaging plot? Here, beat the crap out of 50 enemies down a series of long hallways. Oh hey, it's gonna take some time for this event to happen, how about you get derailed on some pointless side story about one of the main characters where in the end nothing changes at all, and it's so irrelevant that nobody even bothered recording any voice lines for it? As the game progresses, the enemies get more health and more super-armor to where they don't stagger as much with your attacks so you have to go out of your way to use the ex-boost mechanic a lot. "Okay so just turn the difficulty down to the lowest setting." You do that and you pretty much don't even fight the battle yourself. It decides so many things for you during the battle just by you simply moving around and pressing nothing else. you move towards an enemy you suddenly grab them. You move the joystick at all you randomly start full-on sprinting. You press the regular attack button, your guy spends ex-boost to do a special move when on other difficulties that's a different button. So I turned it to easy because ironically on the lowest difficulty if your guy is just sprinting around the whole fight you do less damage per second and fights take longer. I still had a heck of a time though, and there are mechanics in the combat system that reward an unreasonable amount of patience. Got my ass kicked a number of times because I didn't want a fight to last 10 minutes. In the end, you can always just button-mash and use heal items and still win, but it looks ugly and it's not very fun. Not to mention they have a "lethal injury" mechanic that permanently decreases max health with certain attacks until you go get it healed for an exorbitant amount of in-game money. To me that's just yet another chore to do in the end. I often caught myself thinking "Why are they trying to fabricate game-play hours like this? It's a great game even if it's beaten in like 10 hours, why do they have to force it to be 30 hours with 20 hours of bull***t?" Again, pretty much all RGG Studio games feel like this, but it seems like it can't decide if it's an open-world game or a strictly linear game so RGG Studio just makes some Frankenstein amalgamation of both. 

Despite all that, it's still a great game and I'm glad I played it. Just have patience.

Great game on controller, I imagine. However, If you want to play this game on PC, I guarantee that you will have a more pleasant experience shoving your keyboard up your asshole horizontally, whether you're into that or not. 

If you're wondering what's so physically painful about this game, it's mostly the lockpicking mechanic. You're supposed to use either the left stick or right stick to slowly raise the lockpick thing to push the pins to the shear line. If you're on mouse, there are set parameters to where the lockpick thing can go. These parameters do not always include the shear line, so if you can't get it first try (assuming the insanely high sensitivity doesn't make it impossible for you to get it at all, my normal DPI is 1600 and I have to move my mouse about a tenth of an inch before it goes too far, and at 200 DPI I sometimes still accidentally overshoot at mach speed) as far as I'm aware, you're just kind of fucked, and eventually if you keep retrying it you should get it after half an hour or so. 

Aside from the lockpicking, which is equally impossible, and significantly more frequent, there's another weird, shitty minigame for unlocking doors where you use your left stick and right stick to do some bullshit, I don't really know, and I don't think the developers know either. The fun part is, even if you're on PC, you still have to use your left stick and right stick. In other words, you have to use your mouse to simulate the left stick and right stick, making what's normally a fairly difficult minigame genuinely the worst experience I have had in the entire Yakuza series so far (0-6), and yes, I did finish Yakuza 3. 

If you do not have a controller, do not get the game. If you already have the game, and don't have a controller, refund it. If you can't refund it, go fuck yourself.

I wanted to come back and update my review after beating the game. I don't know if anyone will see it but I just wanted the opportunity to share how much I enjoyed this game. Yakuza has once again made a compelling, thoughtful, and emotionally gripping story. It is also the first Yakuza game I've played with English Dubs and the voice acting is impeccable and it does not detract from the experience at all. This might be the best story that Ryu Ga Gotoku has published thus far, or at least of the games I've played.  

All of that said there are still some aspects where the game is rough around the edges. Particularly some of the mandatory "detective" minigames can be tedious at times. Particularly the tailing missions, where are occasionally peppered throughout the main story and side quests can be extremely tedious. It feels like these concepts were thrown in without much polish. By the end of the game I was wishing I could just press a button to skip. That said, I powered through them and they weren't frequent enough to make me stop playing. 

The fighting styles are also a little limited, you only have two styles. Crane for crowds and tiger for single enemies and bosses. I could see combat getting stale for some people. I found myself rarely using crane style outside of very niche situations as it is just not that enjoyable and it doesn't have much variety or flexibility, but the extracts and leveling really helped with Tiger Style. There are a number of unlocks that can really change the way you tackle combat and keep things fresh and diverse. Crane  just doesn't seem to evolve that much after you unlock it. 

Another warning, the start of the game is an extremely slow burn. I feel that the pacing both with story beats and the unlocks are excellent starting somewhere around the third chapter. The first chapter was a little bit of a slog to get through. Ultimately it was totally worth it and I would replay this chapter because I imagine that there are many instances of foreshadowing that I missed. 

On a neutral note, I think on the zany scale this is significantly less zany than other Yakuza games. However, side quests were still regularly goofy and engaging. Like all Yakuza games it is filled to the brim with unlocks. I particularly enjoyed drone racing and I may go back to complete that specifically at some point in the future. 

Overall, I still highly recommend. This doesn't break significantly from the formula of the other Yakuza games. In fact, where it breaks from the formula, outside of story telling, might be its weakest points. That said, the story is phenomenal and the new cast of characters is a fresh and welcome take to the experience. 10/10 would recommend.

"A bit" late review for a long awaited game.

The story is insanely good. I like it much more than Lost Judgment story, which is good, but in different way. This plot feels very personal for protagonist, because of number of reasons. Gotta play to figure that out. The script contains unexpected twists and will surprise you quite often. Story battle encounters are so fckn' intense I just can't describe my excitement with words. Epic ride.

Characters are very likeable, voice cast did incredible job. I can't even tell who was my favorite but since we already figured out that Mafuyu is the best girl, couple words about her. At the end of the game I understood that her playful and kind personality won me over. Just hoped more or her in next game, BUT do not make my mistake. She had 3-5 minutes of screen time in LJ. It's depressing sht, so cherish your gal, til you can. Saori is cold, but funny. Resolute and smart.

Yagami-san didn't disappoint. Bright mind, fast legs and fists. Good sense of humor. Can go on and on, but let's say he won't disappoint anyone. Good written character.

Worry not, there's still a good portion of goofyness in Sub Stories. There's also a new (?) Friends system, which I personally liked. While befriending people around town you will gain a certain goodies, such as materials, money, heat restoration if you meet them in town and even sidekicks on a streets of Kamurocho. Etc.

A lot of minigames are back from old [strike]Yakuza[/strike], sorry, Like a Dragon games. Karaoke is not on the list unfortunately. I guess Johnny & Associates asked for some cosmic amounts of money for Takuya Kimura singing.
Back to it. There's two new minigames I'd like to mention. These are Drone Racing and VR Paradise. Races are pretty chill and fun until you're going for last championship with that golden drone broken AI. I still loved it, water under the bridge. There's customization for performance and bit for visual appearance. Devs also scaterred a lot of QR codes in city for you to discover and scan with your drone in order to get upgrade schematics.
VR paradise is Suits and Ladders analogue. Throw dice, move. Fight, get prizes or lose everything earned this match. Also, cool cyber cats.

Combat. There are only 2 styles, but it's already more than Kiwami 2 and Y6 gave us. It's better, more flashy and still can't carry any weapons. Ngl, I had my fun, no complaints, although it gets much much better in the next game.

Visually game looks great, except characters' hair. In next game DLSS, FSR and XESS make hair look like pixelated spaghetti and I guess I wanted to play so badly that didn't put any attention in this title.

Things I didn't like:
- Mortal wounds. New system which reduce your maximum health if you was shot by a gun, steel arms (? don't remember) or received a damage from Boss' special attack, when they in heat mode. You need to see a Doc to cure it and can buy medpacks from him, but they may cost ya at the start of the game. You get several as DLC (included in game). Most bs part is swarming street encounters, when you didn't notice like the guy in the back pulled out the gun couple seconds after the battle started. Well, that will be 20k. System is removed in next game.
- Thumb turn bypass. Broken piece of shit. Very bad with controller, a bit easier with mouse and minimum sensitivity in options + lowest DPI. The fact this thing is present in VR Paradise as a reward tile is "mildly infuriating".
- Money. You can't unlock all skills without grinding VR or other source of income. It's not critical, there's no hardcore encounters (almost), but still unpleasant. If you're going for platinum, that's what will take most of your time. Investing tons of cash into a stupid scyscraper, which does nothing.
- Tailing. Every single one of them except two were basically the same. Long and boring.

TL;DR: buy.

Easily my favorite game that I've played from Ryu Ga Gotoku so far. Having played the Yakuza games from 0 to 5 Remastered, it's clear that RGG really wanted to push the mold with this game and they executed it really well. The story is the best I've seen from the franchise so far, with each chapter feeling like an episode in a season-long detective/mystery series. With some of the Yakuza games, the plot was either too predictable at times or relied on sudden plot twists that seemed to only exist for the sake of progressing the story without any prior set up; Judgement in my opinion doesn't have this flaw and has a coherent story the whole way through. Also, the humor in this game is legitimately some of RGG's best work yet, as there were a lot of times I burst out laughing at what was on screen, both in the main story and the side cases. 

The Dragon Engine they use for the game makes everything look stunning at maxed settings, and I found the combat really enjoyable all the way through. Side note: RGG usually has a heavy fight-choreo segments during boss battles, but they tend to put quick time events in said segments which prevented me from actually enjoying the moves the characters were making; from what I remember every fight-choreo segment for the bosses only had a single button input at the end of them so it feels like you're watching an action movie. Also the Yakuza bosses typically feel like shield/combo maniacs, ie impossible to hit unless you cheese them (tiger drop), but I never felt that being a huge issue in this game. 

Where I think the game really shines is the world-building, as there are so many side cases and friends to meet with many of them actually having great stories to tell/experience. RGG has always had a plethora of interesting substories in the Yakuza games, and the side cases are for the most part very engaging and worth going through. 

Overall enjoyed every minute till the end, and making this the first RGG game that I plan on 100% completing.

(Edit): Recently found out that in chapter 5 [spoiler] when you're in the past and have to investigate the Waku crime scene, the controller doesn't rumble on points of interest unlike in present day since Yagami was basically a newbie at detective work compared to how he is a full-time detective in the present [/spoiler] Just some neat subtle characterization that I really appreciated.

IT'S FINALLY ON STEAM! Judgment is a proper successor to the original Yakuza games (considering that Yakuza: Like A Dragon turned the series into a JRPG series, which I don't hate, far from it, but it's not a genre I'm into). Coming off Yakuza 6 (and Kiwami 2), Judgment feels like a proper upgrade from the series it originated. Gameplay wise, while it does still have some jank to it, the new combat mechanics such as juggling are a fantastic addition, pulling off long juggles on enemies is some of the most fun things you can do here. Soundtrack and the side content are also some of RGGS' best, I like the "quality > quantity" approach here much more than what the PS3 era Yakuza games did, which had TONS of filler and boring content in which felt INSANELY tedious to complete. However, Judgment's best aspect is it's fantastic story. I won't go into detail here because of spoilers, but I can say that thing might be the best story this studio ever wrote (and they wrote some amazing stuff before this). Overall, a fantastic game and one of my personal favorites of the past few years, definitely go check it out. If you've never played a Judgment or a Yakuza game in general, you are can play this without going through the Yakuza series, as the Yakuza stories are not connected to the Judgment games.

Well, it's a game from Yakuza series, so if you liked it[series] so far, this is a must have.
It took me exactly 40 hours to beat it(at around 65% completion), but due to afking, and trying out things with loading and saving, Steam shows up 60.
The story perhaps is the darkest among the whole series, and it's really good. It might be very slow for some, but on chapter 9(out of 13) it really speeds up, and truly engages you. I always fear new main characters in Yakuza but Yagami really grew on me. I felt he was much bolder than Kiryu, especially if we think of Kiryu's Y5-6 versions. Other characters are very well made too.
The combat is awesome. We have 2 combat styles, one for larger groups, and the other rather focusing on one opponent.
I feel like thanks to this game, Dragon Engine was really polished. It's not Y6 where you had a downgrade in literally every aspect of fighting. The ragdoll still acts funny at times, but it's not as bad as in Y6 where it took ages to get up after a ridiculous ragdoll. 
Side content is still top notch, even if we're missing crucial elements like karaoke and some other activities. There's still a large number of things to do. I think Friendships system really works well in encouraging you to do side missions, etc.
Graphics and audio is also great, but that's a series standard. Dragon Engine still looks pretty, cutscenes are awesome. Some of the QTEs in fights are already amongst my faves in entire series(final boss QTE is fantastic) 
Soundtrack in my opinion goes back to the roots, with guitar themes, also sometimes barely audible lyrics. Took me back to the OG Y1-Y2 and Y3 music.
But, the game has it's issues like every game. The tailing missions are horrible. They are way too long, they always come down to slowly walking around your target, the music constantly changes from calm one to dramatic, because target turned and is behind a column, also they're no challenge at all.

I picked this one up for the Ps4 sometime before they announced the steam port and I'm glad I waited.  Being a fan of the Yakuza series, I wasn't sure how I'd appreciate a story without the memorable cast of characters I've grown to love over the course of 7 mainline games.  Easy to say the fresh face of Yagami is a welcome addition to the quaint city of Kamurocho.  I'll never get over just how much content is packed into each title in addition to the wonderful stories guiding the pace of the action.  The main story is a prime candidate for one of the best set in the Yakuza universe.  

If you haven't played any entry prior to Judgment, rest assured this game assumes you haven't.  You can honestly only play this game and have a full understanding of events.  This title is self-contained.

If the volume of the Yakuza series seems daunting, but you've wanted to experience where the love comes from, you can start here and see if it's up your alley.  I doubt you'll be disappointed!

On 50% sale or more, I would recommend picking this up. On PC - particularly early on - there's a number of technical issues. First and foremost there was a lot of sound glitching within the game, audio cutting out, or faraway voices being a super high volume. For some reason these audio issues stopped occuring a few chapters in with no change/update to the game or my PC? I can only conclude that there's some state that is fixed/checked in later stages

The same issue applies with sprinting, I'll hold or toggle sprint and sometimes I'll sprint flawlessly... other times I'll run a few steps, slow down, and then start running again. Sometimes getting into combat will fix this, but most times you'll have to rely on a major cutscene. But, again, after a few chapters this behavior stopped occuring so there's really something not quite right in the early game

Additionally, if you're playing this on a Switch Pro controller forget about trying to use the Nintendo button layout; this thing runs on Xbox controls and that's the end of it -- I changed controls multiple times to see if I get it to be the Nintendo format and in spite of the game saying changes we're saved, they just never were. This gets frustrating when you're placed in a scene with quicktime events... and even more annoying when you play other games then let you use the Nintendo layout

Issues aside, on sale I think it's a decent buy. It's not quite as good as the Yakuza games in my opinion and the story isn't as outlandish or engaging as those games either. Also, many of the missions/side missions require you to do '''investigation''' type tasks suchs as scanning a room for a specific object in first person, or tailing someone. These missions are extremely painful and every single time I rushed through them as quickly as I could. They're absolutely not engaging whatsoever, if there was an autocomplete option I would have immediately selected that instead

Overall if you've played the Yakuza games.... Kamurocho is getting a little boring, but the overall story is just interesting enough to pull you through

This was, technically, my first introduction to the Yakuza series (If you can count this game as one, which personally i do), and honestly, wow. When i was first jumping into this, i was expecting something like, L.A Noire, but with fist fighting, which i was mostly correct minus the fact that the detectiveness part wasnt exactly polished (Though spotting cats was a neat treat). Though despite that, there are couple of flaws within this game, like any other game has really.

Pros:
- The story is amazing. Despite the fact that sometimes the story does side track, one reason or another, the main story is just amazing.
- The fighting. At first, the fighting feels... Eh, but once you start unlocking some fun stuff, by fun stuff i mean new battle EXs and such, then it becomes really neat, specially when some skills are nearly "must have" (In quotation marks), like double quickstep, Tiger Drop (Not needed but badass if you pull it off), and some other stuff like the Flux.
- The graphics are really neat too. I, during the entire playthrough, never noticed i was playing with low Graphs (Prolly because i am just used to running a lesser end PCs in my life), but even with the said low Graphs, its really pretty. Though again, i am not much of a Graphics person. (Aka Gameplay over Graphics type of a person)
- Side Cases & Majority of Friend Events, on the gameplay side, these two are also neat and are mostly your main source of money and SP, and trust me, you will need a decent amount of money, specially for 100%
- OST, just simply look it up on Youtube, nuff said.

Cons:
- 100%, as much as i would LOVE to 100% the game, there are few things that are holding me back and that specific things are 1 Friendship where you need to play a game of Mahjong with special rules, Poker objectives and Shogi. Its less of a game issue and more of a skill issue, problem is, even if i knew how to play any of those, i am mostly relying on luck, as (For Poker for example) you need to win a number of chips, which absolutely relies on luck as opponents may waste their chips or play it very safe.
- Mortal Wounds mechanic, its not exactly a con, its a good feature, whats not good feature is Firearms. It doesnt help that EVENTUALLY, normal enemies have guns too, and they hurt. Doesnt help that Yagami takes his time to get up (Though understandable lol).
- Threat Level, god forbid whoever thought this was exactly a good idea. On paper, it sounds fine, but in practice, its annoying. To explain Threat level, after beating up a good amount of enemies or waiting some time, the Threat level will be at 100%, in order to lower it, you have either defeat the Keihin leaders (There are 4 of them, each of them having their own abilities). While Threat it up, alongside the leaders, Keihin enemies will become A LOT more common... And i mean, A LOT. To the point of annoyance. Again on paper, this sounds fine, the problem is, this feature appears on Chapter 4, and on top of that, the 100% Threat are very random and can happen pretty much any time, and boy oh boy, that any time is A LOT of time. (Also fuck Koga, bro has 2 guns at 50% HP. >:( )

- Tailing Missions. I dont want to put this to either a con or pro so i will just put it here as a Neutral. The Tailing missions are pretty fun at first, but holy shit, does the game overuse them. And majority of the times, they feel the same. The couple of times that it felt different is tailing more paranoid or aware characters, which trust me, its less than you think. 

Overall: 9/10
Remember, this is all my personal opinion, some people may not share the same issues (Like my problem with Mahjong and Poker). But even so, i personally recommend getting the game. Is it worth 40$? Can be arguable, but if you are like me (A person that like to scrape by with sales), then wait out for Sale.
Note: Despite it being a "2022" game, it actually came out 2021 (Remaster, not the OG that would be 2018), therefor threat this game as a 2021 game when it comes to sales.
RGG is just one studio who hears and pleases their audience. I have been waiting for two years and I'm glad to finally be able to play it on PC.

Very much a "if Steam had a neutral option..." review.

Its good, undeniably. BUT.

It's soulless compared to the mainline Yakuza games. The city is bland, there are no real unique or interesting minigames (the drone shit is a bit like Dragon Kart from 7 but more enjoyable; still boring and grindy, the [i]of the dead[/i] game is alright, and the VR is... I dunno). Its clear the devs are trying something new, and the "darker" tone of the main story is honestly quite well executed, though it makes the silly RGG moments very camp and unintentionally funny.

The characters are... weak, bad in the diametrically opposite reason as to Y7:
They are so god damn boring. And there are SO many of them. Compare this games cast to that of Y0/Y3 and its meme tier, I couldn't put a name to the face of most of them, with the exception of Kaito, who feels like a hybrid of Rikyu and Kiryu, and not in a good way- or, not as good as he could have been.

The story is... contrived. Its clear the devs had a solid idea for the final scene, how it was executed, and the drama, but the plot was obviously built from the end backwards, and it shows. Random, near-pointless plot elements, redundant characters, massive coincidences, strange morals that have you almost wanting the "bad guys" to win, and even a dramatic reveal in the last quarter that falls flat on its face. I did appreciate one element of the ending though (spoilers without names) [spoiler] The game sets up clear "jump infront of the bullet" bait, but instead, a character whacks the dude with a thrown armchair, who proceeds to try again, only to get lit up and shot to death LMAO [/spoiler]. But yeah, for the most part, the story lacked any stakes, and not in a good way. Yakuza 3 was chill, but the story was absolutely banging. This game? Well, its nice and chill so you can do the sidequests at any point without feeling goofy (ahem Yakuza 0), but the actual plot is hollow and predictable.

I have high hopes for the sequel, I've heard people say its on a par with 0 but I'll believe it when I play it. Hopefully. Overall, this is a pretty solid game as proof of concept for a new IP, its just a shame its set in Kamurocho and lacking in the main plot department. Substories are pretty solid- if a bit bland for the most part.

The game also took me ages to beat, like, half-a-year type length- which is the longest out of any RGG game I've played so far, but I can't attribute that entirely to the game, as I was busy IRL too. Its undeniable I didn't particurlarly feel like launching the game most days, which says a lot.

10 hours in, the story has started picking up and is going good so far. The gameplay and combat is fine as well.

(full review with screenshots: https://www.gaming-parrot.com/2023/01/judgment-review-i-fought-lawyer.html )

Â Judgment is the beginning of the Yakuza series' move away from that name and its focus on, well, the yakuza. You play as a private detective/lawyer who is not and has never been an actual yakuza member, but who still has close ties with one particular family. The story and gameplay similarly sit somewhere between being about and not about the yakuza - they play a major role in the plot and much of the gameplay revolves around beating them up, but at the same time you can play for hours just doing detective tasks and dealing with civilians.Â 

The two main shakeups to the gameplay are the addition of various detective-y activities and a bunch of new minigames. The detective stuff consists of activities like tailing suspects, looking for clues in the environment, and dialogue-based interrogations. None of this stuff is ever very hard, and it honestly probably wouldn't have been interesting at all if not for the series' trademark bonkers writing constantly intervening to surprise you. The minigames, meanwhile, are a very eclectic bunch. Drone racing and a VR Mario Party-esque games are the main ones, and the latter is meant to be your main source of income since there's no business minigame. I found both of these a bit tedious because of slow movement in VR and excessive grinding for crafting resources with drones, but they're fun for a bit. Most of my time with minigames was with the batting cages, darts, and Outrun! cabinet.Â 

Outside of those changes, you'd be hard pressed to notice that this wasn't another normal Yakuza game just from watching gameplay. Most of your time will be spent on crazy sidequests that almost always end in combat or in street encounters against the bizarrely combative denizens of Kamurocho. The sidequests are nearly all fun, but several of them are frustratingly locked behind completing grindy NPC quests that require finding random resources or grinding casino chips to buy paintings. Combat is similarly fun when its new, but random events that spawn Keihin Gang leaders all over the map happen maddeningly frequently in the later stages of the game. Beating up those leaders is fun the first few times, but it's a lot less entertaining when you're fighting the same guy for the 30th time.Â 

It'd get a lot easier to differentiate the games if a cutscene starts playing, though. Most of the major characters in Judgment are either lawyers at the Genda Law Office or prosecutors working opposite you on a case, and typically your immediate concern is collecting evidence to exonerate your client on a case. The result is something that's half Phoenix Wright and half Yakuza. It's definitely not realistic, but it is thoroughly entertaining.Â

Definitely a must-play if you enjoy the Yakuza franchise. Although it deviates slightly from the normal Yakuza formula, the changes and unique gameplay make it worth your time.

The main strong point of Judgment is definitely the story. Although technically a spin-off from the Yakuza games, it still manages to have one of the most immersive, enjoyable, and strongest story in the whole franchise. I was entirely immersed and invested from the introduction all the way to the credits. The story was so enjoyable to experience that I neglected parts of the game like the drone racing mini-game just to progress through and see what happens next. While Judgment doesn't feature the beloved characters of the main games, it adds a whole new cast of memorable and in-depth characters which really make the story come to life and adds a new fresh feel to the game. 

Combat is also very enjoyable and has a different feel and pace to the main Yakuza games. Yagami has two fighting styles that can be used in combat, both being very unique and different to Kiryu's fighting style. Rather than a strong and grounded playstyle, Yagami favours speed and agility similarly to Majima. Very fun to use Yagami's moveset while jumping on enemies and walls.

Visuals are also stunning and really top off the experience. The dragon engine allows the game to look realistic and have beautiful lighting and graphics while not being that intensive. Really breathes life into Kamurocho. However, physics can be questionable at times.

Iâ€™ve played everything that has been released in the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series from RGG Studio and enjoyed each one of them.  There were amazing games like Yakuza 0, weaker games like Yakuza 3, and different games like Yakuza: Like A Dragon (the most confusingly named one). 

Judgment isnâ€™t technically part of that franchise, but it is from RGG Studio and is counted as a â€œYakuza gameâ€ by most fans.  Itâ€™s the same universe, same city, and has similar interactions with the same Tojo Clan, even if only a side story character crosses over between the two games.   The engine the games run on and the style of the games is very similar.  

In Judgment, you control Yagami, a former lawyer who is now a private investigator.  A simple early case, which involves you trying to assist in the defense of a Tojo Yakuza Captain named Hamura, pulls Yagami into a series of events at the core of the story.  Judgmentâ€™s main focus is telling a complex and intricate narrative that evolves throughout the story, though since unraveling is such a central part of the game, Iâ€™ll avoid mentioning much more about it. 

What I can say though is while the story in Judgment is interesting and unique,  with satisfying moments, it doesnâ€™t feel as tight as previous Yakuza games and ultimately feels bloated.  Itâ€™s a fifteen-hour story told over twenty hours or more.  Whatâ€™s worse is that the same is often true for the side cases.  Interesting and unique stories, like all side stories in these games, but told slowly. 

A lot of the game feels bogged down by dialogue or a need to remind people of the narrative, itâ€™s unfortunate because it gets in the way of its own momentum, and rather than giving high-action moments, it draws out scenes or shows entirely too much detail when brevity could be better. 

Thatâ€™s not to say it harms the story, but it does feel long-winded, and perhaps thatâ€™s also due to how Judgment is intended to be a detective story and so the game is mostly talking.  There are major moments to the story, but in the Yakuza series most chapters end with a major boss battle, in Judgment, thereâ€™s no major reason for the chapter changes, only a few chapters have a big boss battle.  Itâ€™s understandable as the enemies arenâ€™t major Yakuza, but the pace makes the experience feel like more of a slog than it should be. 

The gameplay of Judgment works though.  With Yagami being a detective there are a few new mechanics at play.  Hunting through locations for clues in a first-person view is an interesting and unique idea that if anything is underutilized, as theyâ€™re some of the best moments of detective work.  On the other hand, the tailing missions where Yagami tails suspects are almost never fun, but thatâ€™s to be expected.  The good thing is those donâ€™t happen too often, but they probably arenâ€™t going to excite many people. 

The combat of Judgment is similar to the rest of the series as well, though with Yagami fighting with more of a Shaolin style with two different forms, one for large groups, and one for single enemies, but with enough upgrades itâ€™s easy to use the latter for every battle.  The early hours make Yagami feel rather slow and weak, but a few skill point upgrades and Yagami will be able to take on almost every enemy without a challenge. 

There is one change to the combat that definitely stands out.  Yagami can take â€œMortal Woundsâ€, which means the parts of his health bar are taken off.  This only happens when heâ€™s shot or takes major damage from one of the â€œbossâ€ characters.  This damage canâ€™t be healed by eating and instead requires Yagami to get healed by a doctor or use a med kit.  The issue is there is just one location to heal up that I found, and the medkits, and fixing these wounds are decently expensive.  But as a mechanic, it just means players will have to go find the doctor, and once the money stops being a major issue in the game, it is simply a time-wasting chore, rather than an interesting gameplay mechanic.  

Take that damage when youâ€™re in one of the few battles where players canâ€™t just free roam, and suddenly it changes a major story moment to a painful experience where players will have to struggle with a tiny life bar.   

Of course, the Mortal Wounds can be mitigated with a few features, but rather than getting deep into it, itâ€™s the most important part of the combat system, but also the one that never feels as good as the rest, and one that luckily was removed before the sequel, and hopefully will not return. 

Thereâ€™s more to be said, with a lot of it being potentially spoilers, but at the end of the day, itâ€™s a game where players should discover the story, side quests, missions, and experiences, and rest for themselves.  

One other issue comes up in that there are a few DLC parts to Judgment.  Iâ€™m not sure if everyone gets those or if they were only for the initial launch, but these DLC bonuses range from pointless (An extra Staminan X?) to overpowered (an essence that lets you instantly kill almost every enemy or cause massive damage for bosses).  

Iâ€™m not sure why DLC exist in Judgment, but itâ€™s a shame because they unbalance the game and are no longer optional additions, theyâ€™ll sit in your mailbox outside your apartment but different parts of the game will leave bonuses in that mailbox so youâ€™ll likely add them to your inventory at some point. 

The DLC isnâ€™t a massive negative but definitely one that stands out and itâ€™s something that RGG tends to do for all their games (DLC that unbalances the game). I just wish they had a way to lock it away for an authentic play-through because otherwise, it clutters up your inventory. 

Ultimately Judgment is another Yakuza game, with a different protagonist.  It has all the various Yakuza trapping with large side stories and interesting dialogue.  The story is solid but is told poorly at times, and the experience is long but still one I enjoyed.  After thirty-five hours I have to confess, they must have done something right, even if I was bored during a few chapters. 

Judgment is a slow burn but still one worth playing.  Though with that being said I donâ€™t know if I would ever return to Judgment for a second playthrough due to the length of the story. 

Still, if youâ€™re a fan of the work of the RGG Studio, Iâ€™d recommend checking this out at least for completion's sake and to learn more about the world of the Yakuza. 

8/10

Judgment finally on PC and it's a pretty great port, among the best of Yakuza games ports on PC, everything runs very well on 1080p@60fps without FSR with specs that are a little bit below Recommended.
Way better and way more smoother experience than the PS4 version, which had the infamous 5fps Amon battle aka "Essense of Framedrop".
This game has the best Dragon Engine rendition of Kamurocho up-to-date with more added shortcuts and big amount of enterable areas, some of which, sadly, were cut in Lost Judgment for unknown reason.

Story is great too, I'd say it's even better than in the sequel. Soundtrack is very good but Lost Judgment's soundtrack was more memorable for me.

This game also is not so stuffed with side content as it's sequel, it feels more "compact" as a game overall, and as a result doesn't have that feeling of "content oversaturation" I had when I was playing Lost Judgment or Yakuza 5.

Levelling is also amazingly done compared to Lost Judgment or Yakuza 7, never felt the grind when I collected SP for abilities just by doing stuff in the city, for example, just playing main story + doing substories and going to restraunts to replenish HP gave me enough bonus SP points to gain strong abilities to use in fights later on without any grinding.

This game also has cons, such as annoying "Keihin Gang assault" mechanic which makes you run around town and defeat minibosses when you want to, for example, focus on doing substories and suddenly you get message from Kim, this mechanic could've used longer cooldowns.
Tailing missions were okay for me and not annoying as people make out them to be, always try to keep distance from the mark and this should make probability of failure much lower.


My personal tips for more enjoyable gameplay due to Judgment not being Lost Judgment in terms of combat mechanics:

1. Do not level up damage too early, Lvl. 2 makes Yagami so stupidly overpowered that you can't do proper full combos on common enemies and they just die from just couple of hits on Hard difficulty.
I suggest against levelling up damage unless you are having hard time with Amon or tougher enemies later in the game.

2. Try to prioritize levelling up your moves (Double quickstep, quickstep attack and cancel, etc.) and Combo Speed first, it makes combo inputs overall more smooth and responsive.


Conclusion:
Very strong 9 out of 10. Already completed the game on PS4 and replaying it on PC feels amazing, regional pricing could've been better for 2018 game but thanks to SEGA anyway for bringing it to PC.


P.S.
If any of the Yakuza modders reads this, please could you make a mod that can "turn off" Keihin Gang mechanic [spoiler]after they dealt with after "Revenge of the Keihin Gang" substory[/spoiler]? Or just make the cooldowns way longer?
Without this "endless" mechanic game would be much better.

Post-P.S.
Decided to update the review to include two "essential" mods for the game that I'm now cannot imagine playing without:

1. [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/judgment/mods/14]Faster Style Switching by Emergince[/url]
This small mod makes combat much more fluid by speeding up the style switch, making Judgment's combat more close to what we have in Lost Judgment. I like this subtle change more than full moveset overhauls which, in my opinion, kinda mess up the game flow and feel.

2. [url=https://www.nexusmods.com/judgment/mods/1]Straight to Menu JE by Tacore[/url]
Pretty much self-explanatory, skips the long intro sequence and bring you to start screen as fast as possible.

One of RGG's best games to date. 

Judgment takes the best parts from Yakuza/Like A Dragon series and add its own touch, with detective gadgets, investigation sections, etc. While the detective sections can be better, it does a good job in making players into Yagami's line of thinking.
The combat is somewhat perfected in Judgment with lots of combos, varied enemies and just generally great feel to it. While it does feel slow at first, when certain skills are unlocked, Yagami becomes really enjoyable to play, becoming a master martial artist from just a rookie in the earlier chapters.
Kamurocho is much more fleshed out now due to Friend Events where a huge numbers of npc can be befriended, some tells their own stories, some act like its own substories and some can even be teammates in random battles. This and with the usual substories (now named side cases) make Kamurocho such a well-crafted city. 

Judgment's story it one of RGG's best. It starts quite slow and eventually one case turns to another and then turns into a huge conspiracy where everything is gray, not really knowing what's really right and wrong. It's such a great well written, directed and acted story. The games does an amazing job in fleshing out its characters with believable motivations so when later on they clash with one another, the tension is believable. It makes the fights a battle of ideologies. As a detective story, it is amazing. As a thriller crime game, what a phenomenal one at that.

Yagami is also the most fitting protagonist for Judgment. an ex lawyer turned detective, he gives the game much more grounded feeling and his actions are believable. All the other supporting characters have their own highlights that they become like a real person with flaws and motivations.

Judgment, however, does stumble a bit when it comes to tailing missions and its implementations of Mortal Wounds, but its strengths far outweighs its weakness. Judgment makes me think about what is right and wrong ethically while also makes me feel sympathy, anger, sadness and guilt in its characters. Incredible game

Pros:

- Still no keyboard adaptation, can't evade without focusing on enemy, but you have to hold middle mouse button (its hard to use both MBL and MBR while holding, and remap just moves the problem to other hand) to focus

At first I wasn't sure if I'm gonna like this game. The gamE felt clunkly and slow, and while the story seemed interesting, I wasn't sure if it's something i'd end up liking.
Now, 40 hours later, I say confidently that Judgement is a game that makes me aspire to wanna make something like it.

I love this game and I love that it's a game that geniunely makes me happy. Happy with it's well written story and side stories, combat that's once you get used to it, is very enjoyable with geniunely challenging fights, and amazing music that goes along with it.
Of course the game has flaws with some annoying stuff but that's ignoring the point i'm trying to make. This is a rare game. A game that makes me happy. And in this year where the most praised games were, to put it bluntly, depressing as shit, a game like Judgement was a treat. A treat that I will highly reccomend to at least try, and a treat that I, personally, will cherish.

_On the other hand, the story felt disappointing, not much surprise there.I feel it is more about questioning the player's moral about what's going on during the story than the story itself : The perception of what is justice, and if the end justify the means.

So yes, overall good, but i hope Lost Judgement has a lot of improvements, because that still felt disappointing in the end when compared to Yakuza 0 or 7 for example.

The story is much better than any other Yakuza game I've played. The characters are a bit less iconic/interesting, though. 

The NPCs look more normal. I felt that Yakuza 0 and Kiwami had NPCs that were on average way too attractive. 

The game has plenty of the typical busywork quests. I skip all the archaic Japanese gambling games.

But being a detective and getting paid to do cases is much more believable than being a gangster helping out random people "just because". 

Character development is quite good, and you do end up caring about each character. The story arcs are believable and exciting to follow. 

The worst part of the game is its excessive use of the tailing/following minigame. It's actually quite fun, as long as it's part of an interesting story. But too many side-cases have you follow people that you couldn't give a damn about. (Looking at you, psychic lady)

I can never get myself to 100% these games. I got maybe 45 out of 50 "friends" after 87 hours of play. 

The game does a good job at giving you plenty of time to do these side activities though, and it feels a lot less shoe-horned in than it did in Yakuza 0

The fighting is fun in some ways, but the core mechanics of wall-jumps and hopping over people doesn't really work well. You have to run for a second before it works, so you end up having to run away and then run back, because otherwise you will often not be able to trigger the moves and just awkwardly bump into things. 

The special meter runs out way too quickly for what it does. It never felt worth it to activate it. The fighting system should have spent some more time in the oven. But the game lets you insta-kill/end encounters if you want to, which I did a lot near the end. 

The side-quest where a gang arrives to Kamurocho and you have to defeat it's leaders is SUPER ANNOYING. It happens WAY TOO OFTEN and I cringed every time it happened.

[h1]If you want me to shut up, you're going to have to kill me[/h1]
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Never in my life would I have expected [b]Judgment[/b] to come to PC. I was so happy to finally get a chance to play the game in all its glory, and let me tell you, it was a wild ride. Everything about it was just fantastic and I wanted more of it, and it does everything I want in a video game. Doing this review will be a tough one though, as I donâ€™t want to spoil too much about what this game has to offer. [b]Judgment[/b] is a spin-off from the [b]Yakuza[/b] series and takes place in the red-light district of [b]Kamurocho[/b].

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Fantastic story that can get really intense
[*]Well-crafted characters that are well developed
[*]Fun combat that has two fighting styles to switch between
[*]Lots of minigames and side cases for you to do
[*]Awesome soundtrack that will stick with you
[*]Beautiful graphics that makes Kamurocho feel alive
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The issues were so minor that they did not meddle with my experience
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
Disgraced ex-lawyer [b]Takayuki Yagami[/b] is working as a private detective alongside his best friend [b]Masaharu Kaito[/b], who is an ex-yakuza. Recently, [b]Kamurocho[/b] has been dealing with murders featuring victims of the [b]Kyorei Clan[/b] yakuza where they have their eyes gouged out for some reason. However, it seems that this entire ordeal is more than meets the eye, and [b]Yagami[/b] has to either go head-first into danger or lay low in hiding.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2899835224
I never thought Iâ€™d see the day when a story for a spin-off [b]Yakuza[/b] game manages to pull off an even better story than the main-line [b]Yakuza[/b] games. It knows how to keep things tense throughout and has many twists that will keep you on your toes along the way.

I also enjoyed the characters as well, [b]Yagami[/b] is just entertaining throughout the entire story. And when he is not doing a series case you can make him do side cases where his reactions are just brilliant the moment that happens. [b]Kaito[/b] is also another character I loved, his personality is something I like.

There are many characters that I want to talk about but I donâ€™t want to spoil the story too much, as itâ€™s honesty really well done. I want everyone who is reading this review to experience the story as best as they can, itâ€™s a wild ride from start to finish.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Combat is very well done, you have two distinct fighting styles that you can switch between at any given time. [b]Tiger style[/b] is best used when you are in one on one fights or there is only a single enemy you are fighting. [b]Crane[/b] is better used on multiple enemies and can help take care of large groups. Although [b]Tiger[/b] and [b]Crane[/b] can actually do the exact opposite of what they are supposed to be doing which is interesting, frequent switching is encouraged due to the long recovery times for each style.

Also, thanks to my playing [b]Yakuza 6[/b], I am more comfortable with the [b]Dragon Engine[/b] which does make its return in this game. [b]Yagami[/b] also has access to [b]EX Boost[/b], which makes him less likely to flinch, attack faster, and all damage goes to the [b]EX gauge[/b] instead of his health. [b]Yagami[/b] does also have a skill tree in which he will get upgrades, some of these skills though can only be unlocked by books or 2D codes throughout the game. [b]Crane[/b] style also has no sole upgrades, as most of them benefit [b]Tiger[/b] style only or both.

Bosses do borrow move sets from previous [b]Yakuza[/b] games, however, as they have an additional attack called [b]Deadly Attacks[/b]. These attacks cannot be blocked and if [b]Yagami[/b] gets hit by them, he will not only take damage but cause a [b]Mortal Wound[/b]. [b]Mortal Wounds[/b] will cause [b]Yagamiâ€™s[/b] health bar to not be fixed by normal healing items and he must either use a med kit or go to a doctor which is only available in a certain part of the world, which means there is only one. Health kits are also very expensive so you better stock up on some money if you want to get them.

Guns and stab wounds can also cause [b]Mortal Wounds[/b] but they are not as severe as bosses' attacks are. Although to be fair thatâ€™s a good thing as every time I see a gun in a new [b]Yakuza[/b] game I get flashbacks from [b]Yakuza 0[/b].

There is also a ton of side content for you to do, like playing arcade games, mini-games, and side cases. The side cases were overall very entertaining to do and I loved each one I did, some of them were very funny and they fit the [b]Yakuza[/b] theme of being weird and outlandish. The arcade games to me were interesting but a unique one that I enjoyed was a game called [b]Kamurocho of The Dead[/b], which is a crossover to [b]Yakuza Dead Souls[/b] and [b]The House of The Dead[/b] series.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2899835321
[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The soundtrack for [b]Judgment[/b] is honesty really well done and I loved the amount of good music that was implemented. It nails the aspect of the moment when a certain song comes, my favorite has to be the [b]Keihin Alliance[/b] theme

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
[b]Judgment[/b] is a beautiful-looking game and [b]Kamurocho[/b] is more alive than ever, I did experience some FPS drops while I was playing but a patch was later implemented to solve the problem. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. The game did run at a nice smooth 60 FPS when it was not stuttering
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2899835489
[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
I highly recommend playing [b]Judgement[/b] if you have not already, especially if you are a fan of the [b]Yakuza[/b] series. I recommend this game at full price at that, but I think you should get the [b]Judgment[/b] bundle as you get this game, [b]Lost Judgment[/b], and [b]Lost Judgmentâ€™s[/b] DLC is for free when you purchase both games. A sweet deal that I honestly think is well worth the price as [b]Judgment[/b] never disappointed me in the slightest when it came to its story and gameplay. Something that I personally find a very hard thing for a game to do, and I am looking forward to playing its sequel.
