Reminds me of [b] Shenmue [/b] to some degree, except in Judgement you're not a high school student skipping school to find his fathers murderer. Instead, you're a former Lawyer now being a Local Detective trying to solve murder cases and such (totally cool). 

Nonetheless, I wouldn't be too surprised if this game were made by the same creator... like seriously, take for example the side comparison.

[h1] Interactions with NPC's. [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] yes.. practically with everyone, including ones not of any importance related to the main story.

[b] Judgement: [/b] yes, but only with the ones you can befriend or are otherwise mission related (main story missions or side missions).

[h1] Toy Capsule Machine:  [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] yes, an ass ton of capsule toys to be collected in fact.

[b] Judgement: [/b] yes, but not nearly as many compared to Shenmue.

[h1] Arcade Mini-games: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] yes.

[b] Judgment: [/b] yes, though very few are the same as the ones you can play in Shenmue (I wish the boxing one where you punch the target by timing the button press were in this game)

[h1] Playing Darts: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] Yes.

[b] Judgement: [/b] Yes, but also easier imo.

[h1] Gambling: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] Yes; Slot Machines.

[b] Judgement: [/b] Yes, but with Poker and Black Jack. Also other things perhaps.

[h1] Buying Food and Items at Convenient Stores: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue: [/b] Yes.

[b] Judgment: [/b] Yes.

[h1] Fighting gang members and such: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue; [/b] Yes, occasionally as part of the Story.

[b] Judement; [/b] yes, an ass ton, almost around every corner you get into a fight.

[h1] Chasing people down while evading obstacles with timed button pressing: [/h1]

[b] Shenmue; [/b] yes.

[b] Jedgement: [/b] yes.

[h1] Differences However: [/h1]

Shenmue's fighting system is a bit more combo ish, with each skill having it's own mastery level, in which you can strengthen by training in a Parking Lot or Playground. Also new moves can be learned from Scrolls and certain NPC...
   Judgement has Skills that can be bought and Obtained with SP that are gained from fighting Yakuza and such (no training in a Parking Lot, etc).

In Judgement you can go to Bars and Liquor Stores, get drunk and even use the Drunken Boxing style Martial Arts (sorta), but you can't in Shenmue (there are Bars in Shenmue of course, but you can't drink Alcoholic beverages in that game).

You can play Pool in Shenmue, but not in Judgment (in Judgement you can play Mahjong or some other type of board game).

In Shenmue there's a kitten you can feed and pet... In Judgement there are Stray Cats you can search for during Inspections (what's up with that? also kinda gives me the "where's Waldo?" type vibe lol)

In Shenmue you can get beverages from Vendor Machines and drink them (although pointless, since it doesn't restore health nor anything... but somehow oddly satisfying to watch Ryo Hazuki down a Soda in a few gulps); but not in Judgment, though in Judgement you can go into restaurants to buy food and beverages (in which actually does restore health).

In Judgement you can fly a Drone, and can also do Drone Races (no Drones in Shenmue).

You can smoke in Judgment, not in Shenmue (not a big deal to me of course, I don't give a rats behind about Cigs).

You can go to the Batting Cage and hit Baseballs in Judgement, but not in Shenmue.

[h1] Overall: [/h1]

There are perhaps other similarities and differences as well, but for the most part I'd say if you like Shenmue, then you'll probably really like this game too. that goes without saying of course, that in some aspects I think Shenmue is better, while also Judgement may even be better in other aspects.

P.S. I'm curious whom would win in a fight between Takayuki Yagami versus Ryo Hazuki... what's your thought's? I would be interested to hear in the comments below lol

The Yakuza series, or Like A Dragon, or Ryu Ga Gotoku if you prefer) have formed a critical part of my life at this point. I started Yakuza 0 during the start of the COVID pandemic, and have been on a binging spree since then. I didn't own a Playstation however, so imagine my absolute joy when they just announced Judgement/Lost Judgement for PC. More Yakuza!

Judgement or Judge Eyes is an absolutely amazing spinoff that I really wouldn't mind seeing more of. It's clear that the devs didn't wish to be locked into just the traditional Kiryu plotline with these entries (despite going back to him anyway with the recent announcements lol). If you're wondering if the characters in this one are just as lovable as the old Yakuza games, don't worry, Toshihiro Nagoshi's got your back. 

If you're looking for more critical reviews, there's plenty out there. But if you ask me to list what I love about this series; 
-the Japanese aesthetic.
-the art direction of the locations (seriously, Kamurocho at night in the Dragon Engine looks absolutely [b] amazing [/b])
-the action beat 'em up gameplay (I still liked Yakuza 7 despite not enjoying turn based gameplay as much)
-Buff, muscly men beating the FUCK out of goons, sometimes shirtless, in almost every game, charming female sidekicks.... Hot characters in general, really. Obviously subjective.
-the minigames. THE MINIGAMES. They form 50% of the actual game. You can get lost in any one of the minigames as if they're actual games. You can play SEGA's arcade games in the game because SEGA's the publisher for the Yakuza series and they got the rights for it.
-the plots. Quite frankly the plots are batshit insane in every single game, and it goes so wild at times that after a certain point you slowly accept that these games really are just a fantasy version of reality, just so your suspension of disbelief doesn't shatter completely.

Honestly, despite the flaws in each of these games, the innovations they try with each new entry that both please and piss off fans, each of them is [b] such [/b] a treat that really, you owe it yourself to try at least one of the entries in this series.

i played this game almost exactly one year ago on ps4 for the first time, and while i enjoyed it a lot, the game made me frustrated a few times, i played on normal and got wrecked, and i had marathoned all the numbered games before playing judgment, so i wouldn't have considered myself inexperienced with rgg, looking back i now realize that marathoning can ruin the experience of something, because i was so focused on the story i barely did any side content, i still loved the story it was the best rgg had put out at the time and combat was great, the game was just really hard for some reason, i bought the pc version day one, and after replaying it, i made sure to put more time into the side content and it completely changed the game, it was much easier, no boss was too hard, but the game also felt a little too easy, but the experience was 100% more enjoyable, its very rare for me to enjoy a game more the second time, even yakuza 0 i love it just as much as the first, not more and not less, but judgment i liked more, its story is insanely gripping, and the combat is a lot of fun, the game leans towards tiger a bit too much, but that issue was resolved in lost judgment, this game is definitely worth it, its one of the best from rgg, and even with the issue of johnny's built into this series, its amazing. im hopeful for a future of the judge series.

Originally this game was only sepposed to be sold on PlayStation4 as a spin-off to the original Yakuza/Lad-series. However, when Judgment got first announced that it was going to be ported to pc I had my hopes up. After all, this will probably be "the" only franchise that will have actual combat based street fighting. It seems that RGG studios only have plans to do RPG-styled combat in their future Yakuza/Lad or other spinn-off games. So this looked pretty promising to the fans that Judgment will see a new light of day on pc. Only to discover a month later, that the agency for Yagami's actor: Jhonnys, had allegidly debunked that announcement made by Sega and claimed that the game will not be avalible on steam due to the privacy for their talents and actors. Which by then Sega had no choice but to own up to that word. This came as a pretty big shock to the community as evryone who loved yakuza games or liked the combat based fighting mechanics specifically had to go home empty handed. However here we are, not just Judgment but also Lost Judgment have both been released to steam. This meant that RGG studios has seen the cries of the fandom and blessed them by talking things through with Jhonny's to finalize this negotiation. So if you are one of the people who still enjoy the old combat system from previous Yakuza games and want to see something new and refreshing, then this game is for you.

[i](This review is written in comparison relative to all mainline Yakuza games (Zero -> 7) with exception of spin-offs & the sequel thus may not be as insightful to people that haven't played one of RGG studio's games)[/i]
[h1]TL;DR - Judgment is one of RGG studio's finest work[/h1]


[b][u]The Good[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Combat [/b]- Being made in Dragon Engine (alike K2/6), the combat has undergone massive improvements whilst introducing new mechanics (wall jumps & flux fissures for example). Yagami plays distinctly different from previous protagonists with the two available stances albeit with slight hiccups on how both are designed. The combat truly starts to show its appeal when you've unlocked two combo speed upgrades & majority of EX/skills from the second tab.
[*][b]Story[/b] - This is probably [i]the strongest point[/i] of this game, and in my opinion has the best story out there. The story introduces lots of plot threads & manage to neatly tie it all together by the end whilst having the whole narrative grounded in reality more than any other RGG games; the story is paced neatly with slight intentional paddings here & there but it doesn't take away from the main narrative one bit. It does take awhile to get going, past the slow first few chapters, but it doesn't brake much after.
[*][b]Progression System[/b] - I liked SP systems in place which incentivizes exploring the town for side activities.
[*][b]Visuals[/b] - Amazing if your hardware is capable enough, the port is good enough performance-wise.
[*][b]Tiger Drop[/b]
[*][b]Friendship System[/b] - I don't know what to elaborate here but it is a really nice addition to the game.
[*][b]Masaharu Kaito[/b]
[*][b]Side Contents[/b] - They're still there, in abundance.
[/list]


[b][u]The Alrights[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Music[/b] - Did not find much outstanding tracks up until the last chapter where most of the few bangers are from : I'd definitely have to re-listen to most tracks again.
[*][b]Photo Operations[/b] - One of the new mechanics that are added so you truly feel like a [i]detective[/i], nothing noteworthy and is used once (?) throughout the story
[*][b]Search System[/b] - Another arduous new mechanic in place for you to feel slightly more involved in what Yagami is doing.
[*][b]Lockpicking/Thumb-pressing[/b] - Alright in controls & in difficulties.
[*][b]Limited Medicine[/b] - They've removed sources of Staminan & Toughness XX & Royales while limiting the amount to 3 of each in its lowest quality variant - I don't mind it personally but it could be tough for people who need them.
[*][b]Story Battles[/b] - There are too less solo fights while too many group fights in the story.
[*][b]Combat Stances[/b] - Two stances in place while skills are designed mostly for one of the two (Tiger) - the other stance gets way too less love & is generally lesser fun to use with DE's "attacks-bounce-on-block" function.
[/list]


[b][u]The Bads[/u][/b]
[list]
[*][b]Tailing Mission[/b] - Tiring & probably the least enjoyable experience of the game. Personally, I don't mind it but can't help but sigh when the mission comes as NPC are dumb as rock & does one-dimensional routes with occasional turn arounds.
[*][b]Keihin Gang[/b] - [i]What if we make Majima Everywhere system but with a group of unlikeable chucklefucks with no way of resolving it in story?[/i] The four bosses/characters introduced in this are boring and fell flat while having their presence makes the encounter rate terribly high, with how street fights are rewarded these fights usually get in your way instead of anything meaningful
[*][b]Mortal Wound[/b] - No reason for this to exist - MW is basically a permanent HP-reduction debuff inflicted when you get hit by guns or bosses' finishers moves; it is a way to push a gold-sink into the game with introductions of MedKits.
[*][b]Denuvo DRM[/b]
[/list]


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Judgment is a must-play for fans of RGG studio & their games; it is a well crafted spin-offs that does all right they always did and explore more into narratives and game mechanics they've never done before. I understand that most of the improvements are made in its sequel but this is meant as a standalone review. 
[b]The game has no tie-in relevance or any reference to the mainline games' story[/b] & it serves as a standalone game or an entry point into the whole series. Game is worth the price even without sales.

If you're looking for another entry in the brilliant Yakuza franchise, then Judgment is the way to go.

This is the first entry in the spin off Judgment series and the third in the Dragon Engine. While this game does follow the atypical Yakuza formula of beat em up combat, substories, and everyone's favorite Mahjong. Judgment manages to have that Yakuza feel while maintaining a grounded story. Their is no more tiger dropping tigers and tanking gunshots in heat mode.You play as Takayuki Yagami, a disgraced lawyer turned detective who aims to find the truth behind grizzly killings in Kamurocho. Knives and guns are your biggest threats as mortal wounds permanently looms adding a higher stakes in action packed long battles and boss fights. After two entries, the Dragon engine finally shows its true potential as the combat with Yagami is fast and fluid. The days of the clunky combat of Yakuza 6 are well and truly behind. If you plan on 100% this game be prepared to play a lot of Mahjong and you will get familiar with Dice & Cube. Lastly, I recommend to stay away from spoilers especially that which reveal the identity of the Mole since it would ruin the fun of their boss fight.

Given the overwhelmingly positive review, I just want to give an alternative opinion here. 

The game is overall ok. Solid 6/10. At least it is better than Yakuza Kiwami, which is pretty much just recycled/water-downed Yakuza 0. But also note that this game is nowhere better than Yakuza 0.

I'm very intrigued by the plot, except the game decides to pause the main story mid-game and force you to do boring side-stories. I assume this is because the main story is too short on its own to carry this game. A lot of these side-stories involve you being a detective to either stalk people and/or play "find the object in the room/image" game, both of which feel kinda meh and a slightly annoying. I do enjoy the deductions. But sometimes I feel like the game wants you to deduct in a very specific order. At times you know what happened but you have to kinda guess how the game wants you reach a conclusion and select dialogues (show evidence) in a specific order. 

The combat feels really fresh. It does not feel like recycled content. But beware that the main character really loves walls. Apparently a lot of his moves are designed around running toward a wall and doing some sort of jump-kick. In my opinion this design just makes the combat feel less "open" than Yakuza 0. And since it is kinda difficult to pull off the jump-kick, mostly I just end up getting lazy and grabbing a bike to bash enemies. 

I'm also kinda annoyed by the Japanese audio. Not sure why but the English dialogue audio version of this game feels a lot more crisp than the Japanese one. In the Japanese dialogue audio, it almost feels like the voice actors are speaking through a thin blanket.

Judgment is a third person action game, and a spin off from the Yakuza series, which again takes place in the Kamurocho area of Tokyo. When a Tojo clan captain is accused of murdering a rival gang member, player character Takayuki Yagami, an ex-lawyer turned private investigator, is hired to find evidence proving his innocence, only to become drawn into a much larger conspiracy.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

â€¢	Gameplay is very similar to the Yakuza games, so if youâ€™ve already played any of those, this will feel familiar.

â€¢	Combat takes place in real time (like Kiryuâ€™s games, not Like a Dragonâ€™s turn based system). Youâ€™ll have to beat up enemies with combos of punches and kicks, you can grab and throw enemies, pick up objects like bikes and traffic cones to use as weapons, dodge or block enemy attacks, and successful hits will build up your special meter allowing you to perform various powerful finishing moves.

â€¢	Combat is easier than most of the Yakuza games. After a couple of hours I put the difficulty up to hard, and even then the mobs that wander Kamurocho were quite trivial to defeat. The scripted story encounters and boss fights were more challenging, but I was able to win most fights on the first try.

â€¢	As Yagami investigates the case youâ€™ll need to use his detective skills in various ways. Search crime scenes for clues, reveal evidence during interrogations, stealthily follow suspects as they slowly walk around half the city, and perform QTEs during chase sequences.

â€¢	In addition to main story quests, the open world contains lots of other content. There are side missions where Yagami takes PI cases such as investigating a cheating husband, protecting a client from creepy stalkers, or finding a missing person. Meanwhile many of the shop owners will ask you to help them deal with their problems.

â€¢	If you want to take a break from beating up thugs, there are lots of fun minigames to play. Many of them have appeared in the Yakuza games, including darts, baseball, poker, blackjack, shogi, mahjong and classic Sega arcade games. Judgment also contains a few new games such as drone racing, an on rails shooter called Kamuro Of The Dead, and a VR dice game.

[h1]Story[/h1]

â€¢	As usual the story is excellent, and well written. Yagami is a strong main character, his companions are all very likeable, and there are lots of other interesting characters including Yakuza, lawyers, cops, journalists and scientists. Thereâ€™s so much detail, honestly the storytelling in these games is better than a lot of TV shows.

â€¢	Main story cutscenes look very cinematic.

â€¢	Main quest is fully voiced, and the voice acting is high quality, but the side quests are text only.

â€¢	While the main story has a serious tone, many of the side quests feature the Yakuza gamesâ€™ typical wacky scenarios.

[h1]Technical[/h1]

â€¢	It took me 57 hours to finish the main story and around 70% of side quests.

â€¢	I didnâ€™t have any problems with crashes or framerate.

â€¢	Controls work well most of the time on my Xbox 360 gamepad, although it took me a while to get used to dodge / quick step requiring you to press both RB + A (Iâ€™m sure in previous games it was just the A button). And the two lockpicking minigames are almost impossible using gamepad thumbsticks, so I had to use mouse and keyboard for more precise control.

â€¢	While searching crime scenes, a couple of the clues where so small that these scenes turned into pixel hunts as I moved the cursor over every inch of the screen, still didnâ€™t find anything (even with the ability which makes the gamepad vibrate when youâ€™re hovering over the correct area) and I actually had to consult a guide to progress.

â€¢	The game seems to be in a permanent tutorial mode, as after every fight youâ€™ll see a message appear in the bottom corner of the screen offering you hints about things youâ€™ve already done dozens of times, and I couldnâ€™t find any way to disable this.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Judgment is a great game, the gameplay is mostly enjoyable despite a few small annoyances, and the story is excellent. Thereâ€™s plenty of content to justify a full price purchase.

Thereâ€™s no connection to story or characters of the main Yakuza series, so if youâ€™re interested in these games but donâ€™t want to catch up on 8 games worth of lore, this would be a good starting point.

Resident Evil 8 manages to be a beautiful, visual masterpiece, while including overwhelmingly campy writing. With these factors in mind, it personally sorted itself out for me as a horror/comedy in its story. Take that as you will; personally I loved.

However, one thing that I must stress to my very core is the very real passion, love, and care that went into crafting this game. It may not have enough horror, depending on your taste, and some people may dislike the heavy emphasis on the action aspect of the game.

But as continue to play through the game, you'll realize the delicate structuring of every detail that was put into this piece of art. Every area within this game is so stupidly detailed with the new RE engine, and it can't be praised enough for it's style. And, personally, I think its cheesy writing makes a hilariously bad/good story.

Could it have done better in some spots, definitely, but when you compare this game to overwhelming amount of cash grabs out there, you'll learn to cherish this fun and replayable experience!

I should also mention that I played this game on a Dell Inspiron laptop with integrated graphics and a Ryzen 7, and it still looked visually stunning (with 60 fps in closed, indoor areas, and slightly dipping in outdoor areas). This really speaks about Capcom's desire to optimize this game as much as they could for their audience, and I think that should be well known.

You can get a 9-gates tile for Mahjong from a mid-game store in the sewers, and a Joker card for Poker from a late-game friend mission, but you had better be a WIZ at Mahjong, because unlike the previous Yakuza games, that is the ONLY way you can get the rest of the single-use cheat objects you need for the other side-games!

Judgement exceeded my expectations with a wonderful story, great characters and the same zany side quests weâ€™ve come to expect from the Yakuza series.

I absolutely loved Yazuka 0, Kiwami 1, Kiwami 2 and Yakuza 6 (havenâ€™t played 3, 4 or 5).  It was refreshing to go back into that world with Judgement.  It's got the same gameplay loop as the aforementioned games and that is definitely a good thing.  Combine that with an excellent story and well written and fleshed out characters and youâ€™ve got a real banger.  The game gives you a lot for your money.  It took me almost 55 hours for my first play though so I got plenty of bang for my buck especially considering the quality on display here.

Judgement is visually pleasing, ran super smooth for me on my system and the battle mechanics are tight and well thought out.

Nothing is perfect, however, and I did find myself getting a little overwhelmed towards the end of the game with all sorts of side missions, friend quests, dating and whatnot.  This isnâ€™t a criticism of Judgement as much as it is a criticism of all the Yakuza games as the actual story is serious, intense and urgent, whereas the side content is utterly ridiculous, far out and zany.  This juxtaposition can cause confusion when you are at key moments in the story only to go off looking for a panty thief or lost cats.  This is what makes the Yakuza games so endearing and unique to other titles, though so it really is up to you when you complete side quests and how you choose to experience the game.

In full honesty, this game is about what I expected as an RGG studio game - that is, high quality in basically every regard. I've been a little spoiled for animations and faces recently, so my usually high opinion of their face and movement animation work is less stellar than it has been in the past, but as a whole Judgment still looks very good. 

The music didn't really stand out to me, unfortunately, unlike in the mainline games. I liked the start-of-chapter review stuff a lot, it helped keep everything in focus when I had to take a few weeks off the game and return in the middle of chapter 10. The story was definitely less convoluted than in the LAD games, but this meant that some of the really goofy moments (highlights of the LAD series, imo) felt a little off-key. But the combat might be the best they've done in this engine, it's definitely superior to 6 and K2. It's fast, fluid, and fun, even if the positional stuff (like wall rebounds) take a minute to get adjusted to. 

There was one section, late in the game, where you were required to learn a certain mechanic of an area, and if you fought the boss of the area without utilizing the mechanic, you were (unfairly) punished by making your attacks miss. Also, as a hint: your strongest move, flux fissure, cannot be chained into bosses. They'll just stumble. I did not have a boss encounter where this was not true. 

This is maybe a 7/10 compared to the heights I know RGG can produce. Still a 100% worthwhile experience ("fun" does not begin to describe the drone racing, especially as you power it up). If you like the Yakuza games, you'll probably like this.

A pretty solid game. It has a a great story but it suffers from lacking gameplay compared to some of the games in the Yakuza series. 

The story was amazing, however the combat didn't feel like it had a very high skill ceiling considering you would just spam your OP items you get which I am guessing were some kind of DLC but they kind of completely broke the gameplay once I realized they were actually infinite. You have about 7 or so dlc items which give you super god-like powers, literally summoning lightning from the sky and insta kill destruction. I just used those and all fights became childs play and there was no reason for me to continue doing side-quests to gather money and xp.

Talking about XP, I found the system lacking. I'm probably wrong but for some reason it felt like there weren't a lot of stuff to unlock. There were few things to unlock but A LOT of grinding to get it.

Yagami had really nice combat moves though, they were different from the Yakuza series but it also felt a little lame a lot of the times that he had the exact same animations as Kiryu.

Talking about Yagami, I really enjoyed him and all of the other characters in the game. As I said, the story was really great and so were the characters. There was even a "buddy" system in the game, however, it wasn't really good and I thought that Yakuza: Like A Dragon did it way better.

Being constantly attacked in the streets is no new thing for this series, however now it felt REALLY annoying. There's this gang that is after you and not just random thugs, however sometimes their leaders will appear and defeating them will remove the meter and make the attacks happen less... for a bit. Yes, you don't take them down, you just win the fight over them and later it will happen again and you have to defeat them again again and again just to get some air whilst running from mission to mission. It would've been way more interesting to have a system where you take down their leaders one by one and they're permanently down like in Yakuza 0.

Being in the perspective of a detective really helped this game, it was really interesting for once to see Kamurocho in a different angle, however the tailing missions were probably the worst addition they could've ever added. You do SO many missions where you literally just walk behind and npc and hide from them when they look back, and they go on for WAY too long and you do them way too much. I have no idea what they thought when they added this in. And it's not like it is only for some side missions, no, it's for a lot of the main missions as well.

[h1] Review [/h1]
In this game you take on the [b] role of Japanese detective/ex-lawyer Yagami[/b], who returns to the courtroom to help exonerate the captain of a yakuza clan. But in the search for evidence, a possible connection between the captain and the murders caused by The Mole is discovered. The captain, of course, denies these allegations, but something about the aggressiveness of his response convinces Yagami otherwise. And that's why, after proving his innocence, [b]he sets out to find the true identity of the mass murderer[/b]. An interesting story is accompanied from beginning to end by a lot of twists, action scenes and music which makes the game that much greater

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

After a long time you can switch between multiple combat styles.  Crane style which focuses more on [b]speed and is very useful against groups of enemies[/b] who don't know the concept of blocking. And this is the big weakness, because it is enough for one of them to block and the whole combo is stopped and the only solution is to switch to Tiger style, which is a bit slower, but [b]stronger and focused on accuracy.[/b]

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]

The soundtrack definitely enhances the experience of the game, and every time the music started playing at the start of a fight, I empathized with Yagami's motivations and fought like everything was at stake. Rather than describe each ost individually, I'll leave a list of my favorites here:

I didn't think it was possible to make a spin-off that would somehow surpass its source material, but I was proven quite wrong. [b]Judgment[/b] is, without a doubt in my mind, one of the finest games that Nagoshi's Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio has assembled. It was worth the wait for this port to PC. You owe it to yourself to play this game as a Yakuza fan. I almost feel inclined to say that if you haven't played the Yakuza games, starting with this one would potentially hurt your ability to enjoy the others in the series, despite not having direct-ties to the main-line series. That isnâ€™t to say that the others are bad, per say, but this game, along with Like a Dragon, feel like the culmination of everything this studio has learned.

When I played Yakuza 0-6 in that order as they were releasing on steam, I felt this jarring feeling in the back of my mind that I was watching a creatorâ€™s evolution; 0 was an insane high-bar of content in terms of story, gameplay, and side-activity. Playing 1-5, after, felt like I had just read an authorâ€™s latest best-seller and then went back to read all their previous books in the order they were released. I saw all the tropes, mistakes, and lessons-learned. Getting to 5, 6, and Like a Dragon (hands down the best games next to 0), filled me with only one thought: More. I wanted more.

Judgment is more in a way I never knew I wanted. Apart from the star-setting of Kamurocho, none of the original cast returns, not even a cameo. As much as I loved the references and callback moments of Like a Dragon, Judgment was made with confidence that the audience would enjoy this gameâ€™s cast and story without needing help. It stood proudly on its own, and I have so much respect for that determination. A lesser studio would have had our new cast run into one or two characters from the old blood at some point, and the fact I eventually didnâ€™t want that to happen speaks volumes, considering the original Yakuza cast are some of my most cherished video-game characters ever.

Gameplay is another triumph for Judgment in terms of confidence on the studioâ€™s part. Combat-wise,  we have finally received the best of both worlds: 0/Kiwamiâ€™s fun, dynamic stance-system combined with K2/6/LaDâ€™s modern engine. It was the biggest hurdle for me to get over when I played K2 and 6; tha feeling that something was lost when the stance-system was retired. Yeah, we got the polished visuals and physics, but we lost the depth. Judgment brought it back, along with a fun arrangement of 0-tier side-content. Like all the best in the series, I was lost for a handful of hours in the side-content, and unlike most western RPGs, this never felt like a chore or an obligation for leveling-up. I was delightfully gobbling up content wherever I could find it, because I knew I was going to find quality wherever I looked after my first few hours back in Kamurocho.

The story is harder to talk about because I want you to play this game and not read anything that touches on it, but I want to say that completing Chapter 1 felt like I had just cracked open a premium bottle of wine, and I wasnâ€™t going to chug it, but, rather, savor every moment. RGG had a vision for Judgment, and that vision needed its own vibe, and what a vibe it was, lads.

This game is set in the [i]Yakuza[/i] Extended Universe and very much follows on from the previous [i]Yakuza[/i] titles with real-time combat. What I'm trying to say is that whether or not you like the [i]Yakuza[/i] "formula" is almost certainly going to determine whether or not you like this game. If not, you are unlikely to get any enjoyment out of this title. If you do though, it's really more of the same good stuff you like.
 The "investigation" elements, if you can call them that, feel extremely shallow. None of the dialogue choices actually make any difference; getting the wrong answer in the main story just prompts Yagami to try again. Apart from getting to zero health, the only other way to get a Game Over is if one gets caught during a tailing/photograph sequence. As you can imagine, the tailing sequences themselves are somewhat tedious, involving walking behind someone and taking cover when they look backwards. So, it's safe to say that this is definitely not a big genre-bend from the previous [i]Yakuza[/i] games.
Of course, the most important things in the [i]Yakuza[/i] "formula" are enjoyable fighting, plentiful side quests/mini games, and side-splitting sub stories. Well, this certainly doesn't disappoint in that regard. The fighting has been tweaked somewhat so that Yagami is more of a glass cannon than previous fighting characters, and so are the enemies. This means fewer health bars to break through, but equally it means your own health must be kept in check. It makes for a faster-paced gameplay style, and I do quite like it, even if it is more challenging. As with the characters in the recent [i]Yakuza[/i] titles, Yagami is able to switch between fighting styles. There are only two of them here, which reduces the variety somewhat, but also makes things a bit simpler. The "mortal wounds" element is an attempt to mix things up, but it's just a bit of a pain in all honesty. It's all too easy to get hit with one from a gunman right after the start of a random battle, forcing a trip to the underground doctor and goodbye to 20 grand. The Keihin Gang is also somewhat annoying. I wouldn't mind fighting these guys every so often, but it seems you're getting a call from Kim about them every 5 minutes or so that they're back in town. There's no real story arc with them either; it's basically just a way of farming materials needed for making "extracts," which is another new thing added into this game. At least extracts do have their uses, so it may be worth collecting the materials for them if you find they help you out, or you are just a completionist.
Any slight disappointments in the battle system though are made up by the fantastic story this game has, including all the various investigations you can do, with genuine laugh-out-loud moments. All of the characters are really nicely written, and I just think they did a really fantastic job of it. In conclusion, this game is absolutely worth getting if you want a slight twist on the old [i]Yakuza[/i] formula with a great story and enjoyable gameplay. Steer clear however, if you are wanting to play a game that's truly in the "investigation" genre. Recommended, 75%.

Game is really, really fun, maybe it's because I missed playing an RGG game, having missed the console version these are my first impressions of the game.

Yagami having two fighting styles which is Tiger Style for Big PP Solo Target Damage and Crane Style for kinda AOE EX Actions and EX Boost is a nice change from Kiwami 2, my only real complaint being Crane having nothing truly giving it an edge or something unique in the skills menu and it staggers a lot outside of EX Boost, outside it's inherit kind of AOE damage normals and EX Actions, There are some skills that apply to both fighting styles although nothing that only focuses on buffing or giving Crane Style something new, but it still is useful for dealing with multiple mobs, up to 3 with a couple or few EX Actions and if you like varying up your attacks like me e.g. not spamming Flux Fissure, as fun as it is too watch 2 bars of EX gauge fill while deleting an enemy while drunk(being intoxicated is a buff with skills that gives extra EX Gauge), it get boring after a while personally.

Combat is great, maybe a little easy throughout it all, first playthrough was ~55 hours on Hard and my ~90 hours is padded because of some afk in some session, exploration and premium adventure. I was able ignore damage upgrades till chapter 5 for the first upgrade, 8 or 9 for the second and 12 for the last since i had every other skill. But that was just my experience with Hard Difficulty and only upgraded damage when I felt it would be a needed because the enemies quality in the random fights were getting higher and a certain side-case in the later chapters rewarding 1.2 million yen really made me grind a little for that second upgrade.

For a few nitpicks, nothing that really affects my overall impression of the game just somethings that slightly bothered me. I feel like there could a little more EX Actions, reduce some of the animation times for the EX Actions unlocked later, reduce the frequency of the combat event with a toggle or something and make some normal attack prioritise over EX Actions. 

I really miss Kiwami 2 Kiryu's 4 directions dodge heat actions, they were awesome, would've been cool to see Yagami's version of them.

Some of EX Actions animations lengths were a quite long while visually it's awesome and stimulating, I get a little impatient waiting for them to finish, mainly the Stunned Enemy> Ex Action and Ex Boost> Battle Stance/Lock On(R1)> Ex Boost, other than some animations being a bit too long they're great. 

The Combat Event happens too often and I sometimes just ignored the thugs and just did my own thing, there are some tricks to avoid fighting but I never used them as I still enjoy fighting more than not, would be great if some kind of toggle or frequency reduction was available, the random fights are fine, just the frequency of the event is too often.

There are a few EX Actions that take priority over normal heavy attacks, personally I just wanna soccer kick a low health guy without using my EX Gauge to punt him into the air or make him speen with a EX Action kick, or using the Drunk EX Action instead of the infamous counter from previous games, It's a little annoying but not that bad either since EX Gauge is easy to build once Flux Fissure is unlocked and the EX skills upgraded makes it easier even without Flux Fissure.

The new Deadly Attack/Mortal Wounds systems is interesting but I think it doesn't really do anything in the long run except be a minor inconvenience when you can just use any medkits, even the smallest medkit to regain access to your full health bar and heal up using the plethora of items available, or avoid being wounded completely by running far enough or doing a wall attack depending on the attacks.

Extracts are a cool idea, never really used any since outside of the DLC ones and growth extract and even then I barely got the KamuroGO challenge done by the final chapter, mainly Fire and Lightning Fists, Instant kill for when I'm feeling lazy during the Combat Event and the healing one when I'm running around Kamurocho and being frugal with my Yen. Wish I found a use for them to make crafting the other ones feel slightly more important, jumping over(from a skill) or grabbing enemies works easier than using an extract.

Trailing is okay, not my thing and wish they happened less often and/or were shorter. Lockpicking and thumb turn bypass are okay, lockpicking is more fun too me, had to use my mouse for both since my controllers analogs have spasming problems and precision is tedious with that hardware debuff, still love my 5 year old DS4 controller tho.

Paradise VR, I really didn't like overall, as the only source of large amounts of Yen which in turns means SP later on, it was just boring counting to 6 over and over and luckily i got all skills before I needed to grind baseball multiple times for play passes, only had to grind 6 or so from the goliath home run challenge to get the final battle skill, still hopefully Lost Judgement is better when it comes to SP grinding, I'll find out soon.

The Story, I enjoyed it a lot, I always keep my expectations for stories low regardless of genre and game to keep me entertained, The story was engaging for me, had to use my brain trying to figure everything out answering questions with the current info I was given each chapter. I won't say much because spoilers but it's definitely worth playing just for the story, but beating ass and the side case dialogue are worth it also.

"Hey guys, what haven't we done better than Shenmue yet?"
"...Detective work?"
"Great idea! Let's make a whole game out of it!"

This is the best RGG game since Yakuza 0. It feels like all the best minds at RGG got together, listed out all the cool thing a past Yakuza game has done, and iterated on all of it in one game. 

Every element of this game feeds into other elements. The friend mechanic from Yakuza 2 is taken to its logical conclusion here. Friends help you out around town, give you discounts, and even lead you to additional friends with their own substories. Remember the "Murder at Cafe Alps" substory in Yakuza 3, where you had to link people, places, and information together to figure out what happened? This entire game is built around that idea. I've had several instances where I didn't know where to go, so I talked to someone I had met in a past substory or friend mission, and they actually gave me useful advice. This is a detective game that actively rewards my intuition. If you're somewhat familiar with Kamurocho, try playing with the minimap turned off. The game often gives you enough details to figure out where to go without the marker.

The core of the combat here is really good. Your moves usually have great impact, the animations are extremely fluid, and the heat actions are satisfying. Yagami's Crane style is the coolest thing since Majima's Slugger style in 0. The combat is more slow and deliberate than past titles. Your rush combo loops indefinitely, and every finisher has multiple parts. This encourages you to slow down and think about which attacks you're using, rather than spamming a full rush combo and whatever the last finisher is.

I do have several criticisms.

Context sensitive combat actions don't always work right. Wall jumps sometimes result in Yagami just flying off and attacking nothing. Flux fissures sometimes just don't trigger. This seems most common after an enemy is staggered, which is particularly annoying because that feels like the best opening for a flux fissure.

Mortal wounds just shouldn't exist. They only slow down the combat, waste your money, and waste your time running across town to get them fixed. Wall jumps are recommended to attack through them, which makes it doubly annoying when your wall jump just doesn't hit the enemy.

The English voice acting isn't great. One, a lot of the background and combat voices are still in Japanese. Two, some of the casting choices are questionable, most notably Yagami himself. Yagami's Japanese voice is husky and tired sounding, which fits his character. His English voice is the most generic white dude imaginable. Three, when the casting choice is good (like with Nanami), the direction isn't great. Scenes that should be full of emotion come off as awkward and stilted. I wouldn't normally even mention the voice acting, but English is enabled by default in this game (unlike previous titles, where it wasn't even an option).

All that said, the only thing stopping this from being my favorite game in the franchise is the combat being a little sloppy in places. This game is incredible, and if you've enjoyed any other Yakuza game, you need to try this one.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Great port, runs smooth
+ Great graphics
+ Likeable cast
+ Great story
+ Drone racing is fun

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
+/- Some side stories are good, but a lot of them feel quite repetitive and forgettable
+/- Cool fighting styles, but one of them is superior than the other in virtually every aspect
+/- Yagami is cool, but unfortunately less interesting than the characters of other games
+/- There's very little challenge, both with combat and the investigation aspects

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Mortal wounds forces you to carry special medkits and make regular trips to a clinic
- Detective/investigation aspect is quite... uninspired
- A completely pointless mechanics in the form of a keychain, where you have to memories which keys to use on which doors
- A really annoying mechanic that mass spawns enemies in an event that frequently recurs
- Combat is a little dull compared to its Dragon Engine cousin YK2. You use pretty much the same attack combinations most of the game.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

judgment is a game that you play a lawyer that gets his name smeared, due to a case he won and was believed  he had made the wrong decision by the public's eye, only to find a month later a tragedy happened that made him doubt everything he believed in.
Queue 20 years later as you find the protagonist working as a detective solving small cases for rent, but soon finds his past scars to come back to the surface...

That's about all i feel comfortable to say about the story.

Gameplay wise if you've played yakuza well welcome home as it's based on the lovely dragon engine where you play in a action street brawl/ detective work solving crimes with RPG elements, but with the characters flair in the mix.
The action part as you play the protagonist Yagami, will feel it's much more fast paced compare to past installment as Yagami is a small framed character and uses speed over brawn making it refreshing after so many installments playing Kiryu bulky power style, it's no where near a bad thing, but it's night and day with the style difference.

You'll use what you have at your disposal to dispatch the enemies coming at you, whether it be hand to hand marshal arts, to batons and tonfas, even a bicycle and street signs.
As you win brawls you'll earn money and experience to buy new skills.
As for the puzzle segments you'll embody the character solving mysteries, by following targets, gathering clues and piecing what happened.

Ontop of that in Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio fashion they littered the game in mini games.

The first Yakuza-related game I've actively disliked unfortunately. I'm starting to think that Yakuza 0 may have been a fluke in an otherwise mediocre series. While the other mainline Yakuza titles have been carried by brilliant characters like Kiryu and Majima, Yagami and Kaito are as forgettable as the 4th protagonist in Yakuza 4. 

This has not been helped by the fact that the switch to the Dragon Engine has come with a noticable downgrade in cutscene quality. Just like LaD, this game is padded with ugly automated cutscenes, with all of the budget seemingly saved for the (admittedly amazing) finale.

This is also the first Yakuza game I've played where I've barely touched any of the side content, a blasphemy for any Yakuza playthrough. Perhaps this is because I simply wished for the mediocre story mode to end as soon as possible or maybe I'm just tired of the formula, but it did feel like there was a general lack of minigames outside of the abysmal VR and Drone flying which I dropped after the tutorial.

RGG studio is gradually running out of Yakuza 0 goodwill for me, but here's hoping that the upcoming Lad8 and Kiryu prologue are good.

after playing through every yakuza game, some of them more than once, this game is such a breath of fresh air. resetting everything about the characters while keeping the world intact is so refreshing to see, as it helps us see the light of kamurocho from a much grittier light, a civilian rather than a yakuza. the story is as compelling as it is entertaining, and there are no loose ends left in this story.

in the world of detectives, very rarely is there a case of black and white.

It's great fun, has decent graphics and there's lots to do. My only gripe is that we're in Kamurocho... once again... RGG Studios should have added some new locations, or expanded Kamurocho a bit at least. It's basically Yakuza: Detective Edition, but that's cool if you know what you're getting into. Don't expect Sherlock Holmes: Crimes and Punishments level detective work/gameplay though, it's a bit more half-baked than that - you basically get spoon fed the answers. 

On a more positive note, the combat is excellent - animations are top-notch. Main quest is awesome, Yagami is a great protagonist and I have loved every minute of the story so far (even if the writing is a little rough around the edges at time). Side quests are fun and (mostly) well written.

Overall, I recommend the game to Yakuza fans who want a decent spin-off with good combat and decent story. 7/10

Judgement story wise is as incredible as you can expect from the Yakuza series. Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio doesnt miss. This may be one of my favorites and possibly my favorite story in all the Yakuza Franchize. Its incredible. Some of the greatest characters and antagonists in this surrounding corrupt people, the corrupt medical field, and much more. I do feel certain parts dragged and in certain moments side missions were forced into the story. Beyond that, those are my only complaints story wise. 

So now for me to be slightly unfair but to say something for the rest of the game.

Combat is what you'd expect for a Yakuza game with two stances, and a whole new fighting style of course. However, one thing felt strange and clunky. One Tak often wont lock on to enemies worth a shit which can be very frustrating. Two, as much as I love the new wall attack stuff (run up to a wall, spring board off for a devestating attack) I found it not that often to be used, and also made dodging awkward because you have to hold R1 to dodge. I felt this kinda made it awkward. A little one trick pony move that dont get me wrong has many options from grab to heavy and options out of it, I still felt didnt add to much and made that whole thing awkward.

Mini games are lacking I found. (which is big for a Yakuza game, Id especially say in repeatability)  There is a dice roll type VR thing I did not find to be that great. Theres, the usually Mahjong and Like a Dragon like gambling, and drone racing. The drone racing is like an ariel go kart from Like a Dragon. The other parts of this game do feel like reuses of Yakuza 6, as well as parts that have just better versions in Like A Dragon.

To finish this off my only big complaints I can attack this game on. stalking missions (which there are far too many of and its boring as hell) and investigation sections. My feeling towards the investigation sections are eh. Not a big deal honestly. They often were kinda interesting, but other wise frustrating and led to a few moments where I searched it up because sometimes what they expect you to do is ridiculous and without much intuition or direction. This will lead to you running around the room trying to find your little clue, which can time to time feel like a needle in a hay stack. Then theres the stalking missions, that there are far too many of. They are very crap missions where you follow someone without being spotted, going space to space to hide behind cover. They are boring, and sometimes straight up frustrating. They at times made me feel like it was a chore to get back to enjoying the game. The Investigation sections also sometimes had that effect too. 

Oh, and the "parkour." Yagami is very nimble and does a bit of stunts you see. Hes quite fast and can climb over things. This add a few additions in the map of construction areas allowing you to climb over them and run between them. It also allowed you to jump up on cars which also have there own little interaction take downs and such which I thought was nice. It was seemingly weird though and not a big deal to add these areas. I feel it kinda took away from parts of the map and was pointless. Also, theres smoking now, but its kinda useless. As is also eating and many other things now. It just kinda add to your health? I found it nice in Kiwami 2 that it seemingly almost made me want to eat at every location because it gives me skill points. Which speaking of skill points... [b] (yes I know this is turning into a tangent paragraph bare with me) [/b] there isnt much variety here. it just a points system of stars. You open your phone and do a pretty linear upgrade tree. I was not that impressed with its skills either. It was a major downgrade from past games. I think it was even a major downgrade from Yakuza 6, but I cant recall certain parts of it well.

Overall, Judgement is an incredible and amazing game. (imagine that, Ryu Ga Gotoku only makes amazing games? noooo)
However, outside its incredible story adventure, feels like a downer in the series. This is me being a bit harsh because, well for Yakuza game standards its a step down and backwards in many directions. (let me mind you this being a spin off that came out after 6) IT FEELS LIKE IT WAS A SIDE PROJECT. Which I wouldnt be suprised if it was, and well idk if its because its just now coming out on steam and its older now, but it does hold a smaller price tag. This is irrelevant to the verdict however, and I am in no way saying this game is bad whatsoever, its just the opposite of the peak of the series in many areas and kinda feels like a small little spin off that did absolutely incredible in every other area that which being its story and a lot of its missions.


GANG WARS ARE SHIT AND ANNOYING. Basically optional areas of purple show up and these annoying gangs want to always fight you. It feels like a shitty version of MR. BIG BUCKS or whatever their names were in the Kiwami's. Also, a turf war happens chapter to chapter basically. An old guy will annoyingly call you over and over again for help. This is the Yakuza of Fallout 4's "Another Settlement needs your help." I do NOT CARE. O.O

9/10 - Better than Yakuza 4 & 6? Yes. That makes this the bottom of my favories, it also has like one of the best stories in the whole series.

BUY IT NOW. I am being extremely hard on it for the sake of Yakuza franchise standards.

Having played most of the Yakuza / Like a Dragon series games and enjoying them "enough", I can say that Judgment is probably the first "action-style" LAD game that I found myself wanting to play again.

If you liked the Kiryu saga of LAD, the gameplay here is similar... But it's so refreshing to see the gang wars move a bit to the side and experience a story that's a different side of Kamurocho. I find Yagami relatable as a protagonist, and Yagami and Kaito together as a likable "buddy cop" duo.

And the gameplay changes from Kiryu's LAD are welcome, with interesting detective sections including chases, searches, and tailing.

Some frustrations include the lack of good healing items, broken encounter rates, and the occasional too long fight sequence. The Keihin Gang content is probably the most annoying in the game and I sometimes found myself just running from every encounter because it got boring.

I bought it at full-price as soon as it launched on Steam, and I don't regret it. I won't be playing Lost Judgment right away, but I'm looking forward to it.

Judgement is a mixed bag for me. I like a lot of what it does, but it has a few big issues that stop it from being one of my favourite RGG titles.

For the good: The story is fantastic once it gets going. It's a nice mystery story with some amazing moments near the end. However, there is A LOT of filler. The main story is stuffed with cutscenes where our main cast sits down and sloooooowly discusses what you just heard from a different character, and the first half of the game is so slow with very little progression towards the actual mystery. The finale is one of the best in the series, but the lead up to it is painful.

The gameplay is great. It may have taken a few games but RGG finally figured out how to make combat on the Dragon Engine work. The only negative is the annoying "mortal wounds" system. Basically, if you take a hit or get shot, you get a chunk of your health bar permanently removed until you use a med kit or see a doctor. It's not a big deal, but it still adds more running around you have to do.

The only other bad thing I can say is that the encounter rate is WAY TOO HIGH. The game has a system where everyone once in a while, the city will be put on "high alert" and encounter rates will triple until you beat a few bosses. It was fun at first but as the hours dragged on it got very annoying very quickly, and there's no way to disable it.

Overall, if you liked the Yakuza series, you'll probably like this one too. It's got the same style and presentation, just with a more mature story.

Furthermore 'SP', the currency used to upgrade and acquire skills, gets a bit difficult to acquire later in the game which can lead to some frustration.

Still, the game's plenty of fun, there's lots to see and do.  There's a couple of rather creepy parts where you play as someone not Yagami, but on some level I feel like making the player feel a little creeped out was part of the point.  Overall, a very good action RPG.

By this point the RyÅ« ga Gotoku franchise, formerly known internationally as Yakuza and from now on Like a Dragon, is extremely popular everywhere. Weâ€™ve come from having some spin-off titles having no international release and main titles in the franchise having the international release delayed by years, to getting almost day one releases worldwide and future announcements that get so many people excited it wouldâ€™ve been hard to believe this just a few years ago.

Judgment is the first game that is set in the same shared world as the rest of the Like a Dragon titles that has absolutely no â€œLike a Dragonâ€ in its title. It was originally released on PS4 in 2018, has gotten an enhanced Remaster on current gen systems juts last year and now is finally available on PC, released the same day as its sequel Lost Judgement. And I have to be honest, even though I like these series in general, I truly loved only 2 Like a Dragon games so far and unfortunately, being extremely long titles, I did get somewhat tired of them last year when I finally wrapped things up with the PC port of Yakuza 6. Even though Iâ€™ve heard great things about Judgment, I was still afraid that it will tire me out. Instead, it has become the third game in the franchise that I consider exceptional.

At its core, Judgment is a typical Like a Dragon game (apart from, you know, when it plays as a jRPG) â€“ itâ€™s a story-driven action adventure set in an open world that isnâ€™t particularly large, but dense with details and stories. The combat is still somewhat jRPG-ish in how it happens, as during normal city roaming enemies just get randomly spawned to walk around and if they catch up with you, you enter combat that controls differently and the only ways to end this are to lose, win or try to escape. Combat itself remains, as it is in most titles, very beat â€™em up/fighting game like, with combos, usage of weapons you find lying on the floor, visible health bars, special attacks and all of that stuff. Bosses that have more health and special abilities of their own are, of course, also still here and the big new addition for this whole system is that sometimes they can give you â€œpermanentâ€ damage, that cannot be healed normally.

But despite the lack of big changes in the basics, thereâ€™s a lot of new ideas and approaches in Judgment to the point, where it feels unlike a Like a Dragon title. Sure, one of the fighting styles private detective Yagami (the main character) uses is reminiscent of the feet-heavy style Shun â€œBest character in the seriesâ€ Akiyama has, but playing is Yagami is anything but playing like Akiyama. Being a detective, a lot of tasks Yagami-san has to accomplish required a new set of mechanics and Judgment does most of them well. You occasionally get to tail people, hiding behind corners and blending with people. You get access to two lockpicking minigames, one of which is really fun and the other is a big miss. The chase sequences return, being really well done this time around and a far cry from when they first appeared in the franchise and were terrible. You get to investigate scenes in first person mode, sometimes while using a drone for more advantageous perspective, and a lot of these are fun. Thereâ€™s a disguise system that is criminally underutilized despite being really cool. And during some scenes and dialogues you get to perform some simple clue compiling and getting to the conclusion in the most efficient way possible.

And the tone of the story and all of the side-stories is also expectedly fitting a detective tale, not aâ€¦ whatever situation Kiryu, Majima or Ichiban often get into. What I especially loved was how a lot of these stories are now evolved to not just tell a nice story with memorable characters, but many of them often get a continuation or connection to other stories, creating the illusion of a real community in Kamurocho (the setting of the entire game, returning from previous titles). Thereâ€™s even a really amazingly cool little epilogue story that happens when youâ€™ve made all possible friends and helped people with lots of cases. And the â€œgirlfriendâ€ concept here too is finally feeling more like an interaction with a proper character, than just a mechanic for stats, with all available â€œgirlfriendsâ€ getting genuinely interesting stories that you follow.

That said, it still feels veryâ€¦ â€œgirl is a prizeâ€-ish and essentially stops any and all character nuance once youâ€™ve succeeded and you canâ€™t â€œjust be friendsâ€ either. I wouldnâ€™t have noticed or even cared if it wasnâ€™t so far into becoming a genuinely great element of the story, instead of just a slightly more advanced and well written mechanic. Sadly, the aforementioned Friends and the rewarding epilogue story require you to grind a lot of stuff you might not be interested in. I mean â€“ why do you need to play lots of poker to get a really wholesome side-story? Why lock it behind so much stuff most people will not enjoy?

So yeah, Judgment isnâ€™t entirely free of the usual faults of the Like a Dragon title. Fights do get more annoying than fun or challenging as the story goes on. Some systems and ideas become more convoluted for no reason, despite starting with a perfect balance of complexity. And the story isnâ€™t free of occasional overtly dramatic moments that donâ€™t really add anything to the storytelling.

Yet. And yet. I couldnâ€™t help but feel that Judgment might be the most â€œnew player friendlyâ€ title in the franchise and, overall, the mostâ€¦ wellâ€¦ FUN. Thereâ€™s no prerequisite story or world knowledge required, even if knowing the world of Like a Dragon adds to it. The combat system is very easy to understand and the skill system is very streamlined without too much extra stuff. We only get Kamurocho, which remains perfect as far as the size goes, so by the end of the game you will most likely understand where the street you need is without looking at a map or a goal pointer. And it hits all of the best story points you expect from a Like a Dragon title and a collection of really good characters. Personally, Iâ€™ve enjoyed this cast far more than that of Yakuza: Like a Dragon (now probably to be known as Like a Dragon 7: Like a Dragon?..) and Yagami-san is easily one of the best protagonists in the franchise so far.

So, if you havenâ€™t played a single Like a Dragon game before, Iâ€™d say â€“ Judgment is the ideal starting point. I used to say Yakuza 0 or Yakuza 4 and I still consider those titles to be the other 2 best games in the series, but Judgment is just so much better as a jump off point for any series newcomer. And if you have played the series beforeâ€¦ Well, if you like it, youâ€™ve probably played Judgment already and know how great it is. And if you donâ€™t â€“ give Judgment a try as it might be the one that gets you hooked. PC port is fantastic, so now thereâ€™s no reason to not get this game anymore.

These developers never cease to amaze! I'm always blown away by how incredible these games look, and the fights in game are as impressive as ever. Not to mention the boss fights and cutscenes, some of them are so intense and well choreographed that I feel like I'm actually enjoying a movie. Extremely immersive storyline, characters you can really get behind and actually care about, and it's set in an environment that I already know and love, so it feels like I'm right at home. The humor in this game absolutely hits a home run, too. I can't help but laugh at some of the ridiculous things that these developers come up with for side quests.

To be honest, I wasn't sure how I'd feel playing a completely new protagonist in Yagami, as I've been so attached to the Yakuza series for a long time now, and getting to experience this world through Kiryu throughout the last few years, I was worried that I might feel a little biased in that regard, and possibly not enjoy this game as much due to this. I'm happy to say that I was wrong. Yagami shows so much character and personality, and to see how strong of a bond he shares with those around him, as well as how he chooses to bear the weight of responsibility of his past, was extremely moving at the most critical moments, to say the least. This is such a fresh experience, and easily is able to stand on its own as a standalone series. 

I only have a couple of gripes about the game in general, but they're nothing that ever discouraged me from wanting to play the game. First off, though I'll say the vast majority of the detective aspect of this game was super fun and appealing, the tailing missions are a little bit...awkward. In the sense that maybe it could have been designed slightly differently as far as being punished when an NPC realizes that you're tailing them. You can in most instances, literally run up to someone, they'll notice you and start watching you nonstop, until you find a hiding spot. As long as you find a hiding spot, it didn't matter how close you were to the person, if you were running at them or not, everything would be OK. They'll say something like "Must've just been my imagination...", and eventually be on their merry way, and the tracking bar eventually goes back down to zero like nothing ever happened. It was always just a little too easy to get through these, is all. I still enjoyed the experience, as it's something that was entirely new, but it was a little bit awkwardly executed, I feel.

My other gripe is how often a certain group of people come to Kamurocho, and how often a certain someone texts you to let you know, "Oh, they're here! It's awful!" "We need you to stop them!", so on and so forth. Didn't matter how many times you took care of these guys, this stuff here is the only thing that got particularly annoying and repetitive, and I wish it would have been approached slightly differently. Maybe eventually this stops? I'm not sure because as of the point that I finished the main story (the time of writing this review), I haven't done all side quests, etc, so I can't be for certain. I guess more than anything being texted by the same individual over and over for the exact same thing while doing other quests and such was a bit frustrating, particularly when I was going through the main story, as it always felt quite distracting at those times.

All in all, I have to say that if you enjoy the Yakuza series/world in general, and are eyeing this series as a possible purchase, absolutely do so. It's strong enough to easily hold on its own, and I'm looking forward to enjoying more from the Judgment series in the future. Speaking of...about to get into Lost Judgment today, absolutely can't wait.

tl;dr i would hold off on buying this until some more performance patches are released. slowdowns, lockups, and crashes occur quite often and i don't think the game is good enough to make up for that. wait about a month or so and then buy. you could also get the game on sale if that occurs beforehand.

PREFACE:

At the time of writing this game has only been updated once. As the TL;DR indicates the technical complaints may go away in the future (hopefully) but as it stands right now this is my assessment.

TECHNICAL:

Out of all the video games I have ever played this one has had the most frequent technical problems. Every time a new area loads the game locks up for a while, sometimes a minute, and sometimes a "not responding" prompt from Windows even pops up. Very rarely the game shows mercy and instead lets the framerate drop. The game has crashed many times while loading new areas and there were two cases where a save file corrupted and caused an infinite loading screen. I believe my PC is good, and it was able to run Yakuza: Like a Dragon, which features a considerably larger map, with no real issues compared to this. The Drone Racing minigame goes to a black screen very often for some reason.

GRAPHICS/SOUND:

The graphics aim for realism and do it well. I'm pretty sure that most of the people in this game are modeled after real people. I don't think the soundtrack has as many memorable songs as some of the past games though. Overall there is nothing to think too hard about let alone complain.

COMBAT:

The combat is in general okay but a bit weird at times. Wall jumps can lead into attacks but these often cause the player to rocket off in a random direction and getting the aim right requires more finesse than should be needed for a game in which combat takes place primarily on narrow streets and indoors. The criteria for a wall jump is also inconsistent. Sometimes running at a wall does nothing and sometimes you can initiate a wall jump while standing still. 

There are two styles in this game, somewhat of a return to form to 0 and Kiwami's style. Unlike in those games there are only two styles. There is the good style and the other style. The good style is called Tiger. It's the good style because it is faster, does more damage, and has unlockable perks unique to it, whereas the other style doesn't. The other style, Crane, is slow and if a hit is blocked, it stuns you for a second. The only reason to use Crane is to break up a crowd of enemies so you can switch to Tiger and start the real beatdown. I feel like the developers gave more love to Tiger than Crane which is quite sad because a crowd-control style was done quite well with 0's Breaker.

Thankfully, the Tiger Drop is shared by both styles.

Something I don't like is how items are distributed. There is only one variant of the healing drinks (e.g. there is Staminan X but no Staminan Spark) and you can only carry a maximum of six which seems like a bit of an unneeded restriction. There are medical kits that heal a lot of HP but only one guy sells them and it's very inconvenient to have to go to him for this basically essential set of items.

Medical kits also are important because some attacks leave "mortal wounds" that decrease max HP, and the kits bring it back to normal. The idea of enemies that could semi-permanently decrease max HP was cool when bosses and a few enemies with guns could do it, but it became very annoying once these gun-toters started showing up on the street because, again, only one guy in the whole map sells medical kits.

The last thing is Extracts. They're potions that cause various effects like making you fight better or reducing the number of enemies on the map. They're interesting as an idea but I didn't use them too often.

EXPLORATION AND SIDE CONTENT:

You are limited to Kamurocho in this game. You will not be going to Sotenbori, Onomichi, or any other district within urban Japan. That's fine because I don't think the plot gives any opportunities for that, and I don't know if this game could handle multiple cities with its technical performance. You have the typical minigames like batting, mahjong, and the arcade games, with some new additions like a rail shooter and a VR fight zone. This is the Dragon Engine, though, so no fishing. 

There's a special important minigame called the Drone Race. You collect materials and buy parts for it and it's a big part of the side content. It's ultimately not too interesting however, because all you do is steer the drone around a route within Kamurocho and hit booster pads. It's not very involved and half of the tracks are literally the other half but backwards and with some changes to the booster pads.

Another thing that returns from 0 is friends you meet on the street. The benefits are a bit more tangible here, since your friends grant you access to rare items, new Heat (or rather, EX) Actions, and even come to your aid to fight on the streets, which is a real improvement. There are a few people you can romance as well, but unfortunately love has no gameplay benefits.

The system for substories is slightly revamped in that the majority of them are found by going up to someone who pulls up a list of substories for you to pick, similar to how you unlock a sidequest in the Witcher. It's a bit annoying because you will frequently check these rather than encountering the substories organically on the street (which still happens but at a greatly reduced rate).

The piece of side stuff I really don't like is the Keihin Gang. Every now and again you get a text message alerting you that the Gang is coming and then the enemy encounter rate quintuples until you find and defeat a bunch of street bosses who are all really far from each other or until you wait 20 minutes or so. There is no way to stop it and it gets very very annoying after the third or so time. It's like a bad version of the Powerful Foes from 6. At least the Powerful Foes only showed up one at a time.

PLOT:

The storyline follows a model set by some of the later Yakuza games, working with the ideas of vast conspiratorial webs incorporating politics, organized crime, and things that on the surface have nothing to do with either. 

The difference here is that instead of seeing this through the lens of the criminal underworld itself you are a law-abiding (for the most part) detective, and hence this is more like a noir film than a crime drama. There is convolution but not a lot of it. It's interesting to see how the style of the previous games fits into this new skin and I enjoyed some of the hardboiled detective flairs they added. They even have an opening monologue ruminating about the city and its crime and all that. I enjoy it a lot and it gets real weighty at times but not soul-crushing, a balance Yakuza is good at striking.

Despite the stylistic similarities and a shared universe, you do not need to play any previous Yakuza/RGG game to follow the plot, and the game does not have spoilers for such.

It is without a doubt, a Yakuza game with a different character.

There's a few extra mini games (from the Sega stores).
Sub Stories and Main story are now called 'Cases' which isn't much. There's a lot of detective work you need to do. Sometimes the game hands you the hints on the map, sometimes you have to work it out based on what you know of Kamurocho. But at the end of the day, you're back in Kamurocho which hasn't changed all that much.

You make friends now, with their own little quirks and requirements. Eat at this store X times. Introduce this character to another side character you meet (by making friends).

Its fun. It's Yakuza. The combat feels a little, floaty? Delayed? I'm not sure how to state what it feels like. You will do a 2x combo of light attack, see the enemy ignore your attacks and throw a punch. You try to guard and it's delayed. 7 out of 10 times I will take damage from the first swing. Dodging also feels delayed. I will dodge during and attack and Yagami will either not dodge far enough, or the enemy will track your movement and hit you anyway. But it is still quite fun.

Leveling up skills is now done via SP (skill points I think?). Eat a plate of food from a store, get ##SP per plate. Use that to level up the normal kind of stuff. Battle prowess, general 'life' skills or mini game skills (like drone flying or lock picking etc).

If you liked Yakuza for the gameplay and quirky story/theatrics then I reckon you'll like Judgement. If you liked Yakuza for Kiryu as a character, I don't reckon you'll like Yagami too much. If we use Kiryu and Ichiban as a scale. Kiryu being a solid 10 in seriousness and Ichiban being a 1. Yagami is dead in the middle at 5. 

But its Yakuza. Its Kamurocho. Its all the normal shenanigans that we're familiar with and then some. Get it.
