I have fairly mixed feelings on this game. On one hand, it's one of the best stories RGG has put out to-date - it's not quite as emotionally heavy as Yakuza 0 or 7, but Judgement makes up for it by having overall excellent story structure and delivering extremely well on the crime investigation aspects. If you're a fan of Ace Attorney or the times the Yakuza games get into that territory, you'll be right at home.

On the other hand, I'm conflicted on the side content. The game reintroduces the Friend System, where you do things for people around town to increase your rep. In the Yakuza games that used it, you could befriend shopkeepers and they'd give you access to a special attack while you're fighting near their shop, like stuffing a goon's mouth full of spicy chicken. Judgement expands on that by adding more possible outcomes, such as additional locations and facilities for you to use, as well as people that'll roam the city and help you out in fights directly. This is a genuinely good expansion on the friend system, which is more than I can say for the other additions.

The sidequest quality is just below 0, 7 and Kiwami 2. Good, but not great. My absolute biggest gripe is with the minigames; hardly any new additions, tons of removals (THERE'S NO KARAOKE) and one of the new additions is both the most-frequently-required minigame as well as one of the worst minigames RGG has ever put out. The tailing minigame gets old extremely quickly and I genuinely hope this game gets a mod that lets you skip it. It's an incredibly low-stakes stealth minigame that is far too forgiving and does nothing but slow the game down. There's also a Mario Party-ish board game minigame that becomes your primary source of money and EXP once you're done with the game, but I largely ignored it and I haven't gotten around to the meat of it. At a glance it's alright.

The combat isn't perfect, but it's still pretty damn good. Unlike previous titles using the Dragon Engine, you've actually got multiple fighting styles - Crane, which is for dealing with crowds, and Tiger, which is for single-target fights and small groups. They both feel great once you expand their movesets a bit, but there's a very noticeable lack of upgrades specialized for the Crane style. Most upgrades augment both styles and behave differently depending on which one you're using, but Tiger has a bunch of upgrades that drastically alter what it can do. Eventually you'll be spending all but a few fights entirely in Tiger style, it just becomes that much better. Tiger style alone still plays better than Kiryu's Dragon style in Yakuza Kiwami 2 and 6 though, the focus on agility feels great.

Overall the game's excellent with some fairly large holes in it.

Edit: It's worth mentioning that every single issue this game has is fixed in its sequel, Lost Judgement; fighting styles are more distinct and have a large amount of upgrades for each, the tailing minigame has gotten a massive overhaul, the sidequests are mostly-excellent and there's far more minigame variety.

I'm not sure why people like these types of games (Haven't played the Yakuza series, but they look very similar.) so much. They aren't games so much as cheesy soap-opera episodes sprinkled with dull mini games to give the illusion of playing a game. A great example of these illusory tactics is the map. The map is so tiny the game shouldn't even really have one and would be better off as a linear series of events for purposes of story progression. One can  easily run the map end to end in roughly 2 minutes of real time. The map is so small it just becomes an annoyance. There is nothing to discover or explore its so small, so why make the player run back and forth across the same boring and constricted landscape? To make the game feel deeper and larger than it really is, that's why. Its like going camping in your backyard... No fucking point unless your backyard is more than 20 acres of wilderness.

The difficulty level is also a joke. I play on the hardest difficulty and still barely even need to heal myself after battles. These "fights" or "battles" consist of picking up whatever trash or object is around to bash your enemies, and mashing out meaningless spam combos that don't require any real timing or execution. The other "mini games" are just glorified quick time events, chances to spot the difference between things, or requests to find waldo yet again.

The games strong point is style. If you like the certain style and dynamism that only Japanese media can deliver than you might find these titles palatable. Lots of meaningful stares and shouted proclamations amidst crazy action scenes and acrobatics. However, that's about it from the strength category.

I'm going to try and finish the game just to see how the story ends, but could easily see myself getting bored before that happens. Over all, an expensive and disappointing experience that parades itself as something much more satisfying.

I'm a big fan of RGG Studios and their games, the Yakuza franchise. So this review will be very biased and may change when the post-nut clarity kicks in. But what I'm feeling right now, this is one of the top best video games RGG Studios have ever created. The usual things RGG excels at, great open world, great combat, great content, great soundtrack, and great visuals. My only gripe is only on the main plot but thats only purely focusing on the story. The overall story in a wider context is just great and one of the best I had. These are all the qualities RGG Studios had in all of their games.

You play as Takayuki Yagami, a detective and ex-lawyer, searching for the truth about the serial killings that are happening in Kamurocho. Throughout investigating you'll find interesting reveals. The story and mystery is fun to see unfold. This game is very cutscene heavy but have masterful direction and cinematography, so better bring some popcorn. I have my gripes but I'll get to the downsides. Characters aiding Yagami are Kaito. an ex-yakuza and partner, Mafuyu, Saori, Hoshino, and more that are just very lovable and likable even to a fault, Reaching to the end of the story, I found myself wanting more from these cast of characters and to be frank quite dissapointed I didn't get to know MORE about all of them, which says a lot. The main character, Takayuki Yagami is also kinda cool. Didn't get alot of development but is servicable. The sequels will probably explore more on his character.

Combat in this game is fluid af. Unlike past games where you control a brute hitting people like a truck, Takayuki Yagami is fast and have these kung fu moves. You have to styles you can change to which each have different movesets and specials which is the Tiger Style and Crane Style. Tiger Style is more suitable for one-on-one situations meanwhile Crane Style is more for crowd control with large sweeps and kicks. The moves you can do are breathtaking to look at and some will trigger these special cutscenes, typical Yakuza fashioned brutality.  Other than fighting, you explore the district of Kamurocho filled with adult nightlife. In typical Yakuza fashion, there lots of fun sidequests, or in this game sidecases to experience, minigames, and more. Side content in this game are more like the second campaign you can do either after or alongside the main story which is the serial killings. You can make friends (finally) to level up your reputation which in turn will give you more access to more sidecases. The sidecontent in this game is one of the best I had in any video games.

Although this is a detective game, this game is not another Ace Attorney or LA Noire game that really tests your cognitive abilities and more of a crime drama the series is known from. So sometimes moments in the story will not pickup by the characters the sameway it is for the player. On to the downsides, but this is more from a personal note, the story is kidna dumbed down like the main character not knowing a crucial information and meanwhile the player, which is I, know that information. So the moment of reveal when the character finally know that said information is kinda.... meh. But thats just my personal experience.

The soundtrack is okay. I do have one that is in my playlist but other than that, it is all good. Being a standalone franchise branching from the Yakuza game, there is no need to know about past games since nothing from the past is here except the setting. Also while comparing this game and the past, I am more of a fan of sad, emotional moments from the past games, which is not present here since the main story is more focused on solving crimes, law, justice, good and bad. That's why I don't have any strong emotional connection to this game, but that's just my personal taste. 

Overall, a great game that is probably going to be overlooked.

About 15 hours into Judgment and I am getting more or less exactly what I expected: A lot of fun! 
In the world of Yakuza, we take the role of Detective Yagami, a move that really freshens up the original action/rpg/comedy formula. His fighting styles are a bit more elegant perhaps, but of course no less comically brutal than Kazuma's. So far the main story has been good enough with several interesting new characters on display. Kamurocho is as usual packed with things to do besides following the main story missions. Side-missions have become Side-cases, still very much reminiscent of the former, bound to make you laugh at some points. There are the usual arcades, the batting center, dozens of restaurants, stores and bars, the new drone races - one of the more major mini-game additions - and more. The Tokyo-neighbourhood has really come a long way over the years and now I even enjoy just walking around in-game looking at the density of neon-signs and possibilities. I don't really know what else to say besides that the hours will keep ticking up, for weeks if not months ahead, while I keep enjoying Judgment. Great game to give a go if you want to see what Sega studio Ryu ga Gotoku's games are all about as it starts from a new beginning story-wise. As a longtime Sega-fan, I knew I would get this immediately if it was ever ported to PC though, so my grade is:

5/5 - Another love letter to the fun of video games, thanks Sega&RGG for bringing it to PC finally!

[h1][u] Judgment: Darker Than Dark [/u][/h1]

Judgment is an AJRPG - Action Japanese Role Playing Game (with adventure elements) that is set in the same universe of Ryu Ga Gotoku / Like A Dragon / Yakuza, but as a spinoff and is NOT part of the mainline series. It was first released in 2018 for consoles, and very recently in 2022 for PCs. It is developed by RGG studio, also responsible for all the other RGG games, and published by SEGA.

[b][u] Graphics, Environment Design [/u][/b]

Judgment is developed on an updated variant of Dragon Engine (same as Kiwami 2 and 6) and as such, looks absolutely phenomenal when compared to the previous engines used in older games pre-Kiwami 1. The absolutely stunning graphical and technical capability of the engine exacts a substantial toll on GFX cards, however the existence of FSR 1.0 and 2.0 for PC version means it is easier to run across a wider range of hardware, weak to strong.

Judgment's environment is primarily the one and beloved Kamurocho - a very well-done, true to life recreation of Kabukichou, with a few other select locations for purposes of progressing the story. While daytime isn't making an absolutely strong impact, nighttime Judgment's Kamurocho has a different...vibe to it that Yakuza 6 and Kiwami 2 and even LAD does not possess at all, driving home its uniqueness relative to the mainline entries.

[b][u] Story, Character(isation too) [/u][/b]

Judgment follows the tale of freelance detective Takayuki Yagami as he tries to uncover the truth behind a series of murders in Kamurocho that is deeply entrenched in a massive web of conspiracy that could shake the nation of Japan to its core. Without spoiling the story whatsoever, Judgment fulfils the interactive part of a detective thriller show as well as the protagonist self-insert in the form of Yagami, where players follow his story and footsteps; and it does so VERY WELL.

Even though it is only just one game that this review is talking, and that it is just a spinoff, RGG has managed to create a highly compelling cast of characters, not just Yagami, drawing from both camps supporting and fighting against the protagonist, in true RGG fashion.

[b][u] General gameplay [/u][/b]

Judgment's primary gameplay is the same as the Yakuza main entries - kicking and punching the shit out of people, with extreme style and violence. Specifically, it blends the critically well-received multiple style mechanics of Yakuza 0 / Kiwami 1 with the general gameplay / physics  of the Dragon Engine. As a result, the protagonist Yagami can make use of two different styles, Crane and Tiger.

The addition of lethal enemy attacks that reduces max hp until rectified by a doctor or medical kit, as well as wall jump attacks and even mobile attacks around the enemy adds a lot of both novelty and fresh air to a potentially stale combat system. The usage of charged attacks (light and heavy) is reminiscent of older games (Kiwami 1 in recent memory) discourages button mashing same combos over and over.

The general difficulty is also higher as well, with HARD difficulty being potentially comparable to other game's LEGEND mode. This may shoo some away, for it may catch them by surprise unpleasantly, or woo some for the added challenge. Personally, although RGG games aren't known for being intentionally difficult on the same level as Dark Souls, I welcome this change. There is no shame for playing on easier difficulties either since this is the case.

[b][u] Soundtrack [/u][/b]

There is not a lot to say about the soundtrack of Judgment (same for other RGG games because I'm not well-versed with music theory unfortunately) other than that it is about on par for the course relative to RGG's main entries (in my personal opinion). Most tracks have a more gentle, chill sounds as opposed to the more wild, rocky vibes from Kiwami 2, for example. If I were to quantify the strength of an impression that it left on me, I would say its just about equals Kiwami 1 and 2 - I remember roughly the same amount of tracks across all three titles.

Can't take it for granted though so RGG deserves praises for putting out an excellent output with quality consistency equalling other RGG games.

[b][u] Personal nitpicks and final verdict [/u][/b]
I personally dislike that:

1. You CANNOT buy sodas and drinks from vending machines - you can in other Dragon Engine games.

2. There is no karaoke (minor nitpick because it is seemingly justified - the actor for Yagami is supposedly very costly to hire for SEGA)

3. The Keihin gang attacks are a bit annoying - or rather, it is an ineffective replacement for perpetual SP / exp combat farm.

4. The tailing missions are a bit one-note and not very dynamic. It would have been nicer if tailing missions allowed taking cover at almost any location rather than blue-marked spots and/or encouraged the usage of drones. AI taking a round path around a block seems like its emulating a real life person checking to see if they've been followed, but its just a time-sink in a video game. We ought to have a balance between realism and fun for games always.

All those things aside, virtually every other aspects of Judgment is very well done, and makes for a very compelling experience that leaves you wanting to power through it (at least in my case). If I were to rate this with game considering all pros and cons, as a RGG fan, then I'd say that Judgment is a [b]STRONG 8/10[/b].

I liked RGG studio enough that I bought it full price without discount. A 8/10 might be grounds for a full price buy for some, but for most people it might be wait-for-sale. You don't have to get it full price, so long as you experience it sooner or later. Sale or not, it doesn't particularly matter in my opinion.

Now I finally was able to beat judgement after almost an entire week taking 31 hours of my life and I do not regret it for a second. The game has a lot to offer compared to other games I have played not surprising since this is from the same people who made Yakuza.

So If I could rate this game out of ten I would give it a 8.5/10. It takes itself seriously and then at the same point you will be forced to bond with a child. It is stupid sometimes and over the top but honestly that is the charm of the game. I just want to say the pros and cons real quick.

Pros:

Combat - Unique with two unique styles which change the style of combat instead of Yakuza where it usually has more impact, this focuses on speed and movement. SO you will be moving around quickly in the air like a monkey pouncing onto dudes constantly. It is addictive.

Story - Quite unique following a ongoing elaborate case of "what you would do to justify your goals?" However most of the time with some of these segments you will be interrupted from a serious scene to a music tone shift which focuses on comedy. It happens often in the early game and it can be quite jarring.

Soundtrack - Very unique soundtrack especially the theme for "the mole" but honestly with the amount of reused tracks there are for certain sequences, They have a lot of variety. I suggest listening to a couple of spotify, since some are absoulte gems.

Side Content - It is Yakuza side content, silly, wacky and weird however not necessary to complete (most of the time)

Clan Encounters - At random points you will be contacted that a rival gang is out on the streets looking for you, why is it good. Well if you need higher chances of being in encounters plus the luck potion you can have a easy time farming. However it can get annoying when you are on other important missions like main quests and they pop up.

Now THE CONS:

First 6 Chapters - I have no idea how but this introduction is so weak. It helps you get to characters and settings but after your first tailing mission it sends you on a  bunch of meaningless fetch quests and just when something intresting is about to happen you are pulled back to do a mandatory side quest. Here is my question...why?! It is the only way to progress and sometimes you have to do an additional 2 or 3 which take 20 or more minutes. Look I understanding waiting around for info but this is ridiculous.If it happened once in the introduction I wouldn't mind but this happens for at least the first 6 chapters before it starts to ignore it. I dislike it extremely.

Trailing Missions, Lock Picking, etc. - Now I understand trying to diverse a game's options and mechanics but sometimes it feels pointless and unwanted. If these were only used sparingly or well optimized maybe it would have been better but sometimes you have to be close to pixel perfect in order to pull off some of these missions. As side content that makes sense but as most of the mechanics it feels annoying when it pops up for the 50th time.

but other than that the game works as intended and is really fun...I just wish you know some of these methods didn't keep prompting up. Also I listened to this game through its english dub and subtiltes I think it is fine, if you disagree fight me.

Hope this will help you if you ever think about buying it. Personally I recommend it.

I'll be completely honest - I haven't progressed very far into the game, and I'm only on chapter two.

However: This game just isn't as fun as any other Yakuza game.
Yes, I'm a major sucker for Kiryu, Majima etc. but that has 0 impact on why I'm not a huge fan of this iteration.
I wasn't a big fan of Like a Dragon, but surprisingly enough I've sunk more hours into that game than any other Yakuza game.
I can't see myself throwing as many hours into this one as any of the others.

Kamurucho is glorious - Further more it's nice being able to "parkour" around the town, and take some of the small "shortcuts" into side alleys that we've never been able to before.
Whenever I played a new game, it was always one of the top things for me to figure out: "What has changed this time around" and for the most part it hasn't disappointed me.
The major grief I have with the town is the removal of Karaoke - Why couldn't they have left out Mahjong instead? xD

Tailing is probably the worst "game mechanic" I've ever experienced in this universe since they turned the series into a flawed RPG game (Holy fack it's flawed). It seems pointless, slow and it's just plain horrible.
It's even worse than unskipable cutscenes/dialogue.
Next up is the entire investigation crap...
I get it - We're a detective yada yada yada. But why does it have to be so horrible?! And now we have to present our case to convince people of A, B and C?!?

The fighting styles suck - Yes, I haven't unlocked that many skills yet, but they're so clunky and slow. After finishing a combo he'll just stand there for 2 hours while being open to attacks.
The lock-on system is a major downgrade compared to any of the previous games and the new EX meter sucks.
And don't get me started on the freakin' drones.. I thought I wasn't a fan of the toy-car races but seriously.. fuck that drone - And fuck having to scout out areas with it too!
While not having a real impact yet, even on hard, I can't see any reason why the new wound system is in place. It seems weird and horrible at the same time.

Some of the, few, things I welcome in this game is some of the new mini games (zombie shooter is amazing!), the more nimble character (actually being slim enough to go through narrow paths lol) and the removal of weapons/gear but sadly that's about all the positives I can come up with at this point.

When I noticed the game got released, I basically blew my budget to get the collection and sadly I have to admit that I deeply regret it.
I thought I disliked the new direction of Like a Dragon, but honestly I hope this spin-off dies. The sooner the better.

TL:DR - BRING BACK MAH KARAOKE!!!

Doesn't help that anyone who's played the mainline Yakuza games would be already really familiar with this particular town, and they haven't even added the rooftops except for around three small buildings  
My recommendation still stands, however

A great port of a great game. As a spin-off of the Yakuza series, it obviously is cut from the same cloth in a lot of ways but the game definitely stands out as something more than just a spin off especially with it's detective slant. If it wasn't for the somewhat slow start before the main plot really kicks off and for the tedious and unreasonably abundant tailing missions, it would be up for consideration as the best in the series. The story is fantastic, the characters are very interesting, has some beautiful visuals at times, a RIDICULOUSLY good soundtrack, fantastic voice work and a surprisingly solid English dub for their first time since the series' recent popularity boom, combat becomes hilarious fun, and its packed full with tons of fun side content. 

It's easy to get hooked into the main story once it starts to really kick off early on. But its also just as easy to get hooked into ignoring the main story so you can go play darts with your weeaboo ninja friend Ryan Acosta, or going through the drone racing grand prix, or solving side cases about a pervert named Ass Catchem. Love this game. 

Also does not need any prior knowledge of the mainline Yakuza series to get into.

Played through this on PS4 and am going through it again. An amazing Yakuza spin-off game that takes place in the same universe as the mainline games. The Yakuza series has always been heavily story driven and I've enjoyed the stories present in every game in the series despite their flaws. However, Judgement takes the story aspect of the franchise to a new level. It's such an amazing tale filled with many twists and turns. On top of that the game delivers what you expect from other Yakuza games: tons of mini games, plenty of side quests, cathartic combat with a ton of unlockable abilities, beautiful graphics, and a banger soundtrack. 

Highly recommended if you enjoy the Yakuza games or if the trailer looks interesting to you. You don't need to play the other Yakuza games to understand this one. It's a completely stand-alone story and the saga continues in its sequel: Lost Judgement.

Positive:
+ Yakuza Gameplay - beat people up proper 
+ Side Cases and Minigames all over Kamurocho to play 
+ If you pick a wrong option during a "interrogation" the game wont make you restart from a checkpoint, it just simply tells you it makes no sense and lets you retry from the point at which you can choose the option

+ your Healthbar can be "destroyed" by quite a bit if you get stabbed or shot, neat idea (only annoying that you take that damage before you find a way to fix your health)

- The second you get a "major" hint for the story, the game makes sure you realize what the hint is about
- Game breaking bug / softlock regarding a certain Skill

- Street fights are pretty much worthless to attend, they offer 0 Money and only very few skill points (depends on the amount of people you fight)
- the occasionly appearing gang is just plain annoying lol

It's an RGG game, so you can expect great gameplay, writing, etc.  I'm just gonna focus on some other cool technical features (some may have already existed on console).

- Tons of customization including pages of custom controls for each aspect of the game, really good sound customization, and even the option to turn off autosave.  Graphics customization is fairly run of the mill.
- Can pause (and of course skip) cutscenes.  (though it is weird, some sequences when you pause, it only takes you to custom controls)

Well...that's about it.  It's the small stuff, that plenty of devs still ignore, that really matters to me.  Bravo to RGG.

I played this game on the PS5 before the pc port released today so my review will be talking about my experience on PS5 compared to my experience so far on PC.

This game right here is one of the great RGG titles that everyone should at least check out. The combat is similar to Yakuza 0 with how you have styles that you can switch on the fly, that being the Crane Style and the Tiger Style, Crane is more used for crowd control while Tiger is more used for 1v1 fights, but that's what they want you to think, because you can use either style in different ways, even if Crane isn't as good as Tiger, you can start a juggle combo using Tiger and switch to Crane for the more wider and quicker kicks with EX Boost.

The story is amazing, probably one of the best stories RGG has put out next to Yakuza 0, 7, and Lost Judgment. As this is the first game in the Judgment series to follow Yagami and his group, this is a fantastic start, with a captivating case, which originally starts as something small like a serial killing that leads to something even bigger than just a serial killing, without getting into spoilers.

The amount of Side Content in this game also is amazing, 50 Side Cases, and 50 Friends, a huge completion list like how it was in other Yakuza games, my bane of existence the Keihin Gang (probably the only thing that sucks in the game though the bosses are cool), the Judgment games as much as it is serious in its main story, balances that out with the wackiness from the side cases it has, though I did wish that certain points in the main story didn't stop for a mandatory side case.

The detective stuff in the game is alright, the tailing missions as much as i did like them, get boring after the 6th time doing one, especially with the last tailing mission in the main story which is drawn out so long that i wished that it was just a cutscene instead, search mode is a fine addition, especially with the amount of SP you get for just looking around your surroundings, also the cats :3. Lockpicking and it's other counterpart for turnknobs is a pretty neat addition as well, and not as annoying as skyrim's. Chasing is fun, not to short, not to long, they are nice to have the adrenaline pumping after the slow parts.

Now talking about the PC port, yeah its a PC port, basically if you were able to run dragon engine games in the past, you should be able to run this game without that many problems, but it is really nice to have after the long waiting for the PC port. Can't wait to see how modders take this apart, especially on how johnny and associates have prevented us from getting this game on PC because of that reason.

So, if your a Yakuza fan, then this is a must play, if you never played Yakuza game in your life, this is a great starting point to the world of Yakuza and its city Kamurocho.

[h1]The Game Itself:[/h1]


If you enjoy the Yakuza series, then look no further. This spinoff puts you in the roll of a disgraced attorney turned detective who, after taking whatever jobs come his way, gets sucked into the underground crime of Tokyo to solve a string of horrifying murders. With the signature Yakuza combat and 2 styles to fight, a giant city to explore, and the incredible story-telling the series is known for, Judgment is not a game to skip. The shakeup of working as a detective and emphasis on investigation instead of fighting is a lot of fun and brings a welcome change to the series known for being a hardened Yakuza member.


[h1]Steam Deck Performance:[/h1]


Judgment runs significantly better than I expected on the Steam Deck. I assumed it would be a lot harder to optimize, but as soon as the game started, it was a welcome breath of fresh air. The game won't be a stable 60 FPS, unless you are okay draining your battery within 1.5 hours, but 40 FPS is not only achievable, but feels incredible with over 3 hours of battery life. There are some pockets of framerate drops when loading in new areas, but overall, it was worth it for the smoothness, battery life, and low temps.

To my surprise, Judgment also has FSR 2.0 incorporated into it, which was really unexpected. FSR 2.0 is the 2nd generation of AMD's upscaling technology, which allows a game to run much better on lower end devices by upscaling from a lower resolution internally. FSR 2.0 is not turned on by default though, so you do need to go to settings and fiddle with it. The game also offers cloud saves which, as a desktop PC gamer, will be fantastic to go back and forth on.

Overall, I was impressed with the performance. You can set the game down to 30 FPS to minimize all drops, though you can still feel them, but the upgraded smoothness of 40 FPS won me over. If you are hoping to play this game on the Steam Deck, then I have good news for you, it is DEFINITELY playable. Full detailed settings we used can be found on our website below.
